original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Honour to that Blessed One, accomplished and fully enlightened.

original: Saṃyuttanikāye🔽Khandhavaggaṭīkā
analyzed: saṃyutta nikāye
translated: In the Connected Discourses🔽The Section on the Aggregates

original: 1. Khandhasaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Nakulapituvaggo
analyzed: khandha saṃyuttam  nakula pitu vaggo
translated: The Aggregates Connected Discourses🔽The Group of Nakula’s Father

original: 1. Nakulapitusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nakula pitu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse with Nakula’s Father

original: 1. Bhaggā nāma jānapadino rājakumārā. Tesaṃ nivāso ekopi janapado ruḷhīvasena “bhaggā”tveva
analyzed: bhaggāḥ nāma jānapadinaḥ rāja kumārā tesam nivāsaḥ ekaḥ api janapadaḥ ruḷhī vasena
translated: “Bhaggā” is the name of a people of the countryside. Their country, which is inhabited by them, is called “Bhaggā” because of its being inhabited by them.

original: vuccatīti katvā vuttaṃ “evaṃnāmake janapade”ti, evaṃ bahuvacanavasena laddhanāme”ti
analyzed: vuccati iti katvā vuttam evaṃnāmake janapade iti evam bahuvacana vasena laddha nāmā iti
translated: Thus it is said, “in a country of that name.” The meaning is: “in a country that has got its name by means of a plural🔽form.”

original: attho. Tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍeti yo pana vanasaṇḍo pubbe migānaṃ abhayatthāya dinno, tasmiṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ tasmim vana saṇḍe iti yaḥ pana vana saṇḍaḥ pubbe migānam abhaya tthāya dinnaḥ tasmim
translated: In that forest grove: in that forest grove which was formerly given for the protection of deer.

original: vanasaṇḍe. Yasmā so gahapati tasmiṃ nagare “nakulapitā”ti puttassa vasena paññāyittha,
analyzed: vanasaṇḍe saḥ gahapati tasmim nagare nakula pitā ati puttassa vasena paññāyittha
translated: Since that householder was known in that town by the name “Nakula’s father” because of his son,

original: tasmā vuttaṃ “nakulapitā”ti nakulassa nāma dārakassa pitāti attho. Bhariyāpissa “nakulamātā”ti paññāyittha.
analyzed: tasmā vuttam nakula pitā ti nakulassa nāma dārakassa pitā ati atthaḥ bhariyā apissa nakula mātā iti paññāyittha
translated: it is said, “Nakula’s father.” The meaning is: the father of the boy named Nakula. His wife was known as “Nakula’s mother.”🔽Old and frail: frail because of old age, not frail because of disease, etc. Aged and

original: Jarājiṇṇoti jarāvasena jiṇṇo, na byādhiādīnaṃ vasena jiṇṇo. Vayovuḍḍhoti jiṇṇattā
analyzed: jarā jiṇṇaḥ iti jarā vasena jiṇṇaḥ na byādhi ādīnam vasena jiṇṇaḥ vayaḥ vuḍḍhaḥ ti jiṇṇa ttā
translated: advanced in life: frail because of old age.

original: eva vayovuḍḍhippattiyā vuḍḍho, na sīlādivuḍḍhiyā. Jātiyā mahantatāya cirarattatāya
analyzed: eva vayaḥ vuḍḍhi ppattiyā vuḍḍhaḥ na sīla ādi vuḍḍhiyā jātiyā mahantatāya cira ratta tāya
translated: He is of great age because of the greatness of his age, because of his long life.

original: jātimahallako. Tiyaddhagatoti paṭhamo majjhimo pacchimoti tayo addhe gato. Tattha
analyzed: jāti mahallako tiya ddha gato ti paṭhamaḥ majjhimo pacchimo ti tayo addhe gato tattha
translated: He has gone beyond the middle of the three: the first, middle, and last of the three periods of life.🔽He has gone beyond the first and middle periods and has reached the last period of life.

original: paṭhamaṃ dutiyañca atikkantattā pacchimaṃ upagatattā vayoanuppatto. Āturakāyoti dukkhavedanāpavisatāya
analyzed: paṭhamam dutiyam ca atikkanta ttā pacchimam upagata ttā vayaḥ anuppatto ātura kāyo ti dukkha vedanā pavisa tāya
translated: He is afflicted because of the presence of painful feeling.🔽He is a body of suffering because of the absence of satisfaction.

original: anassādakāyo. Gelaññaṃ pana dukkhagatikanti “gilānakāyo”ti vuttaṃ. Tathā hi saccavibhaṅge
analyzed: anassāda kāyaḥ gelaññam pana dukkha gatikanti gilāna kāyaḥ ti vuttam tathā hi sacca vibhaṅge
translated: But sickness is the cause of suffering. Therefore it is said: “He is a sick body.”

original: dukkhasaccaniddese dukkhaggahaṇeneva gahitattā byādhi na niddiṭṭho. Niccapaggharaṇaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: dukkha sacca niddese dukkha ggahaṇena iva gahita ttā na niddiṭṭhaḥ nicca paggharaṇa ṭṭhena ati
translated: For in the explanation of the truth of suffering in the Saccavibhanga, sickness is not mentioned separately because it is included in the mention of suffering.

original: sabbadā asucipaggharaṇabhāvena. So panassa āturabhāvenāti āha – “āturaṃyeva nāmā”ti.
analyzed: sabbadā asuci paggharaṇa bhāvena so pana assa ātura bhāvena ati āha nāma ati
translated: By the word “always” is meant: by the nature of constantly oozing impurity.🔽But his affliction is by aging.

original: Visesenāti adhikabhāvena. Āturatīti āturo. Saṅgāmappatto santattakāyo. Jarāya āturatā
analyzed: visesena ati adhika bhāvena āturati iti āturaḥ saṅgāma patto santatta kāyaḥ jarāya ātura tā
translated: By the word “especially” is meant: by the excess of aging. He is afflicted by aging. He is a body that has entered the battle.

original: jarāturatā. Kusalapakkhavaḍḍhanena mano bhāventīti manobhāvanīyā. Manasā vā bhāvanīyā
analyzed: jarā ātura tā kusala pakkha vaḍḍhanena manaḥ bhāventi iti manaḥ bhāvanīyā manasā vā bhāvanīyā
translated: “Old age and death” . “To be developed by mind” : they are to be developed by the mind through the increase of the side of merit. Or they are to be developed by the mind through the mind .🔽“To be respected” : they are to be developed by mind .

original: sambhāvanīyāti manobhāvanīyā. Anusāsatūti anu anu sāsatūti ayamettha atthoti āha
analyzed: sambhāvanīyā ati manaḥ bhāvanīyā anusāsatu uti anu anu sāsatu uti ayam ettha atthaḥ ti āha
translated: “To be admonished” : to admonish again and again. This is the meaning here.

original: – “punappunaṃ sāsatū”ti. Aparāparaṃ pavattitaṃ hitavacanaṃ. Anotiṇṇe vatthusmiṃ yo
analyzed: punappunam sāsatu iti apara aparam hita vacanam anotiṇṇe vatthusmim yaḥ
translated: “To be admonished again and again” means the repeated utterance of what is beneficial. “In a matter not yet penetrated” means

original: evaṃ karoti, tassa ayaṃ guṇo dosoti vacanaṃ. Tantivasenāti tantisannissayena ayaṃ
analyzed: evam karoti tassa ayam guṇaḥ doso ti vacanam tanti vasena ati tanti sannissayena ayam
translated: the utterance of the quality or the fault of one who acts thus. “By the thread” means by the support of the thread .

original: anusāsanī nāma. Paveṇīti tantiyā eva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: anusāsanī nāma paveṇī iti tantiyāḥ eva vevacanam
translated: This is called “admonition” . “Thread” is a synonym for “string” .

original: Aṇḍaṃ viya bhūtoti adhikopamā kāyassa aṇḍakosato abaladubbalabhāvato. Tenāha “aṇḍaṃ hī”tiādi. Bāloyeva tādisattabhāvasamaṅgī muhuttampi ārogyaṃ paṭijānanto.
analyzed: aṇḍam viya bhūtaḥ ti adhikā upamā kāyassa aṇḍa kosataḥ abala dubbala bhāvataḥ tena āha aṇḍam hi itiādi tādi satta bhāva samaṅgī muhuttam pi ārogyam paṭijānanto
translated: “The being is like an egg” is a simile based on the egg . The body is like an egg because of its weakness and feebleness. Therefore it is said: “For an egg . . . ” . “Like a hair” means one who possesses such a state of being should not even for a moment claim to be healthy.

original: Vippasannānīti pakatimākāraṃ atikkamitvā visesena pasannāni. Tenāha – “suu pasannānī”ti.
analyzed: vippasannāni iti pakatim ākāram atikkamitvā visesena pasannāni tena āha
translated: “Clear” means surpassing the ordinary appearance and being especially clear. Therefore it is said: “Very clear” .

original: Pasannacittasamuṭṭhitarūpasampadāhi tāhi tassa mukhavaṇṇassa pārisuddhīti āha – “parisuddhoti
analyzed: pasanna citta samuṭṭhita rūpa sampadāhi tāhi tassa mukha vaṇṇassa pārisuddhī iti āha parisuddhaḥ ti
translated: and the purity of his facial expression was due to the excellence of the materiality originated by the mind of one who is confident. Therefore he said: “Pure means

original: niddoso”ti. Tenevāha “nirupakkilesatāyā”tiādi. Etenevassindriyavippasannatākāraṇampi
analyzed: niddoso ti tena iva āha nirupakkilesa tāya atiādi
translated: free from stain.” Consequently he said: “For the sake of freedom from defilement,” etc. By this he also shows the reason for the clarity of the faculties.

original: saṃvaṇṇitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Esa mukhavaṇṇo. Nayaggāhapaññā kiresāti idaṃ anāvajjanavaseneva
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇitanti daṭṭhabbam esa mukha vaṇṇaḥ naya ggāha paññā kiresa ati idam an āvajjana vasena iva
translated: This is the facial expression. The words “and the wisdom of his grasp of the method” are said with reference to the fact that he spoke thus

original: vuttabhāvaṃ sandhāyāha.🔽Yaṃ neva puttassātiādi “ovadatu no, bhante, bhagavā yathā mayaṃ paralokepi aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: vutta bhāvam sandhāya āha  yam na iva puttassa atiādi ovadatu naḥ bhante bhagavā yathā mayam para loke pi aññam aññam
translated: without having been asked.

original: samāgaccheyyāmā”ti vuttavacanaṃ sandhāya vuttameva. Madhuradhammadesanāyeva satthu
analyzed: samāgaccheyyāma iti vutta vacanam sandhāya vuttam eva madhura dhamma desanāya iva satthu
translated: The words “What is not even for a son” and so on are said with reference to the words spoken by them: “Venerable sir, let the Blessed One advise us, let him instruct us, so that we may meet together in the future life also.”

original: sammukhā paṭiladdhā, tassa attano pemagāravagahitattā “amatābhiseko”ti veditabbo.
analyzed: sammukhā paṭiladdhā tassa attano amata abhisekaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: The “anointing with the deathless” should be understood as the sweet preaching of the Dhamma received by them in the presence of the Teacher, which they had accepted with love and respect.

original: Idaṃ padadvayaṃ. Ārakattā kilesehi maggena samucchinnattā. Anayeti avaḍḍhiyaṃ, anattheti
analyzed: idam pada dvayam āraka ttā kilesehi maggena samucchinna ttā anayā iti avaḍḍhiyam anattha iti
translated: This pair of terms. Because of distance from defilements, and because of their cutting off by the path. “Unchanging” means not increasing; “unadulterated” means

original: attho. Anaye vā anupāye. Na iriyanato avattanato. Ayeti vaḍḍhiyaṃ atthe upāye ca.
analyzed: atthaḥ anaye vā anupāye na iriyanataḥ avattanataḥ vaḍḍhiyam atthe upāye ca
translated: Attha means: either “not a means” or “not a way.” Na iriyanato avattanato means: not by way of going or by way of occurrence. Ayeti means: in the sense of increase, in the sense of a means.

original: Araṇīyatoti payirupāsitabbato. Niruttinayena padasiddhi veditabbā purimesu atthavikappesu,
analyzed: araṇīyataḥ iti nirutti nayena pada siddhi veditabbā purimesu attha vikappesu
translated: Araṇīyato means: in the sense of being worthy of worship. The derivation of the words should be understood by the method of etymology in the first three meanings,🔽but in the last by the method of the science of grammar.

original: pacchime pana saddasatthavasenapi. Yadipi ariyasaddo “ye hi vo ariyā parisuddhakāyakammantā”tiādīsu
analyzed: pacchime pana sadda sattha vasena api yadi pi ariya saddaḥ ye hi vaḥ ariyā parisuddha kāya kammantā ati ādīsu
translated: Although the word ariya is used in the sense of a person of pure intention in such passages as “those who are ariyas, who are pure in bodily action” ,

original: visuddhāsayapayogesu puthujjanesupi vaṭṭati, idha pana ariyamaggādhigamena sabbalokuttarabhāvena
analyzed: visuddha āsaya payogesu puthujjanesu pi vaṭṭati idha pana ariya magga adhigamena sabba lokuttara bhāvena
translated: here the meaning intended is the state of being ariya by the attainment of the noble path and by the state of being supramundane.

original: ca ariyabhāvo adhippetoti dassento āha – “buddhā cā”tiādi. Tattha paccekabuddhā tathāgatasāvakā
analyzed: ca ariya bhāvaḥ adhippetaḥ ti dassentaḥ āha buddhā ca atiādi tattha paccekabuddhā tathāgata sāvakā
translated: To show this he says: “Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples, and also the good person” . Herein, the Paccekabuddhas and the disciples of the Perfect Sambuddhas are called “good persons” .

original: ca sappurisāti idaṃ “ariyā sappurisā”ti idha vuttapadānaṃ atthaṃ asaṅkarato dassetuṃ
analyzed: ca sappurisā ti idam ariyā sappurisā ti idha vutta padānam attham asaṅkarataḥ dassetuṃ
translated: This is said in order to show without confusion the meaning of the words “ariyas” and “sappurisas” used here.

original: vuttaṃ. Yasmā pana nippariyāyato ariyasappurisabhāvā abhinnasabhāvā, tasmā “sabbeva vā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam yasmā pana nippariyāyataḥ ariya sappurisa bhāvā abhinna sabhāvā tasmā sabbā iva vā tiādi vuttam
translated: But since they are ariyas and good persons in the ultimate sense, they are of undifferentiated nature. Therefore it is said: “All are ariyas” , etc.

original: Ettāvatā hi buddhasāvako vutto, tassa hi ekantena kalyāṇamitto icchitabbo parato
analyzed: ettāvatā hi buddha sāvakaḥ vuttaḥ tassa hi ekantena kalyāṇa mitto icchitabbo paratas
translated: For it is at this point that the disciple of the noble ones is spoken of. For he must be one who has a wholly virtuous friend.

original: ghosamantarena paṭhamamaggassa anuppajjanato. Visesato cassa bhagavāva “kalyāṇamitto”ti
analyzed: ghosam antarena paṭhama maggassa anuppajjanato visesato ca ssa bhagavā ava kalyāṇa mittaḥ ti
translated: For it is at this point that a disciple of the Buddha is referred to. For he must be one who has a wholly virtuous friend, since the first path arises in him only with the help of another’s speech.

original: adhippeto. Vuttañhetaṃ “mamañhi, ānanda, kalyāṇamittaṃ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā
analyzed: adhippetaḥ vuttam ha etam maman hi ānanda kalyāṇa mittam āgamma jāti dhammāḥ sattāḥ jātiyā
translated: And the Blessed One is particularly intended here as “a virtuous friend.” For this is said: “Ānanda, it is by coming to me as a virtuous friend that creatures subject to birth are freed from birth,

original: parimuccantī”tiādi. So eva ca aveccapasādādhigamena daḷhabhatti nāma. Vuttampi cetaṃ
analyzed: parimuccanti itiādi saḥ eva ca avecca pasāda adhigamena daḷhabhatti nāma
translated: and so on. And he is called “a dear and beloved friend” because of his attainment of entire confidence. For this is said:

original: “yaṃ mayā sāvakānaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ, taṃ mama sāvakā jīvitahetupi nātikkamantī”ti.🔽Kataññutādīhi paccekabuddhabuddhāti ettha kataṃ jānātīti kataññū. Kataṃ viditaṃ pākaṭaṃ🔽karotīti katavedī. Paccekabuddhā hi anekesupi kappasatasahassesu kataṃ upakāraṃ jānanti,
analyzed: yam mayā sāvakānam sikkhāpadam paññattam tam mama sāvakāḥ jīvita hetu pi na atikkamanti iti  kataññu tā ādīhi paccekabuddha buddha ati ettha katam jānāti iti kataññū katam viditam pākaṭam  karoti iti kata vedī paccekabuddhāḥ hi anekesu pi kappa sata sahassesu katam upakāram jānanti
translated: “My disciples do not transgress even the slightest training rule, though their lives may be at risk, because they have come to me as a dear and beloved friend.”🔽As to “a Buddha and a Paccekabuddha because of gratitude, etc.,” he knows what is done, thus he is grateful . He makes what is done evident, thus he is thankful . For Paccekabuddhas know what service was done to them even in hundreds of thousands of past ages,

original: katañca pākaṭaṃ karonti satijananaāmisapaṭiggahaṇādinā. Tathā saṃsāradukkhadukkhitassa
analyzed: katam ca pākaṭam karonti sati janana āmisa paṭiggahaṇa ādinā tathā saṃsāra dukkha dukkhitassa
translated: and they make what was done evident by their recollection of it and by their acceptance of material benefits, and so on. And they are grateful and thankful to those who serve them in the dispensation of the present Buddha,

original: sakkaccaṃ karonti kiccaṃ, yaṃ attanā kātuṃ sakkā. Sammāsambuddho pana kappānaṃ asaṅkhyeyyasahassesupi
analyzed: sakkaccam karonti kiccam yam attanā kātum sakkā sammāsambuddhaḥ pana kappānam asaṅkhyeyya sahassesu pi
translated: They do their duty well, whatever can be done by themselves.🔽But the Fully Enlightened One, for thousands of aeons incalculable in extent,

original: kataṃ upakāraṃ maggaphalānaṃ upanissayañca jānanti, pākaṭañca karonti. Sīho viya
analyzed: katam upakāram magga phalānam upanissayam ca jānanti pākaṭam ca karonti sīhaḥ viya
translated: They do their duty well, each according to his ability. But the Fully Enlightened One knows the help given by beings in the past during the time of the Buddhas of the past, and he knows the support given by them for the attainment of the paths and fruits. And he makes it evident. Like a lion

original: ca evaṃ sabbattha sakkaccameva dhammadesanaṃ karontena buddhakiccaṃ karonti. Yāya🔽paṭipattiyā ariyā diṭṭhā nāma honti, tassā appaṭipajjanaṃ, tattha ca ādarābhāvo ariyānaṃ
analyzed: ca evam sabbattha sakkaccam eva dhamma desanam karontena buddha kiccam karonti  paṭipattiyā ariyāḥ diṭṭhāḥ nāma honti tassāḥ appaṭipajjanam tattha ca ādara abhāvaḥ ariyānaṃ
translated: he teaches the Dhamma everywhere with the same carefulness. Thus they do the Buddha’s work.

original: adassanasīlatā, na ca dassane sādhukāritāti veditabbā. Cakkhunā adassāvīti ettha
analyzed: a dassana sīla tā na ca dassane sādhu kāri tā ati veditabbā cakkhunā a dassāvī iti ettha
translated: The failure to practice the way by which one becomes a noble one, and the lack of respect for it, are to be understood as the habit of not seeing the noble ones and the failure to do them honour when one sees them. As to the words “not seeing with the eye”

original: cakkhu nāma na maṃsacakkhu eva, atha kho dibbacakkhupīti āha “dibbacakkhunā vā”ti.
analyzed: cakkhu nāma na maṃsa cakkhu eva atha kho āha dibba cakkhunā vā ati
translated: here, the eye is not only the fleshly eye but also the divine eye. Thus it is said: “Or with the divine eye” .

original: Ariyabhāvoti yehi yogato “ariyā”ti vuccanti, te maggaphaladhammā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: ariya bhāvo ti yehi yogataḥ ariyā ati vuccanti te magga phala dhammāḥ daṭṭhabbā
translated: The noble state: the path and fruit dhammas should be understood by which one is called “noble” in the sense of being yoked to them.

original: Tatrāti ñāṇadassanasseva dassanabhāve. Vatthūti adhippetatthañāpanakāraṇaṃ. Evaṃ
analyzed: tatra ati ñāṇa dassanassa iva dassana bhāve vatthu uti adhippeta ttha ñāpana kāraṇam evam
translated: There: in the seeing of the knowledge and vision itself. Ground: the reason for the knowledge of the intended meaning.

original: vuttepīti evaṃ aññāpadesena attupanāyikaṃ katvā vuttepi. Dhammanti lokuttaradhammaṃ,
analyzed: vutte pi iti evam añña apadesena attupanāyikam katvā vutte pi dhammam ti lokuttara dhammam
translated: And also when spoken of thus: when the supramundane Dhamma or the Dhamma of the four truths is spoken of by way of the words “other” and “self.”

original: catusaccadhammaṃ vā. Ariyakaradhammā aniccānupassanādayo, vipassiyamānā vā aniccādayo,
analyzed: catu sacca dhammam vā ariya kara dhammāḥ anicca anupassana ādayaḥ vipassiyamānāḥ vā anicca ādayaḥ
translated: The Dhamma of the noble individuals is the contemplations of impermanence, etc., or impermanence, etc., as they are contemplated,

original: cattāri vā ariyasaccāni.
analyzed: cattāri vā ariya saccāni
translated: or the four noble truths.

original: Avinītoti na vinīto adhisīlasikkhādīnaṃ vasena na sikkhito. Yesaṃ saṃvaravinayādīnaṃ
analyzed: avinītaḥ ti na vinītaḥ adhi sīla sikkhā ādīnam vasena na sikkhitaḥ yesam saṃvara vinaya ādīnam
translated: Untaught: not taught, not trained, not disciplined in the higher training of virtue, etc.🔽The “untaught ordinary person” is so called because of the absence of the following:🔽The restraint of virtue, the restraint of mindfulness, the restraint of knowledge, and the restraint of energy.

original: abhāvena ayaṃ “avinīto”ti vuccati, te tāva dassetuṃ “duvidho vinayo nāmā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: abhāvena ayam avinītaḥ ti vuccati te tāva dassetum duvidhaḥ vinayaḥ nāma ati ādim āha
translated: To show these, he says, “Restraint is of two kinds.”

original: Tattha sīlasaṃvaroti pātimokkhasaṃvaro veditabbo, so ca atthato kāyikavācasiko avītikkamo.
analyzed: tattha sīla saṃvaro ti pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ veditabbo saḥ ca atthataḥ kāyika vācasikaḥ avītikkamaḥ
translated: Herein, the restraint of virtue should be understood as the restraint by the Pāṭimokkha, which in meaning is non-transgression by way of body and speech.

original: Satisaṃvaroti indriyārakkhā, sā ca tathāpavattā satiyeva. Ñāṇasaṃvaroti “sotānaṃ
analyzed: sati saṃvaroti indriya ārakkhā sā ca tathā pavattā satiyā iva ñāṇa saṃvaroti
translated: The restraint of mindfulness is the guarding of the sense faculties, which is mindfulness occurring in that way.

original: saṃvaraṃ brūmī”ti vatvā “paññāyete pidhīyare”ti vacanato sotasaṅkhātānaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhiduccaritaavijjāavasiṭṭhakilesānaṃ
analyzed: saṃvaram brūmi iti vatvā paññāyete vacanato sota saṅkhātānam taṇhā diṭṭhi duccarita avijjā avasiṭṭha kilesānam
translated: The restraint of knowledge is the restraint of the taints by means of the knowledge of arising, passing away, etc., as stated in the passage: “I say that the ending of the taints is for one who knows and sees, bhikkhus, not for one who does not know and does not see. For one who knows what and sees what? The eye, bhikkhus, is not the taints… eye-consciousness is not the taints… eye-contact is not the taints… Whatever feeling arises with eye-contact as condition… that is not the taints, but from that taints originate.🔽The ear… nose… tongue… body… mind… mind-consciousness… mind-contact… Whatever feeling arises with mind-contact as condition whether pleasant or painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant—that is not the taints, but from that taints originate.

original: saṃvaro pidahanaṃ samucchedañāṇanti veditabbaṃ. Khantisaṃvaroti adhivāsanā, sā ca
analyzed: saṃvaraḥ pidahanam samuccheda ñāṇan ti veditabbam khanti saṃvarā ti adhivāsanā sā ca
translated: restraint should be understood as the covering and the cutting off.🔽Patience as restraint is acquiescence. And that is of two kinds as the acquiescence of endurance and the acquiescence of forbearance.

original: tathāpavattā khandhā, adoso vā, “paññā”ti keci vadanti. Vīriyasaṃvaro kāmavitakkādīnaṃ🔽vinodanavasena pavattaṃ vīriyameva. Tena tena aṅgena tassa tassa aṅgassa pahānaṃ
analyzed: tathā pavattā khandhā adosaḥ vā paññā ti keci vadanti vīriya saṃvaro kāma vitakka ādīnam  vinodana vasena pavattam vīriyam eva tena tena aṅgena tassa tassa aṅgassa pahānam
translated: Restraint should be understood as the covering up and the act of cutting off. Patience as restraint is endurance. And that is the aggregates occurring as such, or it is non-hate, some say. Energy as restraint is the energy occurring as the casting out of sensual desire, etc.,

original: tadaṅgappahānaṃ. Vikkhambhanavasena pahānaṃ vikkhambhanappahānaṃ. Sesapadattayepi eseva nayo.🔽Iminā pātimokkhasaṃvarenātiādi sīlasaṃvarādīnaṃ vivaraṇaṃ. Tattha samupetoti iti-saddo
analyzed: tad aṅga ppahānam vikkhambhana vasena pahānam vikkhambhana ppahānam sesa pada ttaye pi esa iva nayaḥ  iminā pātimokkha saṃvarena ati ādi sīla saṃvara ādīnam vivaraṇam tattha samupetaḥ ti iti saddaḥ
translated: and the abandoning of each of these by means of each of them is the abandoning of that. The abandoning by suppression is the abandoning by suppression. The same method of explanation applies to the remaining three terms.

original: ādiattho. Tena “upagato”tiādinā vibhaṅge āgataṃ saṃvaravibhaṅgaṃ dasseti. Kāyaduccaritādīnanti
analyzed: ādi atthaḥ tena upagataḥ iti ādinā vibhaṅge āgatam saṃvara vibhaṅgam dasseti
translated: By this virtue as restraint, etc., is the explanation of virtue as restraint, etc. Herein, the word iti has the meaning of “thus.” By it he shows the exposition of restraint as stated in the Vibhaṅga thus: “He is furnished with virtue that is fulfilled by the observance of the fundamental and subsidiary training precepts, by restraint of the sense faculties, by moderation in eating, by devoted application to watchfulness, and by the arousing of mindfulness” .

original: dussīlyasaṅkhātānaṃ kāyavacīduccaritādīnaṃ muṭṭhasaccasaṅkhātassa pamādassa, abhijjhādīnaṃ
analyzed: dussīlya saṅkhātānam kāya vacī duccarita ādīnam muṭṭha sacca saṅkhātassa pamādassa abhijjhā ādīnam
translated: By body, speech, and mind, etc., is the abandoning of the bodily misconduct, etc., called “bad conduct,” of the negligence called “lack of clear awareness,” and of the covetousness, etc.,

original: vā akkhantiaññāṇakosajjānañca. Saṃvaraṇatoti pidahanato, vinayanatoti kāyavācācittānaṃ🔽virūpapavattiyā vinayanato, kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ vā apanayanato, kāyādīnaṃ vā jimhapavattiṃ
analyzed: vā akkhanti aññāṇa kosajjānam ca saṃvaraṇataḥ uti pidahanataḥ vinayanataḥ uti kāya vācā cittānam  virūpa pavattiyāḥ vinayanataḥ kāya duccarita ādīnam vā apanayanataḥ kāya ādīnam vā jimha pavattim
translated: and of impatience, ignorance, and negligence. As restraint: as suppression; as disciplining: as disciplining of body, speech, and cognizance,

original: vicchinditvā ujukanayanatoti attho. Paccayasamavāye uppajjanārahānaṃ kāyaduccaritādīnaṃ
analyzed: vicchinditvā ujuka nayanato ti attho paccaya samavāye uppajjana arahānam kāya duccarita ādīnam
translated: or as the removal of bodily misconduct, etc., or as the cutting off of crookedness in the body, etc., and the straightening of it. The meaning is that it is the non-arising in such and such a way of bodily misconduct, etc., that are due to arise when the conditions are complete.

original: tathā tathā anuppādanameva saṃvaraṇaṃ vinayanañca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tathā tathā an uppādanam eva saṃvaraṇam vinayanam ca veditabbam
translated: That is how restraint and disciplining should be understood.🔽The construction is “the abandoning of which.”

original: Yaṃ pahānanti sambandho. “Nāmarūpaparicchedādīsu vipassanāñāṇesū”ti kasmā vuttaṃ?🔽Nanu nāmarūpaparicchedapaccayapariggahakaṅkhāvitaraṇāni na vipassanāñāṇāni sammasanākārena
analyzed: yam pahānan ti sambandhaḥ nāma rūpa pariccheda ādīsu vipassanā ñāṇesu iti kasmā vuttam  nanu nāma rūpa pariccheda paccaya pariggaha kaṅkhā vitaraṇāni na vipassanā ñāṇāni sammasana ākārena
translated: Why is it said “in the kinds of knowledge consisting in insight into mentality-materiality, etc.”?🔽Are not the discernment of mentality-materiality, the investigation of the causal relationship, the resolving of doubts, and the surmounting of uncertainty not kinds of knowledge consisting in insight, since they occur by way of synthesis?

original: appavattanato? Saccametaṃ, vipassanāñāṇassa pana adhiṭṭhānabhāvato evaṃ vuttaṃ. Nāmarūpamattamidaṃ,
analyzed: a pavattanato saccam etam vipassanā ñāṇassa pana adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ evam vuttam nāma rūpa mattam idam
translated: That is so, but it is said thus because they are the footing for the kinds of knowledge consisting in insight. The knowledge that occurs thus “This is mere mentality-materiality”

original: “natthi ettha attā vā attaniyaṃ vā”ti evaṃ pavattañāṇaṃ nāmarūpavavatthānaṃ. Sati
analyzed: natthi ettha attā vā attaniyam vā ati evam pavatta ñāṇam nāma rūpa vavatthānam sati
translated: and “There is no self or anything pertaining to a self here” is the definition of mentality-materiality.

original: vijjamāne khandhapañcakasaṅkhāte kāye, sayaṃ vā satī tasmiṃ kāye diṭṭhi sakkāyadiṭṭhi,
analyzed: vijjamāne khandha pañcaka saṅkhāte kāye sayam vā satī tasmin kāye diṭṭhi sakkāyadiṭṭhi
translated: When there is a body consisting of the five aggregates, the view that it is the self is the “personality view” .🔽And that is the “self view” which occurs as “He regards materiality as the self” .🔽The knowledge of discerning the conditions for that mentality-materiality is

original: sā ca “rūpaṃ attato samanupassatī”ti evaṃ pavattā attadiṭṭhi. Tassa nāmarūpassa kammāvijjādipaccayapariggaṇhanañāṇaṃ
analyzed: sā ca rūpam attataḥ samanupassati iti evam pavattā atta diṭṭhi tassa nāma rūpassa kamma avijja ādi paccaya pariggaṇhana ñāṇam
translated: the “discernment of conditions” .

original: paccayapariggaho. “Natthi hetu, natthi paccayo sattānaṃ saṃkilesāyā”tiādinayappavattā
analyzed: paccaya pariggahaḥ natthi hetu natthi paccayaḥ sattānam saṃkilesāya ati ādi naya ppavattā
translated: The view that there is no cause or condition for the defilement of beings, which occurs thus “There is no cause, there is no condition” ,

original: ahetudiṭṭhi. “Issarapurisapajāpatipakatiaṇukālādīhi loko pavattati nivattati cā”ti🔽tathā tathā pavattā diṭṭhi visamahetudiṭṭhi. Tassevāti paccayapariggahasseva. Kaṅkhāvitaraṇenāti
analyzed: ahetu diṭṭhi issara purisa pajāpati pakati aṇu kāla ādīhi loko pavattati nivattati ca ati  tathā tathā pavattā diṭṭhi visama hetu diṭṭhi tassa iva āti paccaya pariggahassa iva kaṅkhā vitaraṇena ati
translated: is the “wrong view of cause” . The view that the world occurs and ceases through God, the Primal Source, the Lord, the Single Ruler, and so on,🔽which occurs thus, is the “wrong view of a wrong cause” .🔽Of that same discernment of conditions:

original: yathā etarahi nāmarūpassa kammādipaccayato uppatti, evaṃ atīte anāgatepīti tīsu kālesu
analyzed: yathā etarahi nāma rūpassa kamma ādi paccayataḥ uppatti evam atīte anāgate pi iti tīsu kālesu
translated: The knowledge of removing doubt as to how mentality-materiality arises with kamma, etc., as its condition in the three periods of time thus “As mentality-materiality arises with kamma, etc., as its condition now, so it did in the past, and so it will in the future” ,🔽is the “removal of doubt” .

original: vicikicchāpanayanañāṇena. Kathaṃkathībhāvassāti “ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhāna”ntiādinayapavattāya
analyzed: vicikicchā apanayana ñāṇena kathaṃkathībhāvassa ati ahosim nu kho aham atīta maddhā ananti ādi naya pavattāya
translated: The knowledge of removing perplexity as to whether one was in the past, etc., which occurs thus “Was I in the past?

original: saṃsayappavattiyā. Kalāpasammasanenāti “yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppanna”ntiādinā🔽khandhapañcakaṃ ekādasasu okāsesu pakkhipitvā sammasanavasena pavattena vipassanāñāṇena.
analyzed: saṃsaya ppavattiyā kalāpa sammasanena ati yam kiñci rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppanna nti ādinā  khandha pañcakam ekādasasu okāsesu pakkhipitvā sammasana vasena pavattena vipassanā ñāṇena
translated: And the arising of doubt.

original: Ahaṃ mamāti gāhassāti “attā attaniya”nti gahaṇassa. Maggāmaggavavatthānenāti maggāmaggañāṇavisuddhiyā.
analyzed: aham mama ati gāhassa ati attā gahaṇassa magga amagga vavatthānena ati magga amagga ñāṇa visuddhiyā
translated: By the discerning of the aggregates: by the knowledge of insight occurring by way of discerning the five aggregates of clinging in the eleven ways beginning thus: “Whatever material form exists, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near — all material form should be seen as it really is with correct wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’ ”🔽By the defining of the path and the not-path: by the purification by knowledge and vision of the way.

original: Amagge maggasaññāyāti amagge obhāsādike “maggo”ti uppannasaññāya. Yasmā sammadeva
analyzed: amagge magga saññāya ati amagge obhāsa ādike uppanna saññāya yasmai sammat eva
translated: By the perception of the path in the not-path: by the perception that arises in regard to the not-path, such as the obhāsa, etc., as the path.

original: saṅkhārānaṃ udayaṃ passanto “evamete saṅkhārā anurūpakāraṇato uppajjanti, na pana🔽ucchijjantī”ti gaṇhāti, tasmā vuttaṃ “udayadassanena ucchedadiṭṭhiyā”ti. Yasmā pana🔽saṅkhārānaṃ vayaṃ “yadipime saṅkhārā avicchinnā vattanti, uppannuppannā pana appaṭisandhikā
analyzed: saṅkhārānaṃ udayam passantaḥ evam ete saṅkhārāḥ anurūpa kāraṇataḥ uppajjanti na pana 🔽ucchijjanti iti gaṇhāti tasmai vuttam udaya dassanena uccheda diṭṭhiyā ati yasmai pana 🔽vayam yadi pi ime saṅkhārāḥ avicchinnāḥ vattanti uppanna uppannā pana appaṭisandhikā
translated: Since he sees the arising of formations correctly, he understands thus: “In this way these formations arise from appropriate conditions; they do not arise without conditions.🔽They do not arise by their own will, nor by the will of another, nor by the will of a creator, nor by the will of an overlord, nor by the will of a person, nor by the will of a god, nor by the will of Brahmā, nor by the will of a lord of Brahmās, nor by the will of a world-guardian, nor by the will of a lord of the world, nor by the will of a lord of the gods, nor by the will of a lord of the three worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the four worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the six worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the seven worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the eight worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the ten worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the hundred worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the two thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the three thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the four thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the five thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the six thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the seven thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the eight thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the nine thousand worlds, nor by the will of a lord of the ten thousand worlds, nor by

original: nirujjhantevā”ti passato kuto sassataggāho. Tasmā vuttaṃ “vayadassanena sassatadiṭṭhiyā”ti.
analyzed: nirujjhantā iva ati passataḥ kutas sassata ggāho tasmā vuttam vaya dassanena sassata diṭṭhiyā ati
translated: How can the view of eternalism arise in one who sees thus? Hence it was said above: “By seeing dissolution, the view of eternalism.”

original: Bhayadassanenāti bhayatūpaṭṭhānañāṇena. Sabhayeti sabbabhayānaṃ ākarabhāvato sakaladukkhavūpasamasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: bhaya dassanena āti bhaya tu upaṭṭhāna ñāṇena sa bhayā iti sabba bhayānam ākara bhāvato sakala dukkha vūpasama saṅkhātassa
translated: By seeing fear: by the knowledge of appearance as fearful. In what is fearful: in the five aggregates, which are called “fearful” because they are the source of all fear,

original: paramassāsassa paṭipakkhabhāvato ca sabhaye khandhapañcake. Abhayasaññāyāti “abhayaṃ🔽khema”nti uppannasaññāya. Assādasaññā nāma pañcupādānakkhandhesu assādanavasena pavattasaññā,
analyzed: parama ssāsassa paṭipakkha bhāvato ca sa bhaye khandha pañcake abhaya saññāyāti abhayam  khemanti uppanna saññāya assādasaññā nāma pañca upādānakkhandhesu assādana vasena pavatta saññā
translated: and because they are the opposite of the supreme security called the stilling of all suffering.🔽The perception of safety: the perception that arises thinking “safety,”🔽“security,” in regard to the five aggregates. The perception of enjoyment is the perception that occurs in regard to the five aggregates by way of finding enjoyment in them;

original: yo “ālayābhiniveso”tipi vuccati. Abhiratisaññā tattheva abhiramaṇavasena pavattasaññā,🔽yā “nandī”tipi vuccati. Amuccitukāmatā ādānaṃ. Anupekkhā saṅkhārehi anibbindanaṃ,
analyzed: yaḥ ālaya abhinivesaḥ ti pi vuccati abhirati saññā tattha iva abhiramaṇa vasena pavatta saññā  yā nandī iti pi vuccati a muccitu kāma tā ādānam anupekkhā saṅkhārehi anibbindanam
translated: it is called “attachment to sense pleasures.” The perception of delight is the perception that occurs in regard to the five aggregates by way of delighting in them;🔽it is called “delight.” The desire not to be separated: the grasping. Non-equanimity: the non-disenchantment with formations;

original: sālayatāti attho. Dhammaṭṭhitiyaṃ paṭiccasamuppāde. Paṭilomabhāvo sassatucchedaggāho,
analyzed: atthaḥ dhamma ṭṭhitiyam paṭiccasamuppāde paṭiloma bhāvo
translated: the meaning is, “attachment.” In the dependent origination, which is the stability of dhammas. The view of eternalism and annihilationism: the view that is contrary to the order of dependent origination.

original: paccayākārapaṭicchādakamoho vā. Nibbāne ca paṭilomabhāvo saṅkhāresu nati, nibbānapaṭicchādakamoho🔽vā. Saṅkhāranimittaggāhoti yādisassa kilesassa appahīnatā vipassanā saṅkhāranimittaṃ
analyzed: paccaya ākāra paṭicchādaka mohaḥ vā nibbāne ca paṭiloma bhāvaḥ saṅkhāresu na ti nibbāna paṭicchādaka mohaḥ  vā saṅkhāra nimitta ggāhaḥ ti yādisassa kilesassa appahīna tā vipassanā saṅkhāra nimittam
translated: Or it is delusion that conceals the mode of conditionality. And the inclination to formations is the opposite of Nibbāna, or it is delusion that conceals Nibbāna.

original: na muñcati, so kileso, yo “saṃyogābhiniveso”tipi vuccati, saṅkhāranimittaggāhassa,
analyzed: na muñcati so kilesaḥ yo vuccati saṅkhāra nimitta ggāhassa
translated: The “grasping of the sign of formations” is the non-abandoning of a defilement of such-and-such a kind, which prevents insight from being released from the sign of formations. That defilement is called “adherence to rules and vows” .

original: atikkamanameva vā pahānaṃ.
analyzed: atikkamanam eva vā pahānam
translated: The “surmounting of the grasping of the sign of formations” is its abandoning.

original: Pavatti eva pavattibhāvo, pariyuṭṭhānanti attho. Nīvaraṇādidhammānanti ādi-saddena
analyzed: pavatti eva pavatti bhāvaḥ pariyuṭṭhānanti atthaḥ nīvaraṇa ādi dhammānam ti ādi saddena
translated: “The state of occurrence” is occurrence itself; the meaning is, “the state of being obsessed.” “The states beginning with the hindrances” : by the word “beginning”

original: nīvaraṇapakkhiyā kilesā vitakkavicārādayo ca gayhanti. Catunnaṃ ariyamaggānaṃ bhāvitattā
analyzed: nīvaraṇa pakkhiyā kilesā vitakka vicāra ādayo ca catunnam ariya maggānam bhāvita ttā
translated: the defilements associated with the hindrances and the applied and sustained thoughts are included. “By the development of the four noble paths” :

original: accantaṃ appavattibhāvena yaṃ pahānanti sambandho. Kena pana pahānanti? “Ariyamaggehevā”ti
analyzed: accantam appavatti bhāvena yam pahānan ti sambandho kena pana pahānan ti ariya maggehi iva āti
translated: the abandoning is by means of the state of non-occurrence through complete absence of occurrence. “By what is it abandoned?” “By the noble paths themselves.”

original: viññāyamānoyamattho tesaṃ bhāvitattā appavattivacanato. “Samudayapakkhikassā”ti ettha
analyzed: viññāyamānaḥ ayam atthaḥ tesam bhāvita ttā appavatti vacanataḥ samudaya pakkhikassa ti ettha
translated: This is the meaning that should be understood. Because of the development of those paths, there is the statement of non-occurrence. “Of that which is on the side of origination” :

original: cattāropi maggā catusaccābhisamayāti katvā tehi pahātabbena tena tena samudayasaṅkhātena
analyzed: cattāraḥ api maggā catu sacca abhisamayā ti katvā tehi pahātabbena tena tena samudaya saṅkhātena
translated: and because of that it is called “the penetration of the four truths.”

original: lobhena saha pahātabbattā samudayasabhāvattā ca. Saccavibhaṅge ca sabbakilesānaṃ
analyzed: lobhena saha pahātabba ttā samudaya sabhāva ttā ca sacca vibhaṅge ca sabba kilesānam
translated: And in the Description of the Truths the state of being origin is stated of all defilements,🔽so it is said that views, etc., are “on the side of origin” .

original: samudayabhāvassa vuttattā “samudayapakkhikā”ti diṭṭhiādayo vuccanti. Paṭipassaddhattaṃ vūpasantatā.
analyzed: samudaya bhāvassa vutta ttā samudaya pakkhikā ti diṭṭhi ādayaḥ vuccanti paṭipassaddha ttam vūpasanta tā
translated: The state of being calm is the state of being peaceful.🔽The state of being unformed is the absence of the nature of what is formed.

original: Saṅkhatanissaṭatā saṅkhārasabhāvābhāvo. Pahīnasabbasaṅkhatanti virahitasabbasaṅkhataṃ,🔽visaṅkhāranti attho. Pahānañca taṃ vinayo cāti pahānavinayo purimena atthena. Dutiyena
analyzed: saṅkhata nissaṭa tā saṅkhāra sabhāva abhāvaḥ pahīna sabba saṅkhata nti virahita sabba saṅkhatam  visaṅkhāranti attho pahānam ca tam vinayo ca ati pahāna vinayo purimena atthena dutiyena
translated: The state of being abandoned is the state of being devoid of what is formed;🔽the meaning is, the state of being unformed. And it is the abandoning and it is the training, thus it is the abandoning-training.

original: pana pahīyatīti pahānaṃ, tassa vinayoti yojetabbo.
analyzed: pana pahīyati iti pahānam tassa vinayaḥ ti yojetabbo
translated: But by the second meaning it can be construed thus: it is abandoned, thus it is abandoning; the training is that of which that is the case, thus it is the abandoning-training.

original: Bhinnasaṃvarattāti naṭṭhasaṃvarattā, saṃvarābhāvatoti attho. Tena asamādinnasaṃvaropi
analyzed: bhinna saṃvara ttā ati naṭṭha saṃvara ttā saṃvara abhāvato ti attho tena asamādinna saṃvaraḥ api
translated: The state of being without restraint is the state of being without restraint because of the loss of restraint; the meaning is, the state of being without the restraint.

original: saṅgahitova hoti. Samādānena hi sampādetabbo saṃvaro, tadabhāve na hotīti. Ariyeti
analyzed: saṅgahitaḥ uva hoti samādānena hi sampādetabbo saṃvaraḥ tad abhāve na hoti iti ariya iti
translated: So one who has not undertaken the restraint is included too. For the restraint is what should be accomplished by undertaking; it is not there if that is not there.🔽The Noble One

original: ariyo. Paccattavacanañhetaṃ. Eseseti eso eso, atthato anaññoti attho. Tajjāteti atthato
analyzed: ariyaḥ paccatta vacanam ha etam esa ise iti esaḥ esaḥ atthataḥ anaññaḥ ti attho tad jātā iti atthataḥ
translated: Noble: this is a term of self-designation. Eso eso: this is this, the meaning is that it is not different.

original: taṃsabhāvo, sappuriso ariyasabhāvo, ariyo ca sappurisabhāvoti attho.🔽So ahanti attanā parikappitaṃ attānaṃ diṭṭhigatiko vadati. “Ahaṃbuddhinibandhano
analyzed: taṃsabhāvaḥ sappurisaḥ ariya sabhāvaḥ ariyaḥ ca sappurisa bhāvaḥ ti attho  so aham ti attanā parikappitam attānam diṭṭhi gatikaḥ vadati aham buddhi nibandhanaḥ
translated: “This one” : this is a word for oneself. “This one” is the same as “this” . The meaning is that it is not different from what is. “Of the same kind” : the meaning is that it is of the same nature as that . The good person is of the nature of the noble one, and the noble one is of the nature of the good person.🔽“He” : the theorist speaks of himself as he has imagined himself to be. For the theorists hold the view that the self is bound up with the notion of “I.”

original: attā”ti hi attavādino laddhi. Advayanti dvayatārahitaṃ. Abhinnaṃ vaṇṇameva “accī”ti🔽gahetvā “accīti vaṇṇo evā”ti tesaṃ ekattaṃ passanto viya yathāparikappitaṃ attānaṃ
analyzed: attā ati hi atta vādinaḥ laddhi advayanti dvaya tā rahitam abhinnam vaṇṇam eva  gahetvā acci iti vaṇṇaḥ evā ti tesam ekattam passantaḥ viya yathā parikappitam attānam
translated: “Non-dual” : devoid of duality. Just as one who sees the color of a flame as one with the flame, thinking “The flame is just the color,”

original: “rūpa”nti, yathādiṭṭhaṃ vā rūpaṃ, “attā”ti gahetvā tesaṃ ekattaṃ passanto daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: rūpam ti yathā diṭṭham vā rūpam attā ati gahetvā tesam ekattam passantaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: so one should see the self as one with the form as imagined, or the form as seen as one with the self, thinking “The self is just form.”

original: Ettha ca “rūpaṃ attā”ti imissā pavattiyā abhāvepi rūpe attaggahaṇaṃ pavattamānaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca rūpam attā ati imissā pavattiyā abhāve pi rūpe atta ggahaṇam pavattamānam
translated: And although there is no such occurrence as “form is the self,” the apprehension of the self as occurring in regard to form

original: acciyaṃ vaṇṇaggahaṇaṃ viya “advayadassana”nti vuttaṃ. Upamāyo ca anaññattādigahaṇanidassanavaseneva
analyzed: acciyam vaṇṇa ggahaṇam viya advaya dassanan ti vuttam upamāyo ca anaññatta ādi gahaṇa nidassana vasena iva
translated: is called “non-dual seeing” just as the apprehension of the color as occurring in regard to the flame. The similes are given in order to show the apprehension of non-difference, etc.

original: vuttā, na vaṇṇādīnaṃ viya attano vijjamānadassanatthaṃ. Na hi attani sāmibhāvena
analyzed: vuttā na vaṇṇa ādīnam viya attanaḥ vijjamāna dassana attham na hi attani sāmi bhāvena
translated: not for the purpose of showing that it exists in itself, as do colour, etc. For he does not see material form as a self that is a master in the sense of being the owner of the self.

original: rūpañca sakiñcanabhāvena samanupassati. Attani vā rūpanti attānaṃ rūpassa sabhāvato
analyzed: rūpam ca sakiñcana bhāvena samanupassati attani vā attānam rūpassa sabhāvato
translated: Or he sees the self in material form, taking the self to be the support of material form in the sense of its true nature.

original: ādhāraṇabhāvena. Rūpasmiṃ vā attānanti rūpassa attano ādhāraṇabhāvena diṭṭhipassanāya🔽passati. Pariyuṭṭhaṭṭhāyīti pariyuṭṭhānappattāhi diṭṭhitaṇhāhi “rūpaṃ attā, rūpavā
analyzed: ādhāraṇa bhāvena rūpasmim vā attānanti rūpassa attanaḥ ādhāraṇa bhāvena diṭṭhi passanāya  passati pariyuṭṭha ṭhāyī iti pariyuṭṭhāna ppattāhi diṭṭhi taṇhāhi rūpam attā rūpavā
translated: Or he sees material form in the self, taking material form to be the support of the self by way of the view that sees the self as the support of material form.

original: attā”tiādinā khandhapañcakaṃ micchā gahetvā tiṭṭhanato. Tenāha “pariyuṭṭhānākārenā”tiādi.
analyzed: attā atiādinā khandha pañcakam micchā gahetvā tiṭṭhanataḥ tena āha pariyuṭṭhāna ākārena atiādi
translated: He stands with the stand of obsession: he stands by misapprehending the five aggregates as self by way of the wrong view that “Material form is the self, the self possesses material form,” etc., through the obsessions of views and craving that have reached obsessional status. Hence it is said: “by way of the stand of obsession” and so on.

original: Eseva nayoti yo “idhekacco rūpaṃ attato samanupassatī”tiādinā rūpakkhandhe vutto
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ti yaḥ idha ekaccaḥ rūpam attataḥ samanupassati itiādinā rūpa kkhandhe vuttaḥ
translated: This is the method: the method stated in the passage beginning, “One regards material form as self” ,

original: saṃvaṇṇanānayo, vedanākkhandhādīsupi eso eva nayo veditabbo.🔽Suddharūpamevāti arūpena amissitaṃ kevalaṃ rūpameva. Arūpanti suddhaarūpaṃ rūpassa
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā nayaḥ vedanā khandha ādīsu pi esaḥ eva nayaḥ veditabbo 🔽suddha rūpam eva ati arūpena a missitam kevalam rūpam eva arūpam ti suddha arūpam rūpassa
translated: should be understood in the case of the aggregate of feeling, etc., as well.

original: aggahitattā. Catūsu khandhesu tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ vasenāti catūsu khandhesu tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: catūsu khandhesu tiṇṇam tiṇṇam vasena ati catūsu khandhesu tiṇṇam tiṇṇam
translated: Because they are not apprehended. In the four aggregates, by the three, by the three,🔽

original: gahaṇavasena rūpārūpamissako attā kathito tasmiṃ tasmiṃ gahaṇe vedanādivinimuttaarūpadhamme
analyzed: gahaṇa vasena rūpa arūpa missakaḥ attā kathitaḥ tasmin tasmin gahaṇe vedanā ādi vinimutta arūpa dhamme
translated: because they are not apprehended. In the four groups of three: in the four groups of three, that is to say, in the four groups of three kinds of apprehension, the self is said to be mixed with materiality and immateriality. In each apprehension, material dhammas that are not associated with feeling, etc.,

original: kasiṇarūpena saddhiṃ sabbarūpadhamme ca ekajjhaṃ gahaṇasiddhito. Pañcasu ṭhānesu
analyzed: kasiṇa rūpena saddhim sabba rūpa dhamme ca ekajjham gahaṇa siddhitaḥ pañcasu ṭhānesu
translated: are established as being apprehended together with the kasiṇa materiality. In the five instances

original: ucchedadiṭṭhi kathitā, te te eva dhamme “attā”ti gahaṇato tesañca ucchedabhāvato.🔽Avasesesu pana pannarasasu ṭhānesu rūpaṃ “attā”ti gahetvāpi diṭṭhigatiko tattha niccasaññaṃ
analyzed: uccheda diṭṭhi kathitā te te eva dhamme attā ati gahaṇato tesaṃ ca uccheda bhāvato  avasesesu pana pannarasasu ṭhānesu rūpam attā ati gahetvā api diṭṭhigatikaḥ tattha nicca saññam
translated: the annihilationist view is stated because of the apprehension of those and those dhammas as self and because of their annihilation.🔽But in the remaining fifteen instances, although the theorist apprehends materiality as self, he does not give up the perception of permanence there,

original: na vissajjeti kasiṇarūpena taṃ missetvā tassa ca uppādādīnaṃ adassanato, tasmāssa
analyzed: na vissajjeti kasiṇa rūpena tam missetvā tassa ca uppāda ādīnam adassanato
translated: because he establishes the materiality as self by mixing it with the kasiṇa materiality and because he does not see the arising, etc., of the latter. Therefore,

original: tatthapi hotiyeva sassatadiṭṭhi ekaccasassatagāhavasenapi. Maggāvaraṇā viparītadassanato.
analyzed: tattha api hotiyā iva sassata diṭṭhi ekacca sassata gāha vasena api magga āvaraṇā viparīta dassanato
translated: in these instances too he has the eternalist view by way of the grasping of partial eternity. But it is not a hindrance to the path, because it is the wrong view of seeing.

original: Na saggāvaraṇā akammapathappattatāya. Akiriyāhetukanatthikadiṭṭhiyo eva hi kammapathadiṭṭhiyo.
analyzed: na sagga āvaraṇāḥ a kammapatha ppatta tāya a kiriyā a hetuka natthika diṭṭhiyaḥ eva hi kammapatha diṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: It is not a hindrance to heaven, because it does not come under the course of action. Only the wrong views of inaction, causelessness, and nihilism come under the course of action.

original: Kāyoti rūpakāyo. So āturoyeva asavasabhāvato. Rāgadosamohānugatanti appahīnarāgadosamohasantāne
analyzed: rūpa kāyo so asava sabhāvataḥ rāga dosa moha anugatanti appahīna rāga dosa moha santāne
translated: “Sick” : the material body. It is sick by nature as a result of the cankers. “With lust, hate, and delusion” : occurring in a continuity that has not abandoned lust, hate, and delusion.

original: pavattaṃ. Idhāti imasmiṃ sutte. Dassitaṃ āturabhāvena. Nikkilesatāyāti sayaṃ pahīnakilesasantānagatatāya.
analyzed: pavattam idha āti imasmin sutte dassitam ātura bhāvena nikkilesa tāya ati sayam pahīna kilesa santāna gata tāya
translated: “Here” : in this sutta. “The sick state” : the state of being sick. “To be free from cankers” : to be in a continuity that has abandoned cankers.

original: Sekhā neva āturacittā pahīnakilese upādāya, appahīne pana upādāya āturacittā. Anāturacittataṃyeva🔽bhajanti vaṭṭānusārimahājanassa viya tesaṃ cittassa kilesavasena āturattābhāvato.🔽Nakulapitusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽2. Devadahasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sekhā na iva ātura cittā pahīna kilese upādāya appahīne pana upādāya ātura cittā  bhajanti vaṭṭa anusāri mahā janassa viya tesam cittassa kilesa vasena ātura ttā abhāvato  nakula pitu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The trainees are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have been abandoned, but they are sick because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have been abandoned.

original: 2. Devā vuccanti rājāno “dibbanti kāmaguṇehi kīḷanti laḷanti, attano vā puññānubhāvena🔽jotantī”ti katvā. Tesaṃ dahoti devadaho. Sayaṃjāto vā so hoti, tasmāpi “devadaho”ti
analyzed: devāḥ vuccanti rājānaḥ dibbanti kāma guṇehi kīḷanti laḷanti attanaḥ vā puñña anubhāvena 🔽jotanti iti katvā tesam dahoti deva daho sayaṃjātaḥ vā saḥ hoti tasmā api deva dahoti
translated: They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned. They are not sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned, but they are sick in mind because of the cankers that have not been abandoned.

original: vutto. Tassa avidūre nigamo “devadaha”ntveva saṅkhaṃ gato yathā “varaṇānagaraṃ, godhāgāmo”ti.
analyzed: vuttaḥ tassa avidūre nigamaḥ deva dahan tvā iva saṅkham gataḥ yathā varaṇā nagaram godhāgāmī iti
translated: and the village not far from it became known as Devadaha, just as Vārāṇasī became known as Goḍhārāma.

original: Pacchābhūmiyaṃ aparadisāyaṃ niviṭṭhajanapado pacchābhūmaṃ, taṃ gantukāmā pacchābhūmagamikā.
analyzed: apara disā ayam niviṭṭha janapadaḥ pacchābhūmam tam gantu kāmā pacchābhūma gamikā
translated: The country inhabited in the western region is called the western country. Those who want to go there are called “those who are going to the western country.”

original: Te sabhāreti te bhikkhū therassa vasena sabhāre kātukāmatāya. Yadi thero tesaṃ bhāro,🔽therassapi te bhārā evāti “te sabhāre kātukāmatāyā”ti vuttaṃ. Evañhi thero te ovaditabbe
analyzed: te sabhāre ti te bhikkhū therassa vasena sabhāre kātu kāma tāya yadi thero tesam bhāro  therassa api te bhārāḥ evā ati te sa bhāre kātu kāma tāya ati vuttam evam hi theraḥ te ovaditabbe
translated: “They wanted to make the Elder their companion”: they wanted to make the Elder their companion in the sense of making him carry their load.🔽If the Elder were their load, they would be his load too. Therefore it is said: “they wanted to make the Elder their companion.” For the Elder thought: “I should advise and instruct them.”

original: anusāsitabbe maññatīti. Idāni tamatthaṃ vivaranto “yo hī”tiādimāha. Ayaṃ nibbhāro
analyzed: anusāsitabbe maññati iti idāni tam attham vivarantaḥ yaḥ hi iti ādim āha ayam nibbhāraḥ
translated: Now, in order to explain this matter, he said: “For he who,” etc. This is the explanation.

original: nāma kañci puggalaṃ attano bhāraṃ katvā avattanato.
analyzed: nāma kañci puggalam attanaḥ bhāram katvā avattanataḥ
translated: “He who” is a person who, having made someone else his load, does not carry him.

original: Catubbidhenāti dhātukosallaṃ āyatanakosallaṃ paṭiccasamuppādakosallaṃ ṭhānāṭṭhānakosallanti evaṃ catubbidhena.
analyzed: catubbidhena ati dhātu kosallam āyatana kosallam paṭiccasamuppāda kosallam ṭhānāṭṭhāna kosallam ti evam catubbidhena
translated: “In four ways”: in the four ways of skill in the elements, skill in the sense bases, skill in dependent origination, and skill in what is possible and impossible.

original: Te mahallakābādhikātidaharapuggale gaṇhitvāva gacchati. Te hi divasadvayena vūpasantaparissamā
analyzed: te mahallaka ābādhika ati dahara puggale gaṇhitvā ava gacchati te hi divasa dvayena vūpasanta parissamā
translated: He takes only those who are neither too old nor too young, for they are free from affliction after two days.

original: eva. Hatthivānaratittirapaṭibaddhaṃ vatthuṃ kathetvā. “Eḷakāḷagumbeti kāḷatiṇagacchamaṇḍape”tipi vadanti.
analyzed: eva hatthi vānara tittira paṭibaddham vatthum kathetvā eḷa kāḷa gumba iti kāḷa tiṇa gacchamaṇḍapa iti pi vadanti
translated: They say that the story is connected with an elephant, a monkey, and a bird, and that the place is the “black-antelope thicket” or the “black-grass thicket.”

original: Vividhaṃ nānābhūtaṃ rajjaṃ virajjaṃ, virajjameva verajjaṃ, tattha gataṃ, paradesagatanti
analyzed: vividham nānā bhūtam rajjam virajjam virajjam eva verajjam tattha gatam para desa gatanti
translated: “Various” means of different kinds. “Royal enmity” is enmity between kings. “Gone to” means gone to another country.

original: attho. Tenāha “ekassā”tiādi. Cittasudattādayoti cittagahapatianāthapiṇḍikādayo. Vīmaṃsakāti
analyzed: atthaḥ tena āha ekassa atiādi cittasudatta ādayaḥ iti citta gahapati anāthapiṇḍika ādayaḥ vīmaṃsakāḥ iti
translated: Therefore he says “of one king” and so on. “Citta Sudatta and others” are Citta the householder, and Nāta and others. “Inquirers”

original: dhammavicārakā. Kinti kīdisaṃ. Dassananti siddhantaṃ. Ācikkhati kīdisanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: dhamma vicārakā kinti kīdisam dassananti siddhantam ācikkhati kīdisam ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: are those who investigate the Dhamma. “What kind of” means what sort. “View” means doctrine. He explains: “What kind of” is the intention.

original: Dhammassāti bhagavatā vuttadhammassa. Anudhammanti anukūlaṃ avirujjhanadhammaṃ. So
analyzed: dhammassa ati bhagavatā vutta dhammassa anudhammam ti anukūlam a virujjhana dhammam so
translated: “Of the Dhamma” means of the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One. “In accordance with the Dhamma” means in accordance with the nature of things, without contradiction.

original: pana veneyyajjhāsayānurūpadesanāvitthāroti āha – “vuttabyākaraṇassa anubyākaraṇa”nti.
analyzed: pana veneyya ajjhāsayā anurūpa desanā vitthāraḥ ti āha vutta byākaraṇassa anubyākaraṇam ti
translated: But that is the elaboration of the teaching in accordance with the inclinations of the disciples. Therefore he says: “The further explanation of the explanation given.”

original: Dhāreti attano phalanti dhammo, kāraṇanti āha – “sahadhammikoti sakāraṇo”ti. Imināpi
analyzed: dhāreti attanaḥ phalanti dhammo kāraṇanti āha sahadhammiko ti sa kāraṇaḥ ti iminā api
translated: “The Dhamma bears its own fruit” : the Dhamma is the cause, says the teacher, “Sahadhammiko” means “having a cause.”

original: pāṭhantarena vādo eva dīpito, na tena pakāsitā kiriyā.
analyzed: pāṭha antarena vādaḥ eva dīpitaḥ na tena pakāsitā kiriyā
translated: By this alternative reading, too, only the dispute is indicated, not the action.

original: Taṇhāvaseneva channampi padānaṃ attho veditabbo. Yasmā rāgādayo taṇhāya eva avatthāvisesāti.🔽Tenāha “taṇhā hī”tiādi. Vihananti kāyaṃ cittañcāti vighāto, dukkhanti āha – “avighātoti
analyzed: taṇhā vasena iva channam pi padānam atthaḥ veditabbaḥ yasmā rāga ādayaḥ taṇhāya eva avatthā avisesā ti  tena āha taṇhā hi itiādi vihananti kāyam cittam ca ati vighātaḥ dukkhanti āha avighāta iti
translated: The meaning of the four terms should be understood in terms of craving. For greed, etc., are simply different states of craving.🔽Hence he says, “For craving is … ”🔽“Affliction” is the affliction of body and mind. “Suffering” is what is painful, says the teacher, “Anupāyāso” means “without affliction,” “without suffering.”

original: nidukkho”ti. Upāyāseti upatāpetīti upāyāso, upatāpo. Tappaṭipakkho pana anupāyāso
analyzed: nidukkhaḥ ti upāyāseti upatāpeti iti upāyāsaḥ upatāpaḥ tad paṭipakkhaḥ pana anupāyāsaḥ
translated: “Affliction” is what afflicts, what torments. “Non-affliction” should be seen as the opposite of affliction, as non-torment.

original: nirūpatāpo daṭṭhabbo. Sabbatthāti sabbavāresu.
analyzed: nirūpa tāpaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ sabbattha ati sabba vāresu
translated: “Everywhere” means in all the passages.

original: Devadahasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: devadaha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Devadahasutta is finished.

original: 3. Hāliddikānisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: hāliddikāni sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Haliddakaniyasutta

original: 3. “Avantidakkhiṇāpathe”ti aññesu suttapadesu āgatattā āha “avantidakkhiṇāpathasaṅkhāte”ti.
analyzed: avanti dakkhiṇāpatha iti aññesu sutta padesu āgata ttā āha avanti dakkhiṇāpatha saṅkhātā iti
translated: “In the southern region of Avantī” : since it is mentioned in other sutta passages, he says “in the region called the southern region of Avantī.”

original: Majjhimadesato hi dakkhiṇadisāya avantiraṭṭhaṃ. Pavattayittha ettha laddhīti pavattaṃ,
analyzed: majjhima desataḥ hi dakkhiṇa disāya avantiraṭṭham pavattayittha ettha laddhi iti pavattam
translated: For to the south of the Middle Country is the kingdom of Avantī. “It arose” : it was obtained here.

original: pavattitabbaṭṭhānanti āha “laddhipavattaṭṭhāne”ti. Ruppanasabhāvo dhammoti katvā🔽rūpadhātūti rūpakkhandho vutto. Rūpadhātumhi ārammaṇapaccayabhūtena rāgena sahajātenapi
analyzed: pavattitabba ṭṭhānanti āha laddhi pavatta ṭṭhāne ti ruppana sabhāvaḥ dhammaḥ ti katvā  rūpa dhātu uti rūpa kkhandho vuttaḥ rūpa dhātumhi ārammaṇa paccaya bhūtena rāgena sahajātena api
translated: The “form element” is the materiality aggregate.

original: asahajātenapi upanissayabhūtena appahīnabhāveneva vinibaddhaṃ paṭibaddhaṃ kammaviññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: asahajātena api upanissaya bhūtena appahīna bhāvena iva vinibaddham paṭibaddham kamma viññāṇam
translated: The “consciousness bound up with the form element” is the kamma-resultant consciousness bound up with the form element by the lust for the object in the form element, whether it arises together with the lust or not, and by the lust that is its root cause, which lust has not been abandoned.

original: Okasārīti vuccati – “tasmiṃ rūpadhātusaññite oke sarati pavattatī”ti katvā. Avati
analyzed: okasārī iti vuccati tasmin rūpa dhātu saññite oke sarati pavattati iti katvā avati
translated: It is called “wandering in the wood” because it wanders, occurs, in the wood called the form element.

original: ettha gacchati pavattatīti okaṃ, pavattiṭṭhānaṃ. Tenāha – “gehasārī ālayasārī”ti.
analyzed: ettha gacchati pavattati iti okam pavatti ṭṭhānam tena āha geha sārī ālaya sārī iti
translated: The “wood” is the place where it occurs, where it goes and occurs. Hence it is said, “Wandering in the house, wandering in the abode.”

original: Ugacchati vā ettha vedanādīhi saddhiṃ samavetīti oko, cakkhurūpādi. Paccayoti ārammaṇādivasena
analyzed: ugacchati vā ettha vedanā ādīhi saddhim samaveti iti oko cakkhu rūpa ādi paccayo ti ārammaṇa ādi vasena
translated: Or alternatively, the wood is the eye, etc., because it goes there, occurs there, together with feeling, etc.🔽The “condition” is a condition by way of object, etc.,

original: paccayo. Paccayo hotīti anantarasamanantarādinā ceva kammūpanissayaārammaṇādinā ca.
analyzed: paccayo paccayaḥ hoti iti anantara samanantara ādinā ca iva kamma upanissaya ārammaṇa ādinā ca
translated: as object condition, prenascence condition, etc., and as root-cause condition, decisive-support condition, object condition, etc.

original: “Viññāṇadhātu kho, gahapatī”ti evaṃ vutte “kammaviññāṇavipākaviññāṇesu kataraṃ nu
analyzed: viññāṇa dhātu kho gahapati iti evam vutte kamma viññāṇa vipāka viññāṇesu kataram nu
translated: When it is said, “The consciousness element, householder,” it is asked, “Which consciousness element?

original: kho”ti sammoho bhaveyya. Tassa sammohassa vighātatthaṃ apagamanatthaṃ. Asambhinnāvāti
analyzed: kho ti sammohaḥ bhaveyya tassa sammohassa vighāta attham apagamana ttham
translated: and there would be confusion. In order to remove that confusion, in order to make it go away,🔽the teaching was given without mixing them up.

original: asaṃkiṇṇāva desanā katā. Ārammaṇavasena catasso abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇaṭṭhitiyo vuttā
analyzed: asaṃkiṇṇā ava desanā katā ārammaṇa vasena catasso abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ vuttā
translated: The four stations for consciousness accompanied by resolve are stated by way of object,

original: – “rūpupayaṃ vā, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhamānaṃ tiṭṭheyya, rūpārammaṇa”ntiādinā.
analyzed: rūpa upayam vā bhikkhave viññāṇam tiṭṭhamānam tiṭṭheyya rūpa ārammaṇa nti ādinā
translated: “Bhikkhus, consciousness becomes established when it is resolved on form, with form as its object” ,🔽and so on.

original: Tā viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo dassetumpi.
analyzed: tāḥ viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ dassetum pi
translated: And in order to show those stations for consciousness,

original: Daḷhaṃ abhinivesavasena ārammaṇaṃ upentīti upayā, taṇhādiṭṭhiyo. Adhiṭṭhānabhūtāti
analyzed: daḷham abhinivesa vasena ārammaṇam upenti iti taṇhā diṭṭhiyaḥ adhiṭṭhāna bhūtā ati
translated: The resolves are craving and views. They are called “resolves” because they enter into the object by way of strong adherence. They are called “stations” because they are the bases for the object.

original: patiṭṭhānabhūtā. Abhinivesabhūtāti taṃ taṃ ārammaṇaṃ abhinivissa ajjhosāya pavattiyā
analyzed: patiṭṭhāna bhūtā abhinivesa bhūtā ati tam tam ārammaṇam abhinivissa ajjhosāya pavattiyā
translated: They are called “adherence” because they are the cause for the occurrence of consciousness by adhering to and cleaving to this or that object.

original: kāraṇabhūtā. Anusayabhūtāti rāgānusayadiṭṭhānusayabhūtā. Uparimakoṭiyāti pahānassa
analyzed: kāraṇa bhūtā anusaya bhūtā ati rāga anusaya diṭṭha anusaya bhūtā uparima koṭiyā ati pahānassa
translated: They are called “latent tendencies” because they are the latent tendencies to lust and the latent tendencies to views.🔽The highest point is the highest point of abandoning.🔽For the Buddhas have abandoned them together with their latent tendencies.

original: uparimakoṭiyā. Buddhānaññeva hi te savāsanā pahīnā. Pubbe aggahitaṃ viññāṇaṃ aggahitamevāti
analyzed: uparima koṭiyā buddhānam aññā iva hi te sa vāsanā pahīnā pubbe aggahitam viññāṇam aggahitam eva ati
translated: Consciousness that has not been taken up is not taken up.

original: katvā kasmā idha desanā katāti codeti – “idha viññāṇaṃ kasmā gahita”nti. Pubbe “viññāṇadhāturāgavinibandhañca
analyzed: katvā kasmai idha desanā katā ati codeti idha viññāṇam kasmai gahitanti pubbe viññāṇa dhātu rāga vinibandhañca
translated: In the previous section, when it was said, “The consciousness element is the attachment to passion,”

original: viññāṇa”nti vuccamāne yathā yathā sammoho siyā paccayapaccayuppannavibhāgassa dukkarattā,
analyzed: viññāṇan ti vuccamāne yathā yathā sammohaḥ siyā paccaya paccaya uppanna vibhāgassa dukkara ttā
translated: there might have been confusion as to the difficulty of distinguishing between the condition and the conditionally arisen,

original: idha pana sammohassa okāsova natthi avisesena pañcasu khandhesu kilesappahānavasenāti.
analyzed: idha pana sammohassa okāsaḥ uva natthi avisesena pañcasu khandhesu kilesa ppahāna vasena ati
translated: but here there is no opportunity for confusion, because the defilements are abandoned in the five aggregates without distinction.🔽Therefore he says, “For the purpose of showing the abandoning of defilements,” and so on.

original: Tenāha “kilesappahānadassanattha”ntiādi. Kammaviññāṇena okaṃ asarantenā”ti itthambhūtalakkhaṇe
analyzed: tena āha kilesa ppahāna dassana ttha ntiādi kamma viññāṇena okam a sarantena ati ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe
translated: The phrase “not taking the opportunity offered by consciousness as action” is a verbal expression in the form of a locative absolute.

original: karaṇavacanaṃ. Asarantenāti anupagacchantena.
analyzed: karaṇa vacanam a sarantena ati an upagacchantena
translated: “Not taking the opportunity” means not grasping.

original: Paccayaṭṭhenāti ārammaṇādipaccayabhāvena. Nimittaṃ uppattikaṃ. Ārammaṇa…pe… niketanti ārammaṇakaraṇasaṅkhātena nivāsaṭṭhānabhūtena rūpameva niketanti rūpanimittaniketaṃ.
analyzed: paccaya ṭṭhena ati ārammaṇa ādi paccaya bhāvena nimittam uppattikam ārammaṇa pe niketanti ārammaṇa karaṇa saṅkhātena nivāsa ṭṭhāna bhūtena rūpam eva niketanti rūpa nimitta niketam
translated: “As a condition” means as the object condition, etc. The sign is the arising. The object is the object condition, etc. The abode is the form that is the place of dwelling by way of making it an object. Thus the sign of form is the abode of form.

original: Chandarāgassa balavadubbalatāyāti ajjhattakhandhapañcake chandarāgassa balavabhāvena
analyzed: chanda rāgassa balavat ubbala tāya ati ajjhatta khandha pañcake chanda rāgassa balava bhāvena
translated: “The strength or weakness of desire and lust”: because of the strength of desire and lust for the five internal aggregates,

original: taṃ “oko”ti, bahiddhā chasu ārammaṇesu tassa dubbalatāya tāni “niketa”nti vuttāni.🔽Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ pākaṭaṃ katvā dassetuṃ “samānepi hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Okoti vuccati
analyzed: tam okaḥ ti bahiddhā chasu ārammaṇesu tassa dubbala tāya tāni vuttāni  idāni yathāvuttam attham pākaṭam katvā dassetum samāne pi hi itiādi vuttam okaḥ ti vuccati
translated: and that is called “home” . Because of its weakness in regard to the six external objects, they are called “abode” .🔽Now, in order to show the meaning stated above by making it clear, the following is said: “Although they are the same, etc.” “Home” is said.

original: gehameva rattiṭṭhānabhāvato. Niketanti vuccati uyyānādi divāṭṭhānabhāvato. Tato dubbalataro hoti chandarāgo.
analyzed: geham eva ratti ṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ niketanti vuccati uyyāna ādi divāṭṭhāna bhāvato tatas dubbalataraḥ hoti chanda rāgaḥ
translated: It is called “home” because it is the place where one stays at night. It is called “abode” because it is the place where one stays by day, such as a park, etc. The desire and lust for these are weaker.

original: Gehassitasukhenāti gehanissitena cittassa sukhena sukhito sukhappatto hoti. Kiccakaraṇīyesūti khuddakesu ceva mahantesu ca kattabbatthesu. Sayanti attanā. Antoti cittajjhāsaye.
analyzed: geha ssita sukhena ati geha nissitena cittassa sukhena sukhitaḥ sukha ppatto hoti kicca karaṇīyesu iti khuddakesu ca iva mahantesu ca kattabbatthesu sayanti attanā antar ti
translated: “He is happy with the happiness dependent on the home”: he is happy, he has attained happiness, through the happiness dependent on the home, i.e., through the happiness of the mind dependent on the home. “In the performance of duties”: in the performance of the small and great duties. “They lie down in themselves”: they lie down in the mind’s own abode.

original: Evaṃrūpoti īdisarūpo. Vaṇṇasaddo viya rūpasaddo rūpāyatanassa viya saṇṭhānassapi
analyzed: evaṃrūpaḥ ti īdisa rūpaḥ vaṇṇa saddaḥ viya rūpa saddaḥ rūpa āyatanassa viya saṇṭhānassa api
translated: “Such as these”: such as these. The word “form” is intended to denote not only the visible-form base but also the configuration of the visible form, like the word “color.”

original: vācakoti adhippāyena “dīgharassa kāḷodātādīsu rūpesū”ti vuttaṃ. Sukhādīsūti somanassādīsu.
analyzed: vācako ti adhippāyena dīgha rassa kāḷodāta ādīsu rūpesu iti vuttam sukha ādīsu iti somanassa ādīsu
translated: “In long, short, etc., forms”: in long, short, black, white, etc., forms. “In happiness, etc.”: in joy, etc.

original: Tattha hi “abhiṇhaṃ somanassito bhaveyya”nti patthanā siyā. Evaṃsañño nāmāti visayavasena
analyzed: tattha hi abhiṇham somanassitaḥ bhaveyyanti patthanā siyā evaṃsaññaḥ nāma ati visaya vasena
translated: Herein, the aspiration is this: “I might be one who is often joyful.”🔽“One who has such a perception”: he states the aspiration for a particular perception by way of the object.

original: saññāvisesapatthanamāha. Evaṃviññāṇoti pana idha visayamukhena viññāṇavisesapatthanaṃ🔽vadati – “evaṃnipuṇarūpadassanasamatthaṃ, evaṃpañcapasādapaṭimaṇḍitanissayañca me
analyzed: saññā visesa patthanam āha evaṃviññāṇaḥ ti pana idha visaya mukhena viññāṇa visesa patthanam  vadati evam nipuṇa rūpa dassana samattham evam pañca pasāda paṭimaṇḍita nissayam ca me
translated: But here in the phrase “one who has such consciousness” he states the aspiration for a particular consciousness by way of the object,

original: viññāṇaṃ bhaveyyā”ti.
analyzed: viññāṇam bhaveyya ati
translated: saying: “May my consciousness be capable of seeing forms thus subtly, and may its support be endowed with the five benefits thus.”🔽“We have not made the round of the world in front”: he does not aspire to the world.

original: Vaṭṭaṃ purato akurūmānoti loke cittaṃ apatthento. Asiliṭṭhaṃ pubbenāparaṃ asambaddhaṃ.
analyzed: vaṭṭam puratas akurūmāno ti loke cittam a patthentaḥ a siliṭṭham pubbena aparam a sambaddham
translated: “A tangled skein”: the past is not connected with the future.

original: Vadanti etenāti vādo, dosoti āha – “tuyhaṃ doso”tiādi. Idheva imasmiṃyeva samāgame.
analyzed: vadanti etena ati vādaḥ doso ti āha idhā iva imasmin yā iva samāgame
translated: “Argument”: they say by this, thus it is argument. “Fault”: he says, “Your fault,” etc. “Right here”: in this very assembly.

original: Nibbeṭhehi dosato attānaṃ mocehi.🔽Hāliddikānisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Dutiyahāliddikānisuttavaṇṇanā🔽4. Cūḷachakkapañheti mūlapaṇṇāse cūḷataṇhāsaṅkhayasutte. Mahāsakkapañhepīti mahātaṇhāsaṅkhayasuttepi.
analyzed: nibbeṭhehi dosataḥ attānam mocehi 🔽hāliddikāni sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽dutiya hāliddikāni sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽cūḷa chakka pañhā iti mūla paṇṇāse cūḷa taṇhā saṅkhaya sutte mahā sakka pañhe api iti mahā taṇhā saṅkhaya sutte pi
translated: “Free yourself from fault”: free yourself from fault, be released.

original: Etanti “ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā”tiādisuttapadaṃ. Taṇhā sammadeva khīyati etthāti taṇhāsaṅkhayo,
analyzed: etat ti ye te samaṇa brāhmaṇa ati ādi sutta padam taṇhā sammat eva khīyati ettha ati taṇhā saṅkhayaḥ
translated: ‘Ettha’: in the passage of the sutta beginning, ‘Those ascetics and brahmins who …’ . ‘The destruction of craving’: because craving is completely destroyed here.

original: asaṅkhatā dhātūti āha “taṇhāsaṅkhaye nibbāne”ti. Antaṃ atikkantaniṭṭhāti antarahitaniṭṭhā.
analyzed: asaṅkhatā dhātū ti āha taṇhā saṅkhaye nibbāna iti antam atikkanta niṭṭhā ati anta rahita niṭṭhā
translated: ‘The unformed element’: the unformed element of Nibbāna, he says. ‘The end of the round of rebirths’: the end that is beyond the round of rebirths.

original: Tenāha “satataniṭṭhā”ti. Sesapadesūti “accantayogakkhemino”tiādīsu.
analyzed: tena āha satata niṭṭhā iti sesa padesu iti accanta yogakkhemino tiādīsu
translated: Hence he says, ‘the eternal end.’ ‘The rest of the passage’: in the passage beginning, ‘The refuge and shelter …’ .

original: Dutiyahāliddikānisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya hāliddikāni sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second section for recitation is finished.

original: 5. Samādhisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: samādhi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Concentration Discourse

original: 5. Samādhīti appanāsamādhi, upacārasamādhi vā. Kammaṭṭhānanti samādhipādakaṃ vipassanākammaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: samādhi iti appanā samādhi upacāra samādhi vā kammaṭṭhānam ti samādhi pādakam vipassanā kammaṭṭhānam
translated: ‘Concentration’: absorption concentration or access concentration. ‘Meditation subject’: the meditation subject that is the basis for concentration.

original: “Phātiṃ gamissatī”ti pāṭho. Patthetīti “aho vata me īdisaṃ rūpaṃ bhaveyyā”ti. Abhivadatīti
analyzed: phātim gamissati iti pāṭhaḥ pattheti iti aho vata me īdisam rūpam bhaveyya iti abhivadati iti
translated: The reading is ‘phātiṃ gamissatī’ . ‘Grasps’: ‘Oh, may I have such and such a form.’ ‘Approves’:

original: taṇhādiṭṭhivasena abhinivesaṃ vadati. Tenāha “tāya abhinandanāyā”tiādi. “Aho piyaṃ
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena abhinivesam vadati tena āha tāya abhinandanāya atiādi aho piyam
translated: he approves by way of craving and views. Hence he says, ‘By delighting in that’ and so on.

original: iṭṭha”nti vacībhede asatipi tathā lobhuppāde sati abhivadatiyeva nāma. Tenāha “vācaṃ
analyzed: vacībhede asati pi tathā lobha uppāde sati nāma tena āha vācam
translated: Even though there is no verbal expression of the kind, ‘Oh, how pleasant and desirable! ‘, still, when greed arises in that way, it is called ‘approving.’ Hence he says, ‘By verbal expression’ and so on.

original: abhindanto”ti. “Mama ida”nti attano pariṇāmetvā anaññagocaraṃ viya katvā gaṇhanto
analyzed: abhindanto ti mama idam ti attanaḥ pariṇāmetvā anañña gocaram viya katvā gaṇhanto
translated: “He does not break it up”: he takes it as his own, as if making it his own private property, not the common property of others.

original: ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati nāmāti dassento āha “gilitvāti pariniṭṭhapetvā gaṇhātī”ti. “Abhinandatī”tiādayo
analyzed: ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati nāma ati dassentaḥ āha gilitvā iti pariniṭṭhapetvā gaṇhāti iti abhinandati iti ādayaḥ
translated: “He sticks to it”: he shows that he sticks to it by saying, “He swallows it and takes it as his own.”

original: pubbabhāgavasena vuttā, “uppajjati nandī”ti dvārappattavasena. Paṭhamehi padehi anusayo,
analyzed: pubba bhāga vasena vuttā uppajjati nandī iti dvāra ppatta vasena paṭhamehi padehi anusayaḥ
translated: “He delights in it” and so on are said with reference to the prior stage, while “rejoicing arises” is said with reference to the stage when it has reached the door of the sense faculties.🔽Some say that the first terms refer to the underlying tendency, the last to the obsession.

original: pacchimena pariyuṭṭhānanti keci “gahaṇaṭṭhena upādāna”nti katvā. Nābhinandati nābhivadatīti
analyzed: pacchimena pariyuṭṭhānanti keci gahaṇa ṭṭhena upādānanti katvā na abhinandati na abhivadati iti
translated: “He does not delight in it” and so on.

original: ettha heṭṭhā vuttavipariyāyena attho veditabbo. Na “iṭṭhaṃ kanta”nti vadatīti “iṭṭha”nti🔽na vadati, “kanta”nti na vadati. Nābhivadatiyeva taṇhāya anupādiyattā.
analyzed: ettha heṭṭhā vutta vipariyāyena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ na iṭṭham kantanti vadati iti iṭṭhanti  na vadati na vadati taṇhāya
translated: Here the meaning should be understood in the opposite sense to that stated above.🔽He does not say, “I like it,”

original: Samādhisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽6. Paṭisallāṇasuttavaṇṇanā🔽6. Ñatvā āhāti “sati kāyaviveke cittaviveko, tasmiṃ sati upadhiviveko ca imesaṃ laddhuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti ñatvā āha.
analyzed: samādhi sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽paṭisallāṇa sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽ñatvā āha ati sati kāya viveke citta viveko tasmin sati upadhi viveko ca imesam laddhum vaṭṭati iti ñatvā āha
translated: he does not say, “I love it.” He does not say anything at all because he does not grasp through craving.

original: Paṭisallāṇasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭisallāṇa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Paṭisallāna Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Upādāparitassanāsuttavaṇṇanā🔽7. Gahaṇena uppannaṃ paritassananti khandhapañcake “ahaṃ mamā”ti gahaṇena uppannaṃ
analyzed: upādā paritassanā sutta vaṇṇanā  gahaṇena uppannam paritassananti khandha pañcake aham mama ati gahaṇena uppannam
translated: The Discussion of the Sutta on Fear Due to Clinging🔽Fear due to clinging: fear due to craving and fear due to views that have arisen through clinging to the five aggregates as “I” and “mine.”

original: taṇhāparitassanaṃ diṭṭhiparitassanañca. Aparitassananti paritassanābhāvaṃ, paritassanapaṭipakkhaṃ
analyzed: taṇhā paritassanam diṭṭhi paritassanam ca a paritassananti paritassana abhāvam paritassana paṭipakkham
translated: Fearlessness: the absence of fear, or the opposite of fear.

original: vā. Ahu vata metaṃ balayobbanādi. Kammaviññāṇanti vipariṇāmārammaṇaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhisahagataṃ
analyzed: vā ahu vata mā etam bala yobbana ādi kamma viññāṇam ti vipariṇāma ārammaṇam taṇhā diṭṭhi sahagatam
translated: It was once my strength, my youth, etc.: consciousness that has craving and views as its associates and that has a changing object.

original: viññāṇaṃ tadanuvatti ca. Anuparivatti nāma taṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavatti. Tenāha “vipariṇāmārammaṇacittato”ti.
analyzed: viññāṇam tad anuvatti ca anuparivatti nāma tam ārammaṇam katvā pavatti tena āha vipariṇāma ārammaṇa cittato ti
translated: The “following along” is the occurrence of consciousness that has that as its object. Hence it is said: “from consciousness that has a changing object.”
