original: Akusaladhammasamuppādāti taṇhāya aññākusaladhammasamuppādā. Pariyādiyitvāti khepetvā,🔽tassa pavattituṃ okāsaṃ adatvā. Sauttāsoti taṇhādiṭṭhivasena sauttāso. Gaṇhitvāti
analyzed: akusala dhamma samuppādā ti taṇhāya aññā akusala dhamma samuppādā pariyādiyitvā ati khepetvā  tassa pavattitum okāsam a datvā sauttāsaḥ ti taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena sauttāsaḥ gaṇhitvā iti
translated: The arising of unwholesome states: the arising of craving and other unwholesome states.🔽Having overcome: having exhausted.🔽Without giving it an opportunity to occur. With fear: with fear due to craving and views.

original: taṇhādiṭṭhiggāhehi gahetvā tesañceva vasena paritassako. Rūpabhedānuparivatti cittaṃ
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi ggāhehi gahetvā tesam ca iva vasena paritassakaḥ rūpa bheda anuparivatti cittam
translated: Having grasped: having grasped it with the grasping of craving and views. He is fearful because of them. The consciousness that follows along with the breakup of form

original: na hoti. Vaṭṭatīti sabbākārena vattuṃ yuttanti attho.🔽Upādāparitassanāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: na hoti vaṭṭati iti sabba ākārena vattum yuttan ti attho  upādā paritassanā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: it is not. It is possible to speak of it in all ways as “becoming.”🔽The explanation of the Upādāparitassanā Sutta is ended.

original: 8. Dutiyaupādāparitassanāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya opādā paritassanā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the second Upādāparitassanā Sutta is ended.

original: 8. Taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena desanā katā “etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā”ti desanāya āgatattā. Catūsu suttesūti pañcamādīsu catūsu suttesu. Catutthe pana vivaṭṭameva kathitaṃ.
analyzed: taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena desanā katā etam mama esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati desanāya āgata ttā catūsu suttesu iti pañcama ādīsu catūsu suttesu catutthe pana vivaṭṭam eva kathitam
translated: The teaching is given in terms of craving, conceit, and views because of the occurrence of the teaching “This is mine, this I am, this is my self.” In the four suttas: in the four suttas beginning with the fifth. But in the fourth the turning back is stated.

original: Dutiyaupādāparitassanāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya opādā paritassanā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the second Upādāparitassanā Sutta is ended.

original: 9. Kālattayaaniccasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāla ttaya anicca sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Kālattayaanicca Sutta is ended.

original: 9. Yadi atītānāgataṃ etarahi natthibhāvato aniccaṃ, paccuppannampi tadā natthīti
analyzed: yadi atīta anāgatam etarahi natthi bhāvataḥ aniccam paccuppannam pi tadā natthi iti
translated: If the past and future are impermanent because of their non-existence in the present, then the present is non-existent too.

original: ko pana vādo tassa aniccatāya, paccuppannamhi kathāva kā udayabbayaparicchinnattā
analyzed: kaḥ pana vādaḥ tassa anicca tāya paccuppannamhi kathā va kā udaya bbaya paricchinna ttā
translated: What need is there to speak of its impermanence? The present is included in arising and falling away.

original: tassa. Vuttañhetaṃ “nibbattā ye ca tiṭṭhanti, āragge sāsapūpamā”ti.
analyzed: tassa vuttam ha etam nibbattāḥ ye ca tiṭṭhanti āragge
translated: For this is said: “Those that are born and those that stand, are like mustard seeds on the point of an awl.”

original: Kālattayaaniccasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kālattaya anicca sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Kālattayaanicca Sutta is ended.

original: 10-11. Kālattayadukkhasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāla ttaya dukkha sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Kālattayadukkha Sutta, etc.

original: 10-11. Tathārūpenevāti yathārūpeneva puggalajjhāsayena navamaṃ suttaṃ kathitaṃ, tathārūpenevāti.
analyzed: tathārūpena iva ati yathārūpena iva puggala jjhāsayena navamam suttam kathitam tathārūpena iva ati
translated: As in the case of the ninth sutta: as in the case of the ninth sutta, which was preached in accordance with the disposition of the person to whom it was preached.

original: Te kira bhikkhū atītānāgataṃ “dukkha”nti sallakkhetvā, tathā “anattā”ti sallakkhetvā
analyzed: te kira bhikkhū atīta anāgatam dukkhanti sallakkhetvā tathā anattā ati sallakkhetvā
translated: It seems that these bhikkhus, having defined the past and future as “pain,” and having defined them as “not self,”

original: paccuppanne kilamiṃsu. “Atha nesa”ntiādi sabbaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayena vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: paccuppanne kilamiṃsu atha nesanti ādi sabbam heṭṭhā vutta nayena vattabbam
translated: were exhausted in regard to the present. “Then the Blessed One” and so on can all be quoted as in the previous case.

original: Kālattayadukkhasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kāla ttaya dukkha sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Sutta on Pain in the Three Times is ended.

original: Nakulapituvaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽2. Aniccavaggo
analyzed: nakula pitu vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  an icca vaggaḥ
translated: The commentary on the Nakulapitaravagga is ended.🔽The Unprofitable Section

original: 1-10. Aniccādisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anicca ādi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Unprofitable Sutta

original: 12-21. Pucchāvasikaṃ ānandattherassa pucchāvasena desitattā.🔽Aniccādisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pucchāvasikam ānanda therassa pucchā vasena desita ttā  anicca ādi sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Unprofitable Sutta is so called because it was preached by the Elder Ananda in answer to a question.🔽The explanation of the Unprofitable Sutta is ended.

original: Aniccavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: anicca vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Unprofitable Section is ended.

original: 3. Bhāravaggo
analyzed: bhāra vaggo
translated: The Burden Section

original: 1. Bhārasuttavaṇṇanā🔽22. Upādānānaṃ ārammaṇabhūtā khandhā upādānakkhandhā. Parihārabhāriyaṭṭhenāti parihārassa
analyzed: bhāra sutta vaṇṇanā  upādānānam ārammaṇa bhūtā khandhāḥ upādāna kkhandhā parihāra bhāriya ṭṭhena ati parihārassa
translated: The Explanation of the Burden Sutta

original: bhāriyabhāvena garutarabhāvena. Vuttameva atthaṃ pākaṭaṃ kātuṃ “etesañhī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: bhāriya bhāvena garutara bhāvena vuttam eva attham pākaṭam kātum etesam hi iti ādim āha
translated: The aggregates that are the objects of clinging are called clinging-aggregates. As to the meaning of “burdensome to be borne”: as to the meaning of “heavy to be borne” and “heavy to be carried.” In order to make the meaning stated clear he said “for these” and so on.

original: Tattha yasmā etāni ṭhānagamanādīni rūpārūpadhammānaṃ paṅgulajaccandhānaṃ viya aññamaññūpassayavasena
analyzed: tattha yasmai etāni ṭhāna gamana ādīni rūpa arūpa dhammānam viya aññamaññu upassaya vasena
translated: Herein, these going and coming, etc., are the means of access to the material and immaterial states, which are like a lame man and a blind man, respectively.

original: ijjhanti, na paccekaṃ, tasmā “etesa”nti avisesavacanaṃ kataṃ. Puggalanti khandhasantānaṃ🔽vadati. Khandhasantāno hi avicchedena pavattamāno yāva parinibbānā khandhabhāraṃ
analyzed: ijjhanti na paccekam tasmai etesanti avisesa vacanam katam khandha santānam  vadati khandha santānaḥ hi avicchedena pavattamānaḥ yāva parinibbānā khandha bhāram
translated: Herein, since these, namely, the going and coming, etc., are dependent on the other states, like the lame and the blind, and not independent, therefore the word “these” is used without distinction. “Person” : he speaks of the continuity of aggregates.

original: vahanto viya loke khāyati tabbinimuttassa sattassa abhāvato. Tenāha “puggalo”tiādi.
analyzed: vahantaḥ viya loke khāyati tad binimuttassa sattassa abhāvato tena āha puggala itiādi
translated: For the continuity of aggregates, which occurs uninterruptedly as long as there is no attainment of Nibbāna, appears in the world as though it were a burden-bearer, because there is no being apart from that. Therefore he said “person,” etc.

original: Bhārahāroti jātoti bhārahāro nāma jāto.
analyzed: bhārahāraḥ iti jātaḥ iti bhārahāraḥ nāma jātaḥ
translated: “The burden-bearer has come to be”: he has come to be as a burden-bearer.

original: Punabbhavakaraṇaṃ punabbhavo, taṃ phalaṃ arahati, tattha niyuttāti vā ponobhavikā.
analyzed: punabbhava karaṇam punabbhavaḥ tam phalam arahati tattha niyuttā ati vā ponobhavikā
translated: The rebirth-producing is rebirth; it is fit for the fruit, or it is bound to that, thus it is rebirth-linking.

original: Tabbhāvasahagataṃ yathā “sanidassanā dhammā”ti, na saṃsaṭṭhasahagataṃ, nāpi ārammaṇasahagataṃ.
analyzed: tad bhāva sahagatam yathā sanidassanāḥ dhammā ti na saṃsaṭṭha sahagatam na api ārammaṇa sahagatam
translated: It is associated with that state, as in the case of “states with form,” not associated by contact, nor associated as object.

original: “Tatra tatrā”ti yaṃ yaṃ uppattiṭṭhānaṃ, rūpādiārammaṇaṃ vā patvā tatratatrābhinandinī.
analyzed: tatra tatra ati yam yam uppatti ṭṭhānam rūpa ādi ārammaṇam vā patvā tatra tatra abhinandinī
translated: “Here and there”: wherever there is a place of rebirth, or whatever object there is, such as form, etc., it delights in that.

original: Tenāha “upapattiṭṭhāne vā”tiādi. Pañcakāmaguṇikoti pañcakāmaguṇārammaṇo. Rūpārūpūpapattibhave🔽rāgo rūpārūpabhavarāgo. Jhānanikanti jhānasaṅkhāte kammabhave rāgo. Sassatādiṭṭhīti
analyzed: tena āha upapatti ṭṭhāne vā ati ādi pañca kāmaguṇikaḥ ti pañca kāmaguṇa ārammaṇaḥ rūpa arūpu upapatti bhave  rāgaḥ rūpa arūpa bhava rāgaḥ jhāna nikanti jhāna saṅkhāte kamma bhave rāgaḥ sassata diṭṭhi iti
translated: The lust for the five strands of sense pleasure is the lust for the five strands of sense pleasure as object. The lust for the rebirth-state in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming is the lust for the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming.🔽The lust for the rebirth-state consisting in the kinds of kamma called jhana is the lust for jhana. The view of eternity, etc., is the view of becoming. The lust associated with that is called the lust for eternity.

original: bhavadiṭṭhi, taṃsahagato rāgo. Ayanti rāgo bhavataṇhā nāma. Ucchedadiṭṭhi vibhavadiṭṭhi🔽nāma, taṃsahagato chandarāgo vibhavataṇhā nāma. Esa puggalo khandhabhāraṃ ādiyati
analyzed: bhava diṭṭhi tad sahagataḥ rāgaḥ ayanti rāgaḥ bhava taṇhā nāma uccheda diṭṭhi vibhava diṭṭhi  nāma tad sahagataḥ chanda rāgaḥ vibhava taṇhā nāma esa puggalo khandha bhāram ādiyati
translated: The view of annihilation is the view of non-becoming. The will and lust for that is called the lust for annihilation.

original: taṇhāvasena paṭisandhiggahaṇato. “Asesamettha taṇhā virajjati palujjati nirujjhati
analyzed: taṇhā vasena paṭisandhi ggahaṇato asesam ettha taṇhā virajjati palujjati nirujjhati
translated: This person takes up the burden of the aggregates because he grasps rebirths by means of craving.

original: pahīyatī”tiādinā sabbapadāni nibbānavaseneva veditabbānīti āha “sabbaṃ nibbānasseva vevacana”nti.
analyzed: pahīyati itiādinā sabba padāni nibbāna vasena iva veditabbāni iti āha sabbam nibbānassa iva vevacanam ti
translated: All the terms should be understood as referring to Nibbāna in the way beginning: “Herein, craving comes to complete ending and cessation without remainder” .

original: Bhārasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bhāra sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Burden Sutta is finished.

original: 2. Pariññasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pariñña sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Full Understanding

original: 23. Parijānitabbeti pahānapariññāya parijānitabbe. Tathā parijānanañca tattha chandarāgappahānaṃ,
analyzed: parijānitabba iti pahāna pariññāya parijānitabbe tathā parijānanam ca tattha chanda rāga ppahānam
translated: What should be fully known by way of abandoning is what should be fully known by means of full understanding as abandoning. And the act of fully knowing that is the abandoning of will and lust for it.

original: tesaṃ atikkamoti āha “samatikkamitabbeti attho”ti. Accantapariññanti nibbānaṃ vadati.
analyzed: tesam atikkamaḥ ti āha samatikkamitabbā iti attho ti accanta pariññanti nibbānam vadati
translated: The meaning of ‘surpassing’ is ‘surpassing of that’.🔽Nibbana is said to be ‘complete understanding’.

original: Tenāha “samatikkamanti attho”ti.
analyzed: tena āha samatikkamanti attho ti
translated: Hence he said ‘the meaning of “surpassing” is “surpassing of that” ’.

original: Pariññasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pariñña sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Exposition of the Pariññāsutta is ended.

original: 3. Abhijānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: abhijāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Abhiññāsutta🔽‘Knowledge’ is said to be ‘full-understanding as knowledge’ in the sense of ‘knowing by means of knowledge that is distinguished ’.🔽‘By the second phrase’ is by the phrase ‘he fully understands’.

original: 24. Ñātapariññā kathitā “abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya jānana”nti katvā. Dutiyapadenāti “parijāna”nti padena. Tatiyacatutthehīti “virājayaṃ pajaha”nti padehi.
analyzed: ñātapariññā kathitā abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya katvā dutiya padena ati parijānanti padena tatiya catutthehi iti virājayam pajahanti padehi
translated: ‘By the third and fourth’ is by the phrases ‘he becomes dispassionate towards it’ and ‘he is released from it’.

original: Abhijānasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: abhijāna sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Exposition of the Abhiññāsutta is ended.

original: 4-9. Chandarāgasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Chandarāgasutta, etc.🔽They should be understood in the way stated in the section on the elements .

original: 25-30. Dhātusaṃyutte vuttanayeneva veditabbāni, kevalañhi ettha khandhavasena desanā🔽āgatā, tattha dhātuvasenāti ayameva viseso. Cattāri saccāni kathitāni assādādīnavanissaraṇavasena
analyzed: dhātusaṃyutte vutta nayena iva veditabbāni kevalam hi ettha khandha vasena desanā  āgatā tattha dhātu vasena ati ayam eva visesaḥ cattāri saccāni kathitāni assāda ādīnava nissaraṇa vasena
translated: Here the teaching is given in terms of the aggregates,🔽and in the section on the elements it is given in terms of the elements. This is the only difference.🔽The four truths are stated in the teaching of the fourfold discernment of form, etc.,

original: desanāya pavattattā.
analyzed: desanāya pavattattā
translated: because the teaching proceeds by way of the fourfold discernment of form, etc., as gratification, danger, escape, and so on.

original: Chandarāgasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: chandarāga sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Exposition of the Chandarāgasutta, etc., is ended.

original: 10. Aghamūlasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: agha mūla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Aghamūlasutta

original: 31. Aghaṃ vuccati pāpaṃ, aghanimittatāya aghaṃ dukkhaṃ. Idañhi dukkhaṃ nāma visesato
analyzed: agham vuccati pāpam agha nimittatāya agham dukkham idam hi dukkham nāma visesataḥ
translated: Evil is called wicked. Suffering is evil because it is a cause of evil. For this suffering, in particular,

original: pāpahetukaṃ kammaphalasaññitaṃ. Tathā vaṭṭadukkhaṃ avijjātaṇhāmūlakattā. Aghassa🔽nimittatāya aghaṃ dukkhaṃ. Vaṭṭānusārī mahājano hi dukkhābhibhūto tassa patikāraṃ
analyzed: pāpa hetukam kamma phala saññitam tathā vaṭṭa dukkham avijjā taṇhā mūlaka ttā aghassa  nimitta tāya agham dukkham vaṭṭa anusārī mahājanaḥ hi dukkha abhibhūtaḥ tassa patikāram
translated: is a cause of evil, being called the fruit of kamma. So too, the suffering of the round of rebirths is evil because it is a cause of evil, since it is rooted in ignorance and craving.

original: maññamāno taṃ taṃ karotīti.🔽Aghamūlasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: maññamānaḥ tam tam karoti iti  agha mūla sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: For the great multitude that follows the round of rebirths, being overwhelmed by suffering, thinks it is a remedy and does this and that.

original: 11. Pabhaṅgusuttavaṇṇanā🔽32. Pabhijjanasabhāvanti khaṇe khaṇe pabhaṅgusabhāvaṃ.🔽Pabhaṅgusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pabhijjana sabhāvanti khaṇe khaṇe pabhaṅgu sabhāvam  pabhaṅgu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Discourse on the Root of Evil is ended.🔽The explanation of the Discourse on the Fragile is ended.

original: Bhāravaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Natumhākaṃvaggo
analyzed: bhāra vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  na tumhākam vaggo
translated: The explanation of the Burden Chapter is ended.

original: 1. Natumhākaṃsuttavaṇṇanā🔽33. Chandarāgappahānenāti tappaṭibaddhassa chandarāgassa pajahanena. Dabbādi pākatikatiṇaṃ
analyzed: na tumhākam sutta vaṇṇanā  chanda rāga pahānena ati tad paṭibaddhassa chanda rāgassa pajahanena dabba ādi
translated: The Chapter on What Is Not Yours

original: pākaṭamevāti apākaṭaṃ dassetuṃ tālanāḷikerādi dassitaṃ, tiṇakaṭṭhānaṃ vā bhedadassanatthaṃ. Piyālo phārusakaṃ.
analyzed: pākaṭam eva ati apākaṭam dassetum tāla nāḷikera ādi dassitam tiṇaka ṭṭhānam vā bheda dassana attham piyālo phārusakam
translated: The explanation of the Discourse on What Is Not Yours is ended.

original: Natumhākaṃsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: na tumhākam sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Commentary on the “Not Ours” Thread is finished.

original: 3. Aññatarabhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aññatara bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the “A Certain Monk” Thread

original: 35. Yadi rūpaṃ anusetīti rūpadhamme ārabbha yadi rāgādayo anusayanavasena pavattanti.🔽Tena saṅkhaṃ gacchatīti tena rāgādinā taṃsamaṅgīpuggalo saṅkhātabbataṃ “ratto duṭṭho”tiādinā
analyzed: yadi rūpam anuseti iti rūpa dhamme ārabbha yadi rāga ādayaḥ anusayana vasena pavattanti  tena saṅkham gacchati iti tena rāga ādinā tad samaṅgī puggalaḥ rattaḥ duṭṭhaḥ iti ādinā
translated: If it is form that is the underlying tendency, if greed, etc., occur by way of underlying tendency in regard to form-things.🔽It comes to be reckoned as that: the person who has that greed, etc., comes to be reckoned as “greedy, hating, deluded,” and so on,

original: voharitabbataṃ upagacchatīti. Tenāha “kāmarāgādīsū”tiādi. Abhūtenāti ajātena anusayavasena🔽appavattena. Anusayasīsena hettha abhibhavaṃ vadati. Yato “ratto duṭṭho mūḷhoti saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: voharitabbatam upagacchati iti tena āha kāma rāga ādīsu itiādi abhūtena ati ajātena anusaya vasena  a pavattena anusaya sīsena ha ittha abhibhavam vadati yatas rattaḥ duṭṭhaḥ mūḷhaḥ iti saṅkham
translated: by that greed, etc., as the reason. Hence he said “by greed, etc., as the reason” . By what is not: by what is not born, by what is not yet arisen, by what is not yet come into focus.🔽He speaks of the conquest here by way of the underlying tendency. Since it is said, “he is not reckoned as ‘greedy, hating, deluded,’ ”

original: na gacchatī”ti vuttaṃ. Nippariyāyato hi maggavajjhakilesā anusayo.🔽Aññatarabhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: na gacchati iti vuttam nippariyāyataḥ hi magga vajjha kilesāḥ anusayaḥ  aññatara bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: for the defilements that are the path’s opposite are the underlying tendency in the ultimate sense.🔽Commentary on the “A Certain Monk” Thread is finished.

original: 4. Dutiyaaññatarabhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya aññatara bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the “Another Monk” Thread

original: 36. Taṃ anusayitaṃ rūpanti taṃ rāgādinā anusayitaṃ rūpaṃ marantena anusayena anumarati.
analyzed: tam anusayitam tam rāga ādinā anusayitam rūpam marantena anusayena anumarati
translated: That underlying tendency in form: that underlying tendency in form by greed, etc., is followed by the underlying tendency of one who is dying.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “na hī”tiādi. Yena anusayena marantena taṃ anumarati. Tena saṅkhaṃ gacchatīti🔽tathābhūtato tena “ratto”tiādivohāraṃ labhati. Yena anusayena kāraṇabhūtena anumīyati, tena.
analyzed: tena vuttam na hi itiādi yena anusayena marantena tam anumarati tena saṅkham gacchati iti  tena ratta uti ādi vohāram labhati yena anusayena kāraṇa bhūtena anumīyati tena
translated: By means of the underlying tendency by which one who is dying dies, it is reckoned.

original: Dutiyaaññatarabhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya aññatara bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second sutta of the Group of Discourses with Different Threads is finished.

original: 5-6. Ānandasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Ānanda Sutta, etc.

original: 37-38. Ṭhitiyā ṭhitikkhaṇena sahitaṃ ṭhitaṃ. Ṭhitassa aññathattanti uppādakkhaṇato🔽aññathābhāvo. Paññāyatīti upalabbhati. Paccayavasena dharamānattā eva jīvamānassa🔽jīvitindriyavasena jarā paññāyati uppādakkhaṇato aññathattappattiyā. Vuttameva atthaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitiyāḥ ṭhiti kkhaṇena sahitam ṭhitam ṭhitassa aññathattam ti uppāda kkhaṇato  aññathābhāvaḥ paññāyati iti upalabbhati paccaya vasena dharamāna ttā eva jīvamānassa  jīvitindriya vasena jarā paññāyati uppāda kkhaṇataḥ aññathatta ppattiyā vuttam eva attham
translated: “Standing” is together with the moment of standing. “The alteration of what is standing” is the alteration of what has arisen.🔽“Is evident” is perceptible. Because of the conditionality of what is merely persisting, aging is evident in one who is merely living by means of the life faculty.

original: pākaṭataraṃ kātuṃ “ṭhitī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Jīvi…pe… nāmaṃ. Tathā hi abhidhamme “āyu ṭhitī”ti
analyzed: pākaṭataram kātum ṭhiti itiādi vuttam jīvipe nāmam tathā hi abhidhamme āyu ṭhiti iti
translated: The alteration of what has arisen is evident. In order to make the meaning stated more evident, “standing” and so on is said. “Life” is the life faculty. “Name” is the other three aggregates. For in the Abhidhamma the life faculty is called “standing” .

original: niddiṭṭhaṃ. Aññathattanti jarāya nāmanti sambandho.
analyzed: niddiṭṭham aññathattanti jarāya nāmanti sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is this: “alteration” is aging.

original: Tīṇi lakkhaṇāni honti saṅkhatasabhāvalakkhaṇato. Yo koci rūpadhammo vā arūpadhammo🔽vā lokiyo vā lokuttaro vā saṅkhāro. Saṅkhāro, na lakkhaṇaṃ uppādādisabhāvattā. Lakkhaṇaṃ,🔽na saṅkhāro uppādādirahitattā. Na ca…pe… sakkā saṅkhāradhammattā lakkhaṇassa. Nāpi
analyzed: tīṇi lakkhaṇāni honti saṅkhata sabhāva lakkhaṇataḥ yaḥ koci rūpa dhammo vā arūpa dhammo  vā lokiyaḥ vā lokuttaraḥ vā saṅkhāro saṅkhāraḥ na lakkhaṇam uppāda ādi sabhāva ttā lakkhaṇam  na saṅkhāraḥ uppāda ādi rahita ttā na cape sakkā saṅkhāra dhamma ttā lakkhaṇassa nā api
translated: The three characteristics are the characteristic of the formed as such.

original: lakkhaṇaṃ vinā saṅkhāro paññāpetuṃ sakkā saṅkhārabhāvena. Tenāha “lakkhaṇenā”tiādi.
analyzed: lakkhaṇam vinā saṅkhāraḥ paññāpetum sakkā saṅkhāra bhāvena tena āha lakkhaṇena atiādi
translated: Any formed thing, whether a material or an immaterial, mundane or supramundane, dhammā, is a formation, not a characteristic, because of its being the nature of arising, etc. A characteristic is not a formation because of its being devoid of arising, etc. And it is not possible to point to a formation as a characteristic because of its being a formed dhammā. Nor is it possible to point to a characteristic without a formation because of its being the nature of a characteristic. Therefore it is said, “By the characteristic” , etc.

original: Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ upamāya vibhāvetuṃ “yathā”tiādimāha. Tattha lakkhaṇanti kāḷarattasabalādibhāvalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: idāni yathāvuttam attham upamāya vibhāvetum yathā iti ādim āha tattha lakkhaṇam ti kāḷa ratta sabala ādi bhāva lakkhaṇam
translated: Now, in order to illustrate by means of a simile the meaning stated thus, he said, “Just as” , etc. Herein, the characteristic is the obvious characteristic of black, red, white, etc.,

original: pākaṭaṃ hoti “ayaṃ asukassa gāvī”ti.
analyzed: pākaṭam hoti ayam asukassa gāvī iti
translated: and the cow is obvious as having that characteristic. “This is so-and-so’s cow” is said.

original: Evaṃ saṅkhāropi paññāyati sabhāvato upadhārentassa uppādalakkhaṇampi uppādāvatthāti
analyzed: evam saṅkhāraḥ api paññāyati sabhāvataḥ upadhārentassa uppāda lakkhaṇam pi
translated: So too, a formation is obvious as such to one who investigates it, and its characteristic of arising is obvious as the basis for arising.

original: katvā. Kālasaṅkhātoti uppajjamānakālasaṅkhāto. Tassa saṅkhārassa. Khaṇopīti uppādakkhaṇopi
analyzed: katvā kāla saṅkhātoti uppajjamāna kāla saṅkhāto tassa saṅkhārassa khaṇaḥ api iti uppāda khaṇaḥ api
translated: As to the reckoning of time: as to the reckoning of the time of arising. Of that formation. The moment: the moment of arising.

original: paññāyati. Uppādopīti uppādalakkhaṇopi. Jarālakkhaṇanti uppannajīraṇalakkhaṇaṃ, taṃ🔽“ṭhitassa aññathatta”nti vuttaṃ. “Bhaṅgakkhaṇe saṅkhāropi taṃlakkhaṇampi kālasaṅkhāto
analyzed: paññāyati uppādaḥ api iti uppāda lakkhaṇaḥ api jarā lakkhaṇam ti uppanna jīraṇa lakkhaṇam tam  ṭhitassa aññathattan ti vuttam bhaṅga kkhaṇe saṅkhāraḥ api taṃlakkhaṇam pi kāla saṅkhāto
translated: and the sign of its presence is discerned. Arising is also its characteristic of arising. The characteristic of ageing is the ageing of what has come to be. That is said to be “the alteration of what endures.” At the moment of dissolution, the formation and its characteristic are discerned as the moment of dissolution, because of the reckoning of time.

original: tassa khaṇopi paññāyatī”ti pāṭho. Keci pana “jarāpī”ti padampettha pakkhipanti. Evañca🔽vadanti “na hi tasmiṃ khaṇe taruṇo hutvā saṅkhāro bhijjati, atha kho jiyyamāno mahallako
analyzed: tassa khaṇaḥ api paññāyati iti pāṭhaḥ keci pana jarā api iti padam pa ittha pakkhipanti evam ca  vadanti na hi tasmin khaṇe taruṇaḥ hutvā saṅkhāraḥ bhijjati atha khalu jiyyamānaḥ mahallakaḥ
translated: The reading is “At the moment of dissolution, the formation and its characteristic are discerned as the moment of dissolution.”

original: viya jiṇṇo eva hutvā bhijjatī”ti, bhaṅgeneva pana jarā abhibhuyyati khaṇassa atiittarabhāvato
analyzed: viya jiṇṇaḥ eva hutvā bhijjati iti bhaṅgena iva pana jarā khaṇassa ati ittara bhāvato
translated: But some include the word “ageing” here, and they say that it is not a formation that is young that breaks up at that moment, but rather it is one that has become aged and decrepit, like an old man who is feeble, that breaks up. But ageing is only evident by means of dissolution, and it is not possible to discern it as enduring because it is surpassed by the moment. This is their intention.🔽The three characteristics of the immaterial states.

original: na sakkā paññāpetuṃ ṭhitiyāti tesaṃ adhippāyo. Tānīti arūpadhammānaṃ tīṇi lakkhaṇāni.🔽Atthikkhaṇanti arūpadhammavijjamānakkhaṇaṃ, uppādakkhaṇanti adhippāyo. Sabbadhammānanti
analyzed: na sakkā paññāpetum ṭhitiyā ti tesam adhippāyaḥ tāni iti arūpa dhammānam tīṇi lakkhaṇāni 🔽atthi khaṇanti arūpa dhamma vijjamāna kkhaṇam uppāda kkhaṇanti adhippāyaḥ sabba dhammānam ti
translated: The moment of its presence: the moment of the presence of the immaterial state is intended.

original: sabbesaṃ rūpārūpadhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā na bhavitabbaṃ. Tassevāti tassā eva ṭhitiyā. Tamatthanti
analyzed: sabbesam rūpa arūpa dhammānam ṭhitiyā na bhavitabbam tassa iva ati tassāḥ eva ṭhitiyā
translated: and it would not be possible for any material or immaterial state to endure. ‘Of that itself’: of that very endurance. ‘That meaning’:

original: jarālakkhaṇassa paññāpetuṃ asakkuṇeyyabhāvaṃ. Aññe pana “santativasena ṭhānaṃ ṭhitī”ti🔽vadanti, tayidaṃ akāraṇaṃ aṭṭhānaṃ. Yasmā sutte “ṭhitassa aññathattaṃ paññāyatī”ti
analyzed: jarā lakkhaṇassa paññāpetum asakkuṇeyya bhāvam aññe pana santati vasena ṭhānam ṭhitī ti  vadanti tayidam akāraṇam aṭṭhānam yasmā sutte ṭhitassa aññathattam paññāyati iti
translated: the impossibility of pointing to the characteristic of ageing. But others say that ‘endurance’ is the state of standing by way of continuity.🔽This is no reason, it is untenable. Because in the suttas endurance is shown without distinction as the opposite of arising and dissolution, with the words, ‘In what is enduring, change is discerned’ .

original: uppādavayehi nibbisesena ṭhitiyā jotitattā. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.🔽Apica yathā dhammassa uppādāvatthāya bhinnā bhaṅgāvatthā icchitā, aññathā uppajjamānameva
analyzed: uppāda vayehi nibbisesena ṭhitiyāḥ jotita ttā yat pana ittha vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vuttam eva  apica yathā dhammassa uppāda avatthāya bhinnāḥ bhaṅga avatthāḥ icchitāḥ aññathā uppajjamānam eva
translated: But what should be said here has already been said above.

original: bhijjatīti āpajjati, evaṃ bhaṅgāvatthāyapi bhinnā bhaṅgābhimukhāvatthā icchitabbā.
analyzed: bhijjati iti āpajjati evam bhaṅga avatthāya api bhinnā bhaṅga abhimukhā avatthā icchitabbā
translated: Moreover, just as the place of dissolution is assumed to be different from the place of arising of a state, otherwise it would follow that it is dissolved as soon as it arises, so too the place of dissolution should be assumed to be different from the place of facing dissolution.

original: Na hi abhaṅgābhimukho bhijjati. Na cettha sakkā uppādābhimukhāvatthaṃ parikappetuṃ
analyzed: na hi abhaṅga abhimukhaḥ bhijjati na ca ittha sakkā uppāda abhimukha avattham parikappetum
translated: For it is not dissolved while not facing dissolution. And it is not possible to assume a place of facing arising,

original: tadā tassa aladdhattalābhattā. Ayaṃ visesoti ṭhitikkhaṇo nāma rūpadhammānaṃyeva,
analyzed: tadā tassa a laddha ta lābha ttā ayam visesaḥ ti ṭhiti khaṇaḥ nāma rūpa dhammānaṃ yeva
translated: because at that time it has not yet obtained that. This is the difference. The ‘moment of endurance’ is only of material dhammas,

original: na arūpadhammānanti ayaṃ īdiso viseso. Ācariyamati nāma tasseva ācariyassa mati,
analyzed: na arūpa dhammānam ti ayam īdisaḥ visesaḥ ācariyamati nāma tassa iva ācariyassa mati
translated: and not of formless states. This is the kind of difference. The teacher’s view is the view of that teacher.

original: sā sabbadubbalāti āha “tasmā”tiādi.
analyzed: sā sabba dubbalā ti āha tasmā atiādi
translated: It is the weakest of all, which is why it is said, “Therefore … ”

original: Ānandasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ānanda sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Ānanda Sutta is ended.

original: 7-10. Anudhammasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Anudhamma Sutta, etc.,🔽is ended.

original: 39-42. Apāyadukkhe sakalasaṃsāradukkhe ca patituṃ adatvā dhāraṇaṭṭhena dhammo, maggaphalanibbānāni.
analyzed: apāya dukkhe sakala saṃsāra dukkhe ca patitum a datvā dhāraṇa ṭṭhena dhammaḥ magga phala nibbānāni
translated: The Dhamma is so called in the sense of bearing up , in that it does not allow one to fall into the suffering of the states of loss or into the suffering of the whole of the round of rebirths. It comprises the path, fruition, and Nibbāna.🔽And the preliminary part of the way that is in conformity with that is called “the Dhamma that is in conformity with that” .

original: Tadanulomikā cassa pubbabhāgapaṭipadāti āha “dhammānudhammapaṭipannassā”tiādi. “Nibbidābahulo”ti
analyzed: tad anulomikā ca ssa pubbabhāga paṭipadā ti āha dhamma anudhamma paṭipannassa ātiādi nibbidā bahulo ti
translated: The expression “abounding in dispassion”

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ paduddhāro kato, pāḷiyaṃ pana “nibbidābahulaṃ vihareyyā”ti āgataṃ.🔽Ukkaṇṭhanabahuloti sabbabhavesu ukkaṇṭhanabahulo. Tīhi pariññāhīti ñātatīraṇappahānapariññāhi.
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam paduddhāro kato pāḷiyam pana nibbidā bahulam vihareyya āti āgatam  ukkaṇṭhana bahulo ti sabba bhavesu ukkaṇṭhana bahulo tīhi pariññāhi iti ñāta tīraṇa ppahāna pariññāhi
translated: is a gloss on the words “abounding in dispassion” in the text, which is “abounding in the state of dispassion” .🔽“Abounding in weariness” means abounding in weariness with all kinds of becoming.🔽“With three kinds of full understanding” : with full understanding as the known, full understanding as investigation, and full understanding as abandoning.

original: Parijānātīti tebhūmakadhamme paricchijja jānāti, vipassanaṃ ussukkāpeti. Parimuccati
analyzed: parijānāti iti tebhūmaka dhamme paricchijja jānāti vipassanam ussukka apeti parimuccati
translated: “He fully understands” : he comprehends by delimiting the states in the three planes, and he intensifies insight.

original: sabbasaṃkilesato “maggo pavattito parimuccatī”ti vuttattā. Tathāti iminā ito paresu
analyzed: sabba saṃkilesataḥ maggaḥ pavattitaḥ parimuccati iti vutta ttā tathā ati iminā itas paresu
translated: “He is freed from all defilements” is said because the path is set up.🔽By “thus” he shows that the path is in the other three.

original: tīsu maggo hotīti dasseti. Idhāti imasmiṃ sutte. Aniyamitāti aggahitā. Tesu niyamitā
analyzed: tīsu maggaḥ hoti iti dasseti idha ati imasmin sutte aniyamitā ati agga hitā tesu niyamitā
translated: “Here” means in this sutta. “Not specified” means not taken up.🔽They are specified in the passage beginning, “Contemplating inconstancy” .🔽“That” is contemplation. “Here” means in that.

original: “aniccānupassī”tiādivacanato. Sāti anupassanā. Tattha niyamitavasenevāti idaṃ lakkhaṇavacanaṃ🔽yathā “yadi me byādhayo bhaveyyuṃ, dātabbamidamosadha”nti. Na hi sakkā etissā eva
analyzed: anicca anupassī iti ādi vacanato sā ati anupassanā tattha niyamita vasena iva ati idam lakkhaṇa vacanam  yathā yadi me byādhayaḥ bhaveyyum na hi sakkā etissaḥ eva
translated: This is a characteristic statement.🔽It is like the statement, “If I had any diseases, I would give you this medicine.”

original: anupassanāya vasena sammasanācāraṃ matthakaṃ pāpetunti.
analyzed: anupassanāya vasena sammasana ācāram matthakam pāpetunti
translated: For it is not possible to bring the practice of reflection to perfection by means of that contemplation alone.

original: Anudhammasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: anudhamma sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Anudhammas is finished.

original: Natumhākaṃvaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽5. Attadīpavaggo
analyzed: na tumhākam vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  atta dīpa vaggo
translated: The commentary on the Natumhākaṃ vagga is finished.🔽The Attadīpa Vagga

original: 1. Attadīpasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: attadīpa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Attadīpa Sutta

original: 43. Dvīhi bhāgehi āpo ettha gatāti dīpo, dīpo viyāti dīpo oghehi anajjhottharanīyatāya.
analyzed: dvīhi bhāgehi āpaḥ ettha gatā ati dīpaḥ dīpaḥ viyā ati dīpaḥ oghehi an ajjhottharanīya tāya
translated: An island is a place that is gone to for protection from two parts of the ocean. An island is like an island in that it cannot be submerged by the ocean.

original: Yo paro na hoti, so attā, idha pana dhammo adhippeto. Attā dīpo etesanti attadīpā.
analyzed: yaḥ paraḥ na hoti saḥ attā idha pana dhammaḥ adhippetaḥ attā dīpaḥ etesanti atta dīpā
translated: The self is that which is not other. But here the Dhamma is intended. They have a self for an island are those who have the Dhamma for an island.

original: Paṭisaraṇattho dīpaṭṭhoti āha – “attasaraṇāti idaṃ tasseva vevacana”nti. Lokiyalokuttaro
analyzed: paṭisaraṇa atthaḥ dīpa ṭṭho ti āha atta saraṇā iti idam tassa iva vevacanam ti lokiya lokuttaraḥ
translated: The meaning of “refuge” is the meaning of “island” . That is why he said: “Self-refuge is a synonym for that” .🔽The Dhamma, which is both mundane and supramundane, is called “self” because it is the sole protector.

original: dhammo attā nāma ekantanāthabhāvato. Paṭhamena padena vutto eva attho dutiyapadena
analyzed: dhammaḥ attā nāma ekanta nātha bhāvataḥ paṭhamena padena vuttaḥ eva atthaḥ dutiya padena
translated: The meaning stated by the first term is stated again by the second term.🔽That is why it is said: “Therefore it is said” , etc.

original: vuccatīti vuttaṃ “tenevāhā”tiādi. Yavati etasmā phalaṃ pasavatīti yoni, kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: vuccati iti vuttam tena iva āha atiādi yavati etasmā phalam pasavati iti kāraṇam
translated: The source is the cause from which the fruit originates.🔽The source is the origination-place of these .

original: Kiṃ pabhuti uppattiṭṭhānaṃ etesanti kiṃ pabhutikā. Pahānadassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ. Tenevāha
analyzed: kim pabhuti uppatti ṭṭhānam etesan ti kim pabhutikā pahāna dassana ttham āraddham tena iva āha
translated: It is undertaken for the purpose of showing the abandoning . That is why he said:🔽“Previously, too, they were abandoned” , etc.

original: “pubbe ceva…pe… te pahīyantī”ti. Na paritassati taṇhāparittāsassa abhāvato. Vipassanaṅgenāti
analyzed: pubbe ceva pe te pahīyanti iti na paritassati taṇhā parittāsassa abhāvataḥ vipassana aṅgena ati
translated: He does not worry because he has no craving-worry .

original: vipassanāsaṅkhātena kāraṇena.
analyzed: vipassanā saṅkhātena kāraṇena
translated: By the means of insight : by the means called insight.

original: Attadīpasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: attadīpa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Attadīpa Sutta is ended.

original: 2. Paṭipadāsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Paṭipadā Sutta

original: 44. Sabhāvatosanto vijjamāno kāyo rūpādidhammasamūhoti sakkāyoti āha – “sakkāyo dukkha”nti.
analyzed: vijjamāno kāyaḥ rūpa ādi dhamma samūho ti sa kāyaḥ iti āha sa kāyaḥ dukkhanti
translated: The body, which is peaceful by nature, is the collection of material and immaterial dhammas called “form,” etc. It is called “self” . That is why he said: “The self is suffering” .

original: Diṭṭhi eva samanupassanā, diṭṭhisahitā vā samanupassanā diṭṭhisamanupassanā, diṭṭhimaññanāya
analyzed: diṭṭhi eva samanupassanā diṭṭhi sahitā vā samanupassanā diṭṭhi samanupassanā diṭṭhi maññanāya
translated: Contemplation of view is the contemplation of the other conceivings together with the conceiving of views.

original: saddhiṃ itaramaññanā. Saha vipassanāya catumaggañāṇaṃ samanupassanā “catunnaṃ ariyasaccānaṃ🔽sammadeva anurūpato passanā”ti katvā.
analyzed: saddhim itara maññanā saha vipassanāya catu magga ñāṇam samanupassanā catunnam ariya saccānam  sammadeva anurūpato katvā
translated: The four path-knowledges together with insight are contemplation in the sense of “seeing rightly and suitably the four noble truths.”

original: Paṭipadāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭipadā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Path of Practice is finished.🔽The Unformed Element

original: 3. Aniccasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anicca sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element

original: 45. Virāgo nāma maggo, vimuttiphalanti āha – “maggakkhaṇe virajjati, phalakkhaṇe🔽vimuccatī”ti. Aggahetvāti evaṃ nirujjhamānehi āsavehi “ahaṃ mamā”ti kañci dhammaṃ
analyzed: virāgaḥ nāma maggaḥ vimutti phalanti āha magga kkhaṇe virajjati phala kkhaṇe  vimuccati iti aggahetvā ati evam nirujjhamānehi āsavehi aham mama ati kañci dhammam
translated: The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element

original: anādiyitvā. “Cittaṃ virattaṃ, vimuttaṃ hotī”ti vuttattā phalaṃ gayhati, “khīṇā jātī”tiādinā
analyzed: an ādiyitvā cittam virattam vimuttam hoti iti vutta ttā phalam khīṇā jātī iti ādinā
translated: The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element

original: paccavekkhaṇāti āha “saha phalena paccavekkhaṇadassanattha”nti. Upari kattabbakiccābhāvena
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇā ti āha saha phalena paccavekkhaṇa dassana attham ti upari kattabba kicca abhāvena
translated: The Unformed Element🔽The Unformed Element🔽The

original: ṭhitaṃ. Tenāha “vimuttattā ṭhita”nti. Yaṃ pattabbaṃ, taṃ aggaphalassa pattabhāvena
analyzed: ṭhitam tena āha vimutta ttā ṭhitam ti yam pattabbam tam agga phalassa patta bhāvena
translated: It is “stood upon” because of being liberated. Thus it is said: “It is stood upon because of being liberated.”

original: adhigatattā santuṭṭhaṃ parituṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: adhigata ttā santuṭṭham parituṭṭham
translated: It is “satisfied” and “pleased” because of having reached the highest fruit, which is what should be reached.

original: Aniccasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: anicca sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the sutta on impermanence is finished.

original: 4. Dutiyaaniccasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya anicca sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the second sutta on impermanence

original: 46. Pubbantaṃ atītakhandhakoṭṭhāsaṃ. Anugatāti sassatādīni kappetvā gahaṇavasena
analyzed: pubba antam atīta khandha koṭṭhāsam anugatā ati sassata ādīni kappetvā gahaṇa vasena
translated: The past is the section on the aggregates in the past. “Followed”: they are followed by taking them as eternal, etc., and then grasping them.

original: anugatā. Aṭṭhārasa diṭṭhiyoti catasso sassatadiṭṭhiyo, catasso ekaccasassatadiṭṭhiyo,
analyzed: anugatāḥ aṭṭhārasa diṭṭhiyaḥ ti catasso sassata diṭṭhiyaḥ catasso ekacca sassata diṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: “The eighteen views”: there are four eternalist views, four views of the partial eternalists,

original: catasso antānantikadiṭṭhiyo, catasso amarāvikkhepadiṭṭhiyo, dve adhiccasamuppannadiṭṭhiyoti
analyzed: catasso anta anantika diṭṭhiyaḥ catasso amara āvikkhepa diṭṭhiyaḥ dve adhicca samuppanna diṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: four views of the finitists and infinitists, four views of the escapists, and two views of the chance originationists.

original: evaṃ aṭṭhārasa diṭṭhiyo na honti paccayaghātena. Aparantanti anāgataṃ khandhakoṭṭhāsaṃ
analyzed: evam aṭṭhārasa diṭṭhiyaḥ na honti paccaya ghātena anāgatam khandha koṭṭhāsam
translated: Thus these eighteen views are not by the destruction of conditions. The future is the section on the aggregates in the future.

original: sassatādibhāvaṃ kappetvā gahaṇavasena anugatā. Soḷasa saññīvādā, aṭṭha asaññīvādā,
analyzed: sassata ādi bhāvam kappetvā gahaṇa vasena anugatā soḷasa saññīvādāḥ aṭṭha asaññīvādā
translated: They are followed by taking them as eternal, etc., and then grasping them. There are sixteen views of the eternalists, eight views of the non-eternalists,

original: aṭṭha nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā, satta ucchedavādā, pañca paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānavādāti
analyzed: aṭṭha nevasaññī nāsaññī vādā satta uccheda vādā pañca parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādā ati
translated: eight views of the neither-eternalists-nor-non-eternalists, seven annihilationist views, and five views of the nibbana here and now.

original: evaṃ catucattālīsa diṭṭhiyo na honti paccayaghātena. Sassatadiṭṭhithāmaso ceva sīlabbatadiṭṭhiparāmāso
analyzed: evam catucattālīsa diṭṭhiyaḥ na honti paccaya ghātena sassata diṭṭhi thāmaso ca iva sīlabbata diṭṭhi parāmāso
translated: Thus the forty-four views do not exist by the destruction of conditions. The view of eternalism and the view of moral efficacy and ritualism

original: ca na hoti paccayaghātena. Tenāha “ettāvatā paṭhamamaggo dassito”ti anavasesadiṭṭhipahānakittanato.
analyzed: ca na hoti paccaya ghātena tena āha ettāvatā paṭhama maggaḥ dassito ti anavasesa diṭṭhi pahāna kittanato
translated: So the forty-four views are absent owing to the destruction of conditions. And the view of eternity and the clinging to rules and vows are absent owing to the destruction of conditions. Hence it was said above, “The first path is shown in this way,” since it is praised for the complete abandoning of views.🔽“Abandoned” means suppressed.

original: Pahīnā vikkhambhitā. Idaṃ panāti “rūpasmi”ntiādi.
analyzed: pahīnāḥ vikkhambhitāḥ idam panāti rūpasmin tiādi
translated: “This” is “in visible objects” , etc.

original: Dutiyaaniccasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya anicca sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second sutta on impermanence is ended.

original: 5. Samanupassanāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: samanupassanā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Contemplation

original: 47. Paripuṇṇagāhavasenāti pañcakkhandhe asesetvā ekajjhaṃ “attā”ti gahaṇavasena.
analyzed: paripuṇṇa gāha vasena āti pañca kkhandhe a sesetvā ekajjham attā iti gahaṇa vasena
translated: By a complete grasping: by grasping the five aggregates without exception as a single “self.”🔽They contemplate one of these five aggregates as a self.

original: Etesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ aññataraṃ “attā”ti samanupassanti. Itīti evaṃ.
analyzed: etesam pañcannam upādānakkhandhānam aññataram attā ati samanupassanti iti iti evam
translated: “Thus”: in this way.🔽In the case of the person in whom this contemplation called “view of self” exists,

original: Yassa puggalassa ayaṃ attadiṭṭhisaṅkhātā samanupassanā atthi paṭipakkhena avihatattā
analyzed: yassa puggalassa ayam atta diṭṭhi saṅkhātā samanupassanā atthi paṭipakkhena avihata ttā
translated: it is present because it is not suppressed by its opposite.

original: saṃvijjati. Pañcannaṃ indriyānanti cakkhādīnaṃ indriyānaṃ.
analyzed: saṃvijjati cakkha ādīnam indriyānaṃ
translated: Of the five faculties: of the eye, etc.,

original: Ārammaṇanti kammaviññāṇassa ārammaṇaṃ. Mānavasena ca diṭṭhivasena ca “asmī”ti gāhe🔽sijjhante taṃsahagatā taṇhāpi taggahitāva hotīti vuttaṃ “taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasena asmīti
analyzed: ārammaṇanti kamma viññāṇassa ārammaṇam māna vasena ca diṭṭhi vasena ca asmi iti gāhe  sijjhante tad sahagatā taṇhā api tad gahitā ava hoti iti vuttam taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena asmi iti
translated: And because of conceit and views, the “I am” conceit🔽and the craving associated with it are also taken as the self.🔽Thus it is said: “He thinks thus: ‘I am,’🔽‘I will be’ in the future.”

original: evampissa hotī”ti. Gahetvāti ahaṃkāravatthuvasena gahetvā. Ayaṃ ahamasmīti ayaṃ cakkhādiko,
analyzed: evam pi ssa hoti iti gahetvā ati ahaṃkāra vatthu vasena gahetvā ayam aham asmi iti ayam cakkhu ādiko
translated: “Having taken” : having taken as the self the basis for the conceit “I am.”🔽“This is my self” : this eye, etc., or this pleasure, etc., is my self.

original: sukhādiko vā ahamasmi. “Rūpī attā arogo paraṃ maraṇā”ti evamādigahaṇavasena pavattanato
analyzed: sukha ādikaḥ vā aham asmi rūpī attā arogaḥ param evamādi gahaṇa vasena pavattanato
translated: Because it occurs in the form of such conceivings as “The self is material after death, and is healthy,”

original: vuttaṃ “rūpī bhavissantiādīni sabbāni sassatameva bhajantī”ti. Vipassanābhinivesato
analyzed: vuttam rūpī bhavissanti ādīni sabbāni sassatam eva bhajanti iti vipassanā abhinivesato
translated: it is said: “All these views belong to eternalism.”🔽Before the attainment of insight, the five aggregates are as they are.

original: pubbe yathevākārāni pañcindriyāni, atha vipassanābhinivesato paraṃ tenevākārena ṭhitesu🔽cakkhādīsu indriyesu avijjā pahīyati vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhaetvā maggassa uppādanena, atha
analyzed: pubbe yathā iva ākārāni pañca indriyāni atha vipassanā abhinivesato param tena iva ākārena ṭhitesu  cakkhu ādīsu indriyesu avijjā pahīyati vipassanam vaḍḍhaetvā maggassa uppādanena atha
translated: Then, after the attainment of insight, they remain as they are.🔽In the eye, etc., ignorance is abandoned by the arising of the path after the development of insight.🔽Then, through a succession of paths, the knowledge of the path of arahantship arises.

original: maggaparamparāya arahattamaggavijjā uppajjati. Taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiyo kammasambhārabhāvato.
analyzed: magga paramparāya arahatta magga vijjā uppajjati taṇhā māna diṭṭhiyo kamma sambhāra bhāvato
translated: Craving, conceit, and views are the conditions for kamma.

original: Kammassa…pe… eko sandhīti hetuphalasandhi. Puna eko sandhīti phalahetusandhimāha.
analyzed: kammassape ekaḥ sandhi iti hetu phala sandhi punar ekaḥ sandhi iti phala hetu sandhim āha
translated: … of kamma … one juncture: this is the juncture of cause and fruit. Again, one juncture: this is the juncture of fruit and cause.

original: Tayo papañcā atīto addhā atītabhavaaddhānaṃ tesaṃ adhippetattā. Anāgatassa paccayo
analyzed: tayo papañcā atītaḥ addhā atīta bhava addhānam tesam adhippeta ttā anāgatassa paccayo
translated: Three proliferations: the past extent, the future extent, and the present world. The condition for the future is shown

original: dassito assutavato puthujjanassa vasena. Sutavato pana ariyasāvakassa vasena vaṭṭassa vūpasamo dassitoti.
analyzed: dassitaḥ assutavato puthujjanassa vasena sutavataḥ pana ariyasāvakassa vasena vaṭṭassa vūpasamaḥ dassito ti
translated: from the standpoint of the uninstructed worldling who has not seen the noble ones. But the stilling of the round is shown from the standpoint of the instructed noble disciple.

original: Samanupassanāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: samanupassanā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Discourse on Contemplations is finished.

original: 6. Khandhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: khandha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Discourse on the Aggregates

original: 48. Tathevāti ārammaṇabhāveneva. Ārammaṇakaraṇavasena upādānehi upādātabbanti upādāniyaṃ.
analyzed: tathā iva ati ārammaṇa bhāvena iva ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena upādānehi upādātabbanti upādāniyam
translated: “Just so”: only as objects. They are to be clung to by the clingings in the sense of being made into objects, thus they are “able to be clung to” .

original: Idhāpīti upādānakkhandhesupi. Vibhāgatthe gayhamāne aniṭṭhappasaṅgopi siyā, abhidhamme
analyzed: idha api iti upādānakkhandhesu pi vibhāga atthe gayhamāne aniṭṭha ppasaṅgaḥ api siyā abhidhamme
translated: Here too: in the case of the aggregates as objects of clinging. If the meaning of “division” is taken, then what is undesirable might be expected. But in the Abhidhamma

original: ca rāsaṭṭho eva āgato, “tadekajjhaṃ abhisaṃyuhitvā”ti vacanato “rāsaṭṭhena”icceva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca rāsaṭṭhaḥ eva āgataḥ tat ekajjham abhisaṃyuhitvā iti vacanato rāsaṭṭhena ecca eva vuttam
translated: the meaning of “heap” is given, because of the words, “having combined all that into one” . That is why only the meaning of “heap” is stated.

original: Khandhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khandha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Discourse on the Aggregates is finished.

original: 7-8. Soṇasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Soṇa Sutta, etc.

original: 49-50. Visiṭṭhoti padhāno. Uttamoti ukkaṭṭho. Aññaṃ kiṃ bhaveyyāti aññaṃ kiṃ kāraṇaṃ🔽bhaveyya tathā samanupassanāya aññesaṃ avijjamānatāya vacanapariṭṭhitipabhinnato.
analyzed: visiṭṭhaḥ ti padhānaḥ uttamaḥ ti ukkaṭṭhaḥ aññam kim bhaveyya ati aññam kim kāraṇam  bhaveyya tathā samanupassanāya aññesam a vijjamāna tāya vacana pariṭṭhiti pabhinnato
translated: ‘Outstanding’ means pre-eminent. ‘Supreme’ means the highest. ‘What else could there be?’ means what other reason could there be?

original: Vajirabhedadesanaṃ nāma atthato teparivaṭṭadesanā.
analyzed: vajirabhedadesanam nāma atthato
translated: Because, by such a contemplation, there is nothing else. The ‘turning away from verbal proliferation’ is the explanation of the ‘breaking up of the thunderbolt’.

original: Soṇasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: soṇa sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sonadanda Sutta is ended.

original: 9-10. Nandikkhayasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: nandi khaya sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Nandiya Sutta, etc.

original: 51-52. Navamadasamesūti suttadvayaṃ saheva uddhaṭaṃ, dvīsupi atthavaṇṇanāya sarikkhabhāvato.
analyzed: navama dasamesu iti sutta dvayam saha iva uddhaṭam dvīsu pi attha vaṇṇanāya sa rikkha bhāvato
translated: The two suttas in the ninth and tenth months are commented on together because their meaning is similar.

original: Nandanaṭṭhena nandī, rañjanaṭṭhena rāgo. Satipi saddatthato bhede “imesaṃ atthato
analyzed: nandana ṭṭhena nandī rañjana ṭṭhena rāgaḥ sati pi sadda tthataḥ bhede imesam atthato
translated: ‘Delight’ is in the sense of delighting, and ‘lust’ is in the sense of relishing. Although there is a difference in the literal meaning,🔽nevertheless, after saying that there is no difference in the meaning,

original: ninnānākaraṇatāyā”ti vatvāpi pahāyakadhammabhedena pana labbhateva bhedamattāti dassetuṃ
analyzed: ninnānākaraṇatāya iti vatvā api pahāyaka dhamma bhedena pana labbha tā iva bheda mattā ati dassetuṃ
translated: in order to show that there is a difference in the sense of the quality to be abandoned,

original: “nibbidānupassanāya vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Virajjanto rāgaṃ pajahatīti sambandho. Ettāvatāti
analyzed: nibbida anupassanāya vā tiādi vuttam virajjantaḥ rāgam pajahati iti sambandhaḥ ettāvatā ati
translated: it is said, ‘through the contemplation of dispassion,’ and so on. The connection is this: one who is becoming dispassionate abandons lust. As far as this:

original: “nandikkhayā rāgakkhayo”ti ettāvatā. Vipassanaṃ niṭṭhapetvā vipassanākiccassa pariyosānena.
analyzed: nandi khayā rāga kkhayo ti ettāvatā vipassanam niṭṭhapetvā vipassanā kiccassa pariyosānena
translated: “With the destruction of delight, the destruction of lust” is the end of insight.🔽With the destruction of lust: with the destruction of lust by the insight that ends in emergence.

original: Rāgakkhayāti vuṭṭhānagāminipariyosānāya vipassanāya rāgassa khepitattā. Anantaraṃ
analyzed: rāga kkhayā ti vuṭṭhāna gāmi nipariyosānāya vipassanāya rāgassa khepita ttā anantaram
translated: With the destruction of delight: with the destruction of delight by the noble path that arises next to that insight.

original: uppannena ariyamaggena samucchedavasena nandikkhayoti. Tenāha “idha maggaṃ dassetvā”ti.
analyzed: uppannena ariya maggena samuccheda vasena nandi khayaḥ ti tena āha idha maggam dassetvā iti
translated: That is why it is said, “Having shown the path here” .

original: Anantaraṃ pana uppannena ariyaphalena paṭipassaddhivasena nandirāgakkhayā sabbaṃ
analyzed: anantaram pana uppannena ariya phalena paṭipassaddhi vasena nandi rāga kkhayā sabbam
translated: But with the destruction of lust and delight by the noble fruition that arises next to that path, the mind is liberated from all defilements.

original: saṃkilesato cittaṃ vimuccatīti. Tenāha “phalaṃ dassita”nti.🔽Nandikkhayasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saṃkilesataḥ cittam vimuccati iti tena āha phalam dassitam ti  nandikkhaya sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: That is why it is said, “Having shown the fruition here” .🔽The commentary on the Nandikkhaya Sutta is ended.

original: Attadīpavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: attadīpa vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Attadīpa Vagga is ended.

original: Mūlapaṇṇāsako samatto.🔽6. Upayavaggo
analyzed: mūla paṇṇāsako samatto  upaya vaggaḥ
translated: The first section is finished.🔽The Chapter on Approach

original: 1. Upayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Approach

original: 53. Upetīti upayo. Kathamupeti? Taṇhāmānādivasenāti āha “taṇhāmānadiṭṭhivasenā”ti.
analyzed: upeti iti upayaḥ katham upeti taṇhā māna ādi vasena ati āha taṇhā māna diṭṭhi vasena ati
translated: Approach: approach is upayo . How does one approach? By means of craving, conceit, etc., is the meaning. That is why it is said, “By means of craving, conceit, and views” .

original: Kathamidaṃ labbhatīti? “Avimutto”ti vacanato. Taṇhādiṭṭhivasena hi baddho, kiṃ upetīti
analyzed: katham idam labbhati iti avimuttaḥ ti vacanataḥ taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena hi baddhaḥ kim upeti iti
translated: How is this known? Because of the words, “He is not liberated” . For one bound by craving and views is not liberated. What does he approach?

original: āha “pañcakkhandhe”ti tabbinimuttassa tathā upetassa abhāvato. Ko panupetīti? Taṃsamaṅgīpuggalo.
analyzed: āha pañca kkhandha iti tad vinimuttassa tathā upetassa abhāvataḥ kaḥ panupeti iti tad samaṅgī puggalo
translated: He said “the five aggregates” because there is no such coming to be of what is free from that cause. But who comes to be? The person who is a member of that class.

original: Taṇhādiṭṭhivasena upagamassa vuttattā viññāṇanti akusalakammaviññāṇamevāti vadanti.
analyzed: taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena upagamassa vuttattā viññāṇanti akusala kamma viññāṇam eva ati vadanti
translated: And since the coming to be is said to be by craving and by view, they say that “consciousness” is only unprofitable kamma-resultant consciousness.

original: Javāpetvāti gahitajavaṃ katvā. Yathā paṭisandhiṃ ākaḍḍhituṃ samatthaṃ, evaṃ katvā.
analyzed: java apetvā iti gahita javam katvā yathā paṭisandhim ākaḍḍhitum samattham evam katvā
translated: Having made it run: having made it run as far as the rebirth-linking. Having made it able to draw the rebirth-linking.

original: Tenāha “paṭisandhī”tiādi. Aggahaṇe kāraṇaṃ vuttameva “okaṃ pahāya aniketasārī”ti
analyzed: tena āha paṭisandhi itiādi aggahaṇe kāraṇam vuttam eva okam pahāya aniketa sāri iti
translated: Hence he said “rebirth-linking” and so on. The reason for the non-grasping has already been stated in the answer to the verse, “Leaving the pool, the homeless one” .

original: gāthāya vissajjane. Kammanimittādivasena paṭisandhiyā paccayabhūtaṃ ārammaṇaṃ paṭisandhijanakassa
analyzed: gāthāya vissajjane kamma nimitta ādi vasena paṭisandhiyā paccaya bhūtam ārammaṇam paṭisandhi janakassa
translated: The object that is a condition for the rebirth-linking by way of the sign of kamma, and so on, is cut off by the kamma that generates the rebirth-linking.

original: kammassa vasena vocchijjati. Patiṭṭhā na hoti sarāgakāle viya anupaṭṭhānato. Appatiṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: kammassa vasena vā ucchijjati patiṭṭhā na hoti sa rāga kāle viya an upaṭṭhānataḥ appatiṭṭhitam
translated: There is no establishment, like the time of lust, because of non-occurrence.🔽The consciousness that is not established

original: viññāṇaṃ vuttappakārena. Anabhisaṅkharitvāti anuppādetvā paccayaghātena.🔽Upayasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: viññāṇam vutta ppakārena an abhisaṅkharitvā ati an uppādetvā paccaya ghātena  upaya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: does not arise in the way stated, by the destruction of conditions without causing any more kamma.🔽The commentary on the Upaya Sutta is finished.

original: 2. Bījasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bīja sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Bīja Sutta is finished.

original: 54. Bījajātānīti jāta-saddo padapūraṇamattanti āha “bījānī”ti. Vacanti setavacaṃ.
analyzed: bīja jātāni iti āha bījāni iti vacanti
translated: They are ‘white’ because they are white in colour.

original: Ajjukanti tacchakaṃ. Phaṇijjakaṃ tulasi. Abhinnānīti ekadesenapi akhaṇḍitāni. Bījatthāyāti
analyzed: ajjukanti tad śakam phaṇijjakam tulasi abhinnāni iti ekadesena api akhaṇḍitāni bīja atthāya ati
translated: ‘Fresh’ means not dried up. ‘Pheṇijjaka’ is a kind of grass. ‘Unbroken’ means not split up even in one place. ‘For the purpose of seed’

original: bījakiccāya. Na upakappatīti paccayo na hotīti dasseti. Na pāpitānīti pūtitaṃ na
analyzed: bīja kiccāya na upakappati iti paccayaḥ na hoti iti dasseti na pāpitāni iti pūtitam na
translated: means for the purpose of the function of seed. ‘Does not serve’ shows that it is not a condition. ‘Not rotten’ means not gone to putrefaction.

original: upagatāni. Taṇḍulasārassa ādānato sārādāni. Ārammaṇaggahaṇavasena viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhati
analyzed: upagatāni taṇḍula sārassa ādānato sāra ādāni ārammaṇa ggahaṇa vasena viññāṇam tiṭṭhati
translated: ‘With kernel’ because of the taking up of the kernel of the rice. ‘Consciousness stands’ by way of apprehending the object.

original: etthāti viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo. Ārammaṇavasenāti ārammaṇabhāvavasena. Sinehanaṭṭhenāti taṇhāyanavasena
analyzed: ettha ati viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyo ārammaṇa vasena ati ārammaṇa bhāva vasena sinehana ṭṭhena ati taṇhāyana vasena
translated: ‘Bases for consciousness’ . ‘By way of object’ means by way of being an object. ‘By way of what is clung to’ means by way of what is clung to as craving.

original: siniddhatāpādanena, yato “nandūpasecana”nti vuttaṃ. Tathā hi viropitaṃ taṃ kammaviññāṇaṃ🔽paṭisandhiaṅkuruppādanasamatthaṃ hoti. Sappaccayanti avijjāayonisonamanasikārādipaccayehi
analyzed: siniddha tā āpādanena yatas nandu upasecanam ti vuttam tathā hi viropitam tam kamma viññāṇam  paṭisandhi aṅkura uppādana samattham hoti sa paccayanti avijjā ayonisona manasikāra ādi paccayehi
translated: ‘By way of what is moistened’ means by way of what is made sticky by craving, since it is said ‘watered by relishing’ . For thus the kamma-consciousness that has been sown🔽becomes capable of producing the sprout of rebirth-linking. ‘With conditions’ means with conditions such as ignorance, craving, and attention.

original: sappaccayaṃ. Viruhati vipākasantānuppādanasamattho hutvā.🔽Bījasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sa paccayam viruhati vipāka santāna uppādana samatthaḥ hutvā 🔽bīja sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: ‘It grows’ means that it becomes capable of producing the continuity of the result.

original: 3. Udānasuttavaṇṇanā🔽55. Udānaṃ udāharīti attamanavācaṃ nicchāresi. Esa vuttappakāro udāhāro. Bhuso nissayo
analyzed: udāna sutta vaṇṇanā  udānam udāhari iti atta mana vācam nicchāresi esa vutta ppakāraḥ udāhāraḥ bhusaḥ nissayo
translated: 3. The Sutta on Exultations🔽He uttered an exultation: he uttered a speech of exultation. This is the kind of exultation.

original: upanissayo, dānameva upanissayo dānūpanissayo. Esa nayo sesesupi. Tattha dānūpanissayo🔽annādivatthūsu balavāti balavabhāvena hoti, tasmā upanissayabahulo kāmarāgappahāneneva🔽kataparicayattā vipassanamanuyuñjanto na cirasseva anāgāmiphalaṃ pāpuṇāti, tathā🔽suvisuddhasīlūpanissayo kāmadosajigucchanena. Yadi evaṃ kasmā ime dve upanissayā🔽dubbalāti vuttā? Vijjūpamaññāṇasseva paccayabhāvato. Sopi bhāvanūpanissayasahāyalābheneva,🔽na kevalaṃ. Bhāvanā pana paṭivedhassa visesahetubhāvato balavā upanissayo. Tathā
analyzed: upanissayaḥ dānam eva upanissayaḥ dāna upanissayo esa nayo sesesu pi tattha dāna upanissayo  anna ādi vatthūsu balavā ati balava bhāvena hoti tasmai upanissaya bahulaḥ kāma rāga ppahānena iva  kata paricaya ttā vipassanam anuyuñjantaḥ na cirassa iva anāgāmi phalam pāpuṇāti tathā  kāma dosa jigucchanena yadi evam kasmai ime dve upanissayā  dubbalā ti vuttā vijju upama ññāṇassa iva paccaya bhāvato saḥ api bhāvanā upanissaya sahāya lābhena iva  na kevalam bhāvanā pana paṭivedhassa visesa hetu bhāvataḥ balavā upanissayaḥ tathā
translated: The support is the strong support.

original: hi sā vajirūpamañāṇassa visesapaccayo. Tenāha “bhāvanūpanissayo arahattaṃ pāpetī”ti.
analyzed: hi sā vaji rūpama ñāṇassa visesa paccayo tena āha bhāvanā upa nissayaḥ arahattam pāpeti iti

original: Soti milakatthero. Vihāranti vasanaṭṭhānaṃ. Vihārapaccante hi paṇṇasālāya thero viharati.
analyzed: saḥ ti milaka theraḥ vihāranti vasana ṭṭhānam vihāra paccante hi paṇṇasālāya theraḥ viharati
translated: So: the Elder Milaka. In a monastery: in a dwelling-place. For the elder was living in a leaf hut at the edge of the monastery.

original: Upaṭṭhāti ekalakkhaṇena. Kūṭagoṇo viya gamanavīthiṃ. Tatthāti allakaṭṭharāsimhi.
analyzed: eka lakkhaṇena kūṭa goṇaḥ viya gamana vīthim tattha ati alla kaṭṭha rāsimhi
translated: He attended on him by means of the single characteristic of going, like a bull with a goad in his ear. There: in the pile of wet timber.

original: Udakamaṇikānanti udakathevānaṃ.
analyzed: udaka maṇi kānanti
translated: Water-carrying vessels: water-carrying pots.

original: Attaniyeva upanesi udānakathāya vuttadhammānaṃ paripuṇṇānaṃ attani saṃvijjamānattā.
analyzed: attaniyā iva upanesi udāna kathāya vutta dhammānam paripuṇṇānam attani saṃvijjamāna ttā
translated: He applied himself to them in himself because the things stated in the Udana were fulfilled in him.

original: Tenāha “uṭṭhānavatā”tiādi. Ayañhi milakatthero sikkhāya gāravo sappatisso vattapaṭivattaṃ
analyzed: tena āha uṭṭhānavatā atiādi ayam hi milaka theraḥ sikkhāya gāravaḥ sa patissaḥ vatta paṭivattam
translated: Hence he said “He was energetic” and so on. For this elder Milaka, who was respectful and reverential towards the training,🔽who was living with purified virtue, fulfilling the duties of deference and respect,

original: pūrento visuddhasīlo hutvā ṭhito, tasmā “dubbalūpanissaye”ti vuttaṃ. Tenāha bhagavā🔽udānento “no cassaṃ…pe… saññojanānī”ti.🔽Sace ahaṃ na bhaveyyanti yadi ahaṃ nāma koci na bhaveyyaṃ tādisassa ahaṃsaddavacanīyassa
analyzed: pūrentaḥ visuddha sīlaḥ hutvā ṭhitaḥ tasmā dubbala upanissayā iti vuttam tena āha bhagavā  udānentaḥ no saññojanāni iti  sace aham na bhaveyya iti yadi aham nāma koci na bhaveyyam tādisassa ahaṃsadda vacanīyassa
translated: was said to have “weak support.” Hence the Blessed One,🔽declaring him in the Udana, said: “If I were not, no one would be” ,🔽“If I, who am called by the name ‘I,’ were not, then no one would be, because of the non-existence of any such thing as that called ‘I.’

original: kassaci atthassa abhāvato. Tato eva mama parikkhāropi na bhaveyyatassa ca pabhaṅgubhāvena
analyzed: kassaci atthassa abhāvataḥ tatas eva mama parikkhāraḥ api na ca pabhaṅgu bhāvena
translated: And then my requisites would not be, because of the non-existence of the one who would use them. And then the requisites of others would not be, because of the non-existence of the one who would use them. And then the requisites of others would not be, because of the non-existence of the one who would use them.
