translated: “the water’s film” : the water’s skin that remains in continuity. For that is collected and then the water is made into a skin. In that skin there is what is called a bubble. “The physical basis”

original: puṭaṃ karoti, tasmiṃ puṭe pubbuḷasamaññā. Vatthunti cakkhādivatthuṃ. Ārammaṇanti
analyzed: puṭam karoti tasmin puṭe pubbuḷa samaññāḥ vatthum ti cakkha ādi vatthum ārammaṇanti
translated: is the eye-sensitivity, etc. “The object”

original: rūpādiārammaṇaṃ. Kilesajallanti purimasiddhaṃ, paṭilabbhamānaṃ vā kilesamalaṃ. Phassasaṅghaṭṭananti
analyzed: rūpa ādi ārammaṇam kilesajallanti purima siddham paṭilabbhamānam vā kilesa malam phassa saṅghaṭṭananti
translated: is the visible-data, etc. “The film of defilement” is the stain of defilement that is already accomplished or is being obtained. “The impact of contact”🔽is the impact of the contact that arises in the eye, etc.

original: phassasamodhānaṃ. Pubbuḷasadisā muhuttaramaṇīyatāya. Yasmā ghammakāle sūriyātapasantāpābhinibbattarasmijālanipāte
analyzed: phassa samodhānam pubbuḷasa disā muhutta ramaṇīya tāya yasmai ghamma kāle
translated: When the sun’s rays fall on a hot place in summer, a mirage appears there.

original: tādise bhūmipadese ito cito samuggatavātavegasamuddhaṭaviruḷhasaṅkhātesu paribbhamantesu🔽aṇuparamāṇutajjārippakāresu bhūtasaṅghātesu marīcisamaññā, tasmā sabbaso sāravirahitāti
analyzed: tādise bhūmi padese itas citas samuggata vāta vega samuddhaṭa viruḍha saṅkhātesu paribbhamantesu  aṇu paramāṇu tajja ari ppakāresu bhūta saṅghātesu marīci samaññā tasmā sabbaso sāra virahitā ati
translated: When the particles of dust in the air are stirred up by the force of the wind blowing here and there,🔽the mass of elements, which is the finest dust, appears as a mirage.🔽Therefore it is said that perception is like a mirage because of its lack of any core.

original: vuttaṃ “saññāpi asārakaṭṭhena marīcisadisā”ti. Yasmā ca passantānaṃ yebhuyyena udakākārena
analyzed: vuttam saññā api asārakaṭṭhena marīci sadisā ti yasmā ca passantānam yebhuyyena udaka ākārena
translated: And because it appears to the seeing as water,🔽it is said that “one might take it up and drink it.”

original: khāyati, tasmā “gahetvā pivituṃ vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Nīlādianubhavanatthāyāti nīlādiārammaṇassa
analyzed: khāyati tasmai gahetvā pivitum vā tiādi vuttam nīla ādi anubhavana tthāya ati nīla ādi ārammaṇassa
translated: For the purpose of experiencing blue, etc.,

original: anubhavanatthāya. Phandatīti phandanākārappattā viya hoti appahīnataṇhassa puggalassa.
analyzed: anubhavana tthāya phandati iti phandana ākāra ppattā viya hoti appahīna taṇhassa puggalassa
translated: means for the purpose of experiencing an object such as blue. It shimmers means it is as if it has reached the state of shimmering for a person whose craving has not been eliminated.

original: Vippalambheti appahīnavipallāsaṃ puggalaṃ. Tenāha “idaṃ nīlaka”ntiādi. Saññāvipallāsato
analyzed: vippalambha iti appahīna vipallāsam puggalam tena āha idam nīla kanti ādi saññā vipallāsato
translated: It is distorted means it is a person whose perversion has not been eliminated. Hence he says, “This is blue,” etc.

original: hi cittavipallāso, tato diṭṭhivipallāsoti. Vippalambhanenāti vippakāravaseneva ārammaṇassa
analyzed: hi citta vipallāso tatas diṭṭhi vipallāso ti vippalambhanena ati vippakāra vasena iva ārammaṇassa
translated: and then the perversion of view. By perversion: by the mere perversion of the object.

original: lambhanena. Vippakāravasena hi etaṃ lambhanaṃ, yadidaṃ anudakameva udakaṃ katvā dassanaṃ
analyzed: lambhanena vippakāra vasena hi etam lambhanam yat idam anudakam eva udakam katvā dassanam
translated: and then the perversion of view. ‘By the perversion of perception’: by the perversion of the object. For this is a perversion in the sense of a perversion of the object, since it shows water that is not water,

original: anagarameva nagaraṃ katvā gandhabbanāṭakādidassanaṃ.🔽Kukkukaṃ vuccati kadalikkhandhassa sabbapattavaṭṭīnaṃ abbhantare daṇḍakanti āha “akukkukajātanti🔽anto asañjātaghanadaṇḍaka”nti. Na tathā hotīti yadatthāya upanītaṃ, tadatthāya na🔽hoti. Nānālakkhaṇoti nānāsabhāvo. Saṅkhārakkhandhovāti eko saṅkhārakkhandhotveva vuccati.
analyzed: anagaram eva nagaram katvā gandhabba nāṭaka ādi dassanam  kukkukam vuccati kadali kkhandhassa sabba patta vaṭṭīnam abbhantare daṇḍakan ti āha a kukkuka jātan ti  na tathā na  hoti nānā lakkhaṇo ti nānā sabhāvo saṅkhāra kkhandho vā ati ekaḥ saṅkhāra kkhandho tu eva vuccati
translated: a city that is not a city, and so on, by showing a mirage as water, a termite-hill as a city, and so on.

original: Assāti purisassa. Apagatapaṭalapiḷakanti apagatapaṭaladosañceva apagatapiḷakadosañca.🔽Asārabhāvadassanasamatthanti asārassa asārabhāvadassanasamatthaṃ. Ittarāti parittakālā,
analyzed: assa ati purisassa apagata paṭala piḷakanti apagata paṭala dosam ca iva apagata piḷaka dosam ca 🔽asāra bhāva dassana samatthanti asārassa asāra bhāva dassana samattham ittarā ti paritta kālā
translated: ‘Not a bamboo’ is a kind of plantain trunk. The meaning is: ‘without a hard core in the middle.’ ‘It is not as it is supposed to be’ is not what it is supposed to be for the purpose for which it is brought. ‘Of various characteristics’: of various natures. ‘A mere aggregate of formations’: it is called ‘a mere aggregate of formations’ as one thing.

original: na ciraṭṭhitikā. Tenāha “lahupaccupaṭṭhānā”ti. Aññadeva ca āgamanakāle cittanti idañca🔽oḷārikavaseneva vuttaṃ. Tathā hi ekaccharakkhaṇe anekakoṭisatasahassasaṅkhāni cittāni
analyzed: na cira ṭṭhitikā tena āha lahu paccupaṭṭhānā ti aññat eva ca āgamana kāle cittam ti idam ca  oḷārika vasena iva vuttam tathā hi ekaccha rakkhaṇe aneka koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhāni cittāni
translated: and they do not last long. Hence it was said above, “They are easy to discern” .🔽And the mind that comes in at the time of arrival is different from the mind that goes out at the time of departure.🔽🔽This is said merely as a gross classification. For in one thought-moment there are many hundred thousand koṭis of kinds of consciousness.

original: uppajjitvā nirujjhanti. Māyāya dassitaṃ rūpaṃ māyāti vuttaṃ. Yaṃkiñcideva kapāliṭṭhakapāsāṇavālikādiṃ.🔽Vañcetīti asuvaṇṇameva suvaṇṇanti, amuttameva muttātiādinā vañceti. Nanu ca saññāpi🔽marīci viya vippalambheti vañceti, idampi viññāṇaṃ māyā viya vañcetīti ko imesaṃ🔽visesoti? Vacanattho nesaṃ sādhāraṇo. Tathāpi saññā anudakaṃyeva udakaṃ katvā gāhāpentī,
analyzed: uppajjitvā nirujjhanti māyāya dassitam rūpam māyā iti vuttam yaṃ kiñcid eva kapāliṭṭha kapāsāṇa vālikā ādiṃ  vañceti iti a suvaṇṇam eva suvaṇṇam ti amuttam eva muttā ati ādinā vañceti nanu ca saññā api  marīci viya vippalambheti vañceti idam pi viññāṇam māyā viya vañceti iti ko imesam  visesaḥ ti vacana atthaḥ na isam sādhāraṇaḥ tathā api saññā anudakam yā iva udakam katvā gāhāpentī
translated: and they do not last long. Hence ‘readily apparent’ is said. And it is said in this way only as a gross distinguishing mark. For in a single thought-moment many hundred thousand koṭis of thoughts arise and cease. The form shown by the conjuring trick is called ‘a conjuring trick.’ Whatever there is of skull-bones, potsherds, sand, etc., is called ‘a mechanical contrivance.’🔽‘Deceives’: it deceives by making what is not gold appear as gold, what is not a pearl appear as a pearl, and so on. But does not perception, like a mirage, deceive by misrepresenting what is not water as water? And does not this consciousness, like a conjuring trick, deceive by misrepresenting what is not as what is? What is the difference between them?

original: apurisaññeva purisaṃ katvā gāhāpentī vippalambhanavasena appavisayā, viññāṇaṃ pana
analyzed: a purisaññā iva purisam katvā gāhāpentī vippalambhana vasena appa visayā viññāṇam pana
translated: The meaning of the words is common to all. Still, perception, by misrepresenting, makes one apprehend what is not water as water, what is not a man as a man, and so on, and so its field is limited. But consciousness, by misrepresenting, makes one apprehend what is not gold as gold, what is not a pearl as a pearl, and so on, and so its field is unlimited.

original: yaṃ kiñci ataṃsabhāvaṃ taṃ katvā dassentī māyā viya mahāvisayā. Tenāha “yaṃkiñcidevā”tiādi.
analyzed: yam kiñci a taṃsa bhāvam tam katvā dassentī māyā viya mahā visayā tena āha yam kiñcid eva atiādi
translated: and it is like a magic trick in that it shows what is not there as if it were there. Hence he said “whatever it may be” and so on.

original: Evampīti ativiya lahuparivattibhāvenapi māyāsadisanti.
analyzed: evam pi iti
translated: In this way too: in that it is like a magic trick in the way it turns up very quickly.

original: Desitāti evaṃ desitā pheṇapiṇḍādiupamāhi.
analyzed: desitā ati evam desitā pheṇa piṇḍa ādi upamā hi
translated: Thus taught: thus taught by means of the similes of the lump of foam, etc.

original: Bhūri vuccati pathavī, saṇhaṭṭhena vipulaṭṭhena ca bhūrisadisapaññatāya bhūripañño.
analyzed: bhūri vuccati pathavī saṇha aṭṭhena vipula aṭṭhena ca bhūri sadisa paññatāya bhūri pañño
translated: Earth is called “bhūri” in the sense of “saṇha” and in the sense of “vipula” . The wise man is like the earth in that he is designated as bhūripañña because he is like bhūri.

original: Tenāha “saṇhapaññena cevā”tiādi. Kimigaṇādīnanti ādi-saddena anekagijjhādike saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: tena āha saṇha paññena ca iva atiādi ādi saddena aneka gijjha ādike saṅgaṇhāti
translated: Hence he said “and the wise man” and so on. Kimigaṇādīnaṃ means the many kinds of deer, etc.

original: Paveṇīti dhammapabandho. Bālalāpinī “ahaṃ mamā”tiādinā. Sesadhātuyo gahetvāva bhijjati
analyzed: paveṇī iti dhamma pabandhaḥ bāla lāpinī aham mama ati ādinā sesa dhātuyaḥ gahetvā ava bhijjati
translated: Paveṇī means the continuity of the Dhamma. Bālalāpinī means “I am mine” and so on. The other elements are included in the taking up of the material form aggregate.

original: ekuppādekanirodhattā, vatthurūpanissayapaccayattā “aya”nti na visuṃ gahitaṃ. Vadhabhāvatoti
analyzed: eka uppāda eka nirodha ttā vatthu rūpa nissaya paccaya ttā ayanti na visum gahitam vadha bhāvato ti
translated: It is not separately mentioned as “this” because it is subject to arising and ceasing together, and because it is the physical basis, the object, and the condition.

original: vadhassa maraṇassa atthibhāvato. Saraṇanti paṭisaraṇaṃ.🔽Pheṇapiṇḍūpamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vadhassa maraṇassa atthi bhāvato saraṇanti paṭisaraṇam  pheṇa piṇḍūpama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Because of the existence of killing: because of the existence of killing, of death.🔽Refuge: a place of refuge.🔽The commentary on the Lump of Foam Simile is finished.

original: 4-6. Gomayapiṇḍasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: gomaya piṇḍa sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Simile of the Dung-Beetle, etc.

original: 96-98. Sassataṃ sabbakālaṃ yāva kappavuṭṭhānā hontīti sassatiyo, sineruādayo. Tāhi
analyzed: sassatam sabbakālam yāva kappa vuṭṭhānāḥ honti iti sassatiyaḥ sineru ādayo tāhi
translated: They are eternalists because they exist for all time until the end of the aeon.

original: samaṃ samakālaṃ. Anenāti bhagavatā. Nayidanti ettha ya-kāro padasandhikaro, idanti
analyzed: samam sama kālam anena ati bhagavatā ettha yakāro pada sandhi karaḥ
translated: At the same time, with that: with the Blessed One.🔽This way: the word ya is a connector. The word idha is a particle. But it takes the gender of whatever it is related to.

original: nipātapadaṃ. Taṃ pana yena yena sambandhīyati, taṃ tiliṅgova hotīti “ayaṃ maggabrahmacariyavāso”ti🔽vuttaṃ. “Na paññāyeyyā”ti vatvā tamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “maggo hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Vivaṭṭentoti
analyzed: nipāta padam tam pana yena yena tam hoti iti ayam magga brahmacariya vāsā iti  vuttam na paññāyeyya iti vatvā tam attham vivaritum maggaḥ hi itiādi vuttam vivaṭṭento ti
translated: Therefore it is said, “This way of life is the life of purity.”🔽In order to explain the meaning of “would not be known,” it is said, “For the way,” etc.

original: vinivaṭṭento appavattiṃ karonto.
analyzed: vinivaṭṭentaḥ appavattim karontaḥ
translated: He would not be able to turn it back: he would not be able to stop it from turning.🔽Royal capital: the city where the king lives.

original: Rājadhānīti rañño nivāsanagaraṃ. Suttamayanti cittavaṇṇavaṭṭikāmayaṃ.
analyzed: rājadhānī iti raññaḥ nivāsa nagaram suttamayanti citta vaṇṇa vaṭṭikā mayam
translated: Made of thread: made of coloured threads.

original: Gomayapiṇḍasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gomaya piṇḍa sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Gomayapiṇḍa Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Gaddulabaddhasuttavaṇṇanā🔽99. Yaṃ mahāsamuddoti ettha yanti samayassa paccāmasanaṃ. Bhummatthe cetaṃ paccattavacananti
analyzed: gaddulabaddha sutta vaṇṇanā  yam mahā samuddaḥ ti ettha yanti samayassa paccāmasanam bhumma atthe ca itam paccatta vacanam ti
translated: The Gaddulabaddha Sutta🔽Here the word ya is a sign of the past. The word bhumma is a pronoun.

original: āha “yasmiṃ samaye”ti. So ca samayo ayanti dassento “pañcame sūriye uṭṭhite”ti āha.
analyzed: āha yasmin samaye iti so ca samayaḥ ayanti dassento pañcame sūriye uṭṭhitā iti āha
translated: Therefore it is said, “At the time.” And showing that that time is past, he says, “When the fifth sun has arisen.”

original: Paricchedaṃ na vadāmi paricchedakārikāya aggamaggavijjāya anadhigatattā. Sunakho
analyzed: paricchedam na vadāmi pariccheda kārikāya agga magga vijjāya an adhigata ttā sunakho
translated: I do not say there is a limit to it because I have not discovered the supreme path of knowledge that would set a limit to it.

original: viya vaṭṭanissito bālo asavasabhāvato. Gaddulo viya diṭṭhibandho. Sakkāyo tassa asavasabhāvato.🔽Puthujjanassa sakkāyānuparivattananti “santāne sattavohāro”ti taṃ tato aññaṃ katvā bhedena niddeso.🔽Gaddulabaddhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽8. Dutiyagaddulabaddhasuttavaṇṇanā🔽100. Diṭṭhigaddulanissitāyāti sahajātādipaccayavasena diṭṭhigaddulanissitāya nissāyeva🔽pavattati tato attānaṃ vivecetuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā. Cittasaṃkilesenevāti dasavidhakilesavatthuvasena
analyzed: viya vaṭṭa nissitaḥ bālaḥ asavasa bhāvataḥ gaddulaḥ viya diṭṭhibandho sakkāyo tassa asavasa bhāvataḥ  puthujjanassa sakkāya anuparivattananti santāne satta vohāro ti tam tatas aññam katvā bhedena niddeso  gaddulabaddha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  dutiya gaddulabaddha sutta vaṇṇanā  diṭṭhi gaddula nissitāya ti sahajāta ādi paccaya vasena diṭṭhi gaddula nissitāya nissāya iva  pavattati tatas attānam vivecetum citta saṃkilesena iva ati dasavidha kilesa vatthu vasena
translated: The fool is “tethered by the round” like the ox by the post because of the round of existence. The fetter of views is “the tether” because of the nature of the defilements. The selfhood is “the ox” because of the nature of the defilements.

original: cittassa saṃkiliṭṭhabhāvena. Ariyamaggādhigamanena cittassa vodānattā vodāyanti visujjhanti.
analyzed: cittassa saṃkiliṭṭha bhāvena ariya magga adhigamanena cittassa vodānattāḥ vodāyanti visujjhanti
translated: The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebirths. The fool’s selfhood is “tethered by the round” because it revolves in the round of rebir

original: Vicaraṇacittanti gahetvā vicaraṇavasena vicaraṇacittaṃ. Saṅkhānāmāti evaṃnāmakā.
analyzed: vicaraṇa cittam ti gahetvā vicaraṇa vasena vicaraṇa cittam evaṃnāmakā
translated: Taking the thought of investigation as the thought of investigation, he investigates by way of investigation. “The name-group”: those called by such names.

original: Brāhmaṇapāsaṇḍikāti jātiyā brāhmaṇā, channavutiyā pāsaṇḍesu taṃ saṅkhāsaññitaṃ pāsaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇapāsaṇḍikā ati jātiyā brāhmaṇā channavutiyā pāsaṇḍesu tam saṅkhā saññitam pāsaṇḍam
translated: “Brahmin sectarians”: Brahmins by birth, they are sectarians of the ninety-six kinds of sectarians.

original: paggayha vicaraṇakā. Paṭakoṭṭhakanti dussāpaṇakaṃ. Dassentāti yathāgatikammavipākacittataṃ
analyzed: paggayha vicaraṇakā paṭa koṭṭhakam ti dussāpaṇakam dassentā ati yathāgati kamma vipāka citta tam
translated: “They wander about, having gone forth from that”: having gone forth from that sect called Saṅkhā. “A painted cloth”: a cloth for painting. “They show”: they show the state of mind that is the result of kamma according to the way it has been done.

original: dassentā. Taṃ cittanti taṃ paṭakoṭṭhakacittaṃ gahetvā vicaranti. Cintetvā katattāti
analyzed: dassentā tam cittam ti tam paṭakoṭṭhaka cittam gahetvā vicaranti cintetvā katattā ati
translated: “They wander about, taking that thought as the thought”: taking that thought of the painted cloth, they wander about. “What is done by thinking”:

original: “imassa rūpassa evaṃ hatthapādā, evaṃ mukhaṃ likhitabbaṃ, evaṃ ākāravatthaggahaṇāni,
analyzed: imassa rūpassa evam hattha pādāḥ evam mukham likhitabbam evam ākāra vattha ggahaṇāni
translated: “The hand and foot of this form should be drawn like this, the face like this, the grasping of the characteristics like this,

original: evaṃ kiriyāvisesā, evaṃ kiriyāvibhāgaṃ, sattavisesānaṃ vibhāgaṃ kātabba”nti tassa🔽ubbattanakhipanapavattanādipayojanañcāti sabbametaṃ tathā cintetvā katattā cittena
analyzed: evam kiriyā visesāḥ evam kiriyā vibhāgam satta visesānam vibhāgam kātabbanti tassa  ubbattana khipana pavattana ādi payojanam ca ati sabbam etam tathā cintetvā katattā cittena
translated: the special actions like this, the classification of the actions like this, the classification of the seven special qualities should be done like this,”🔽and the purpose of the raising, lowering, and turning round, etc., of that

original: manasā cintitaṃ nāma. Upāyapariyesanacittanti “hatthapādā evaṃ likhitabbā”tiādinā
analyzed: manasā cintitam nāma upāya pariyesana cittanti hattha pādāḥ evam likhitabbā iti ādinā
translated: all this is done by thinking thus. Therefore it is called “what is done by thinking” with the mind, with the thought. “The thought of seeking a means”: “The hand and foot should be drawn like this,” etc.,

original: yathāvuttaupāyassa ceva pubbe pavattassa bhūmiparikammavaṇṇadhātusammāyojanupāyassa🔽ca vasena pavattaṃ cittaṃ. Tatopi cittataranti tato cittakammatopi cittataraṃ cittakārena
analyzed: yathā vutta upāyassa ca iva pubbe pavattassa bhūmi parikamma vaṇṇa dhātu sammā yojana upāyassa  ca vasena pavattam cittam tatas pi cittataranti tatas citta kammataḥ pi cittataram citta kārena
translated: and by the means stated and by the means that occurred previously in the form of the preliminary work, the earth kasiṇa, the colour kasiṇa, and the right direction,🔽the mind is more refined than that. And by that, too, it is more refined than the mind of one who has only the meditation subject, because of the non-fulfilment of all the kinds of meditation subject that can be fulfilled by one who has a meditation subject.

original: cintitappakārānaṃ sabbesaṃyeva cittakamme anipphajjanato. Kammacittenāti kammaviññāṇena.
analyzed: cintita ppakārānam sabbesam yeva citta kamme a nipphajjanato kamma cittena ati kamma viññāṇena
translated: By the mind of kamma: by the consciousness of kamma.

original: Kammacittenāti vā kammassa cittabhāvena. So kammassa vicittabhāvo taṇhāvasena jāyatīti
analyzed: kamma cittena ati vā kammassa citta bhāvena saḥ kammassa vicitta bhāvaḥ taṇhā vasena jāyati iti
translated: Or alternatively, by the mind of kamma means by the state of mind of kamma. And that variety of kamma should be understood to arise by means of craving.🔽This meaning is analysed in the Paṭisambhidā commentary.

original: veditabbo. Svāyamattho aṭṭhasālinīṭīkāyaṃ vibhāvito. Evaṃ cittāti evaṃ cittarūpavisesā.🔽Yoniṃ upanetīti taṃ taṃ aṇḍajādibhedaṃ yonivisesaṃ pāpeti vaṇṇaviseso viya phalikamaṇikaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ su ayam attho aṭṭhasālinī ṭīkāyam vibhāvito evam cittā ati evam citta rūpa visesā  yonim upaneti iti tam tam aṇḍaja ādi bhedam yoni visesam vaṇṇa visesaḥ viya phalika maṇikam
translated: Thus: “Thus” : thus with the particular kind of mind and matter.🔽It leads to a destiny: it leads to a particular kind of destiny, which is of the kinds consisting of the egg-born, etc., as a particular colour leads a crystal.

original: Na hi visesā hitavicittasāmatthiyakammaṃ yoniṃ upaneti, tassa tassa vipākuppattiyā
analyzed: na hi visesāḥ hita vicitta sāmatthiya kammam yonim upaneti tassa tassa vipāka uppattiyā
translated: For it is not a kamma that is not a condition for the various kinds of destiny that leads to a destiny, but rather it is a kamma that is a condition for the occurrence of a particular kind of result.

original: paccayo hoti. Yonimūlako tesaṃ cittabhāvoti yaṃ yaṃ yoniṃ kammaṃ satte upaneti, taṃtaṃyonimūlako
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti yoni mūlako tesam citta bhāvo ti yam yam yonim kammam satte upaneti taṃ taṃ yoni mūlako
translated: and is the cause of the variety of their consciousness. The variety of their consciousness is rooted in the kind of rebirth-linking they have,

original: tesaṃ sattānaṃ cittavicittabhāvo. Tenāha “yoniupagatā”tiādi. Sadisacittāva sadisacittabhāvā
analyzed: tesam sattānam tena āha yoni upagata atiādi sadisa cittā ava sadisa citta bhāvā
translated: for the kind of rebirth-linking that kamma produces is the root of the variety of consciousness of those beings. Hence it is said, “According to the kind of rebirth-linking they have” and so on. The variety of consciousness is the same as the variety of consciousnesses.

original: eva. Itītiādi vuttasseva atthassa uppaṭipāṭiyā nigamanaṃ.🔽Tiracchānagatacittabhāvato cittasseva savisesaṃ cittabhāvakaraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha cittaṃ nāmetaṃ cittatarameva veditabbanti sambandho. Sahajātadhammacittatāyāti
analyzed: eva iti itiādi vuttassa iva atthassa uppaṭipāṭiyā nigamanam  tiracchāna gata citta bhāvataḥ cittassa iva sa visesam citta bhāva karaṇam dassetum apica atiādi  vuttam tattha cittam nāma etam cittataram eva veditabban ti sambandhaḥ sahajāta dhamma citta tāya ati
translated: The words “in this way” and so on are a recapitulation of the meaning already stated.🔽In order to show that it is consciousness itself that is the cause of the variety of consciousness, with its special qualities, the text says, “Moreover, etc.” Here the construction is: “This consciousness should be understood as the most conscious.”

original: rāgādisaddhādidhammavicittabhāvena. Bhūmicittatāyāti adhiṭṭhānacittatāya. Kammanānattaṃ
analyzed: rāga ādi saddhā ādi dhamma vicitta bhāvena bhūmi citta tāya ati adhiṭṭhāna citta tāya kamma nānattam
translated: The variety of consciousness due to the variety of states associated with it is the variety of consciousness due to the variety of states such as greed, faith, etc., associated with it. The variety of consciousness due to the plane is the variety of consciousness due to the difference in the consciousness of the fine-material and immaterial planes.

original: mūlaṃ kāraṇaṃ etesanti kammanānattamūlakā, tesaṃ. Liṅganānattaṃ itthiliṅgādinānattavasena
analyzed: mūlam kāraṇam tesam liṅga nānattam itthi liṅga ādi nānatta vasena
translated: The variety of consciousness due to the variety of kamma is the variety of consciousness due to the variety of kamma that is its root.🔽The variety of consciousness due to the variety of sex is the variety of consciousness due to the variety of sex as female, etc.

original: ceva taṃtaṃsaṇṭhānanānattavasena ca veditabbaṃ. Saññānānattaṃ itthipurisadevamanussādisaññānānattavasena.
analyzed: ca iva taṃ taṃ saṇṭhāna nānatta vasena ca veditabbam saññā nānattam itthi purisa deva manussa ādi saññā nānatta vasena
translated: and by the variety of their shapes. The variety of perceptions is to be understood as the variety of perceptions of woman, man, god, human, and so on.🔽The variety of verbal expressions is the variety of such verbal expressions as “three,” “four,” and so on.

original: Vohāranānattaṃ tissotiādivohāranānattavasena. Cittānaṃ vicittānaṃ. Taṃtaṃvohāranānattampi
analyzed: vohāra nānattam tissaḥ ti ādi vohāra nānatta vasena cittānam vicittānam taṃ taṃ vohāra nānattam pi
translated: The variety of consciousnesses is the variety of the different kinds of consciousnesses. The variety of verbal expressions is also

original: citteneva paññapīyati. Raṅgajātarūpasamuṭṭhāpanādinā vatthaṃ rañjayatīti rajako,
analyzed: cittena iva paññapīyati raṅga jātarūpa samuṭṭhāpana ādinā vattham rañjayati iti rajako
translated: only demonstrated by consciousness. A dyer dyes a cloth by means of dyes made from turmeric, lac, indigo, and so on.

original: vaṇṇakāro. Puthujjanassa attabhāvasaññitarūpasamuṭṭhāpanatā niyatā ekantikāti puthujjanaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: vaṇṇa kāro puthujjanassa atta bhāva saññita rūpa samuṭṭhāpana tā niyatā ekantikā ati puthujjana ggahaṇam
translated: A painter paints by means of paints made from turmeric, lac, indigo, and so on. The production of materiality that is the sign of a self is fixed and definite for an ordinary man, thus the inclusion of the ordinary man.

original: “Abhirūpaṃ rūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpetī”ti ānetvā sambandho.
analyzed: abhirūpam rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti iti ānetvā sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is to be made thus: “He produces beautiful materiality.”

original: Dutiyagaddulabaddhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya gaddulabaddha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second knotted stick simile is finished.

original: 9. Vāsijaṭasuttavaṇṇanā🔽101. Atthassāti hitassa. Asādhikā “bhāvanānuyogaṃ ananuyuttassā”ti ananuyuttassa
analyzed: vāsijaṭa sutta vaṇṇanā  atthassa ati hitassa asādhikā bhāvanā anuyogam ananuyuttassa ati ananuyuttassa
translated: The commentary on the knotted stick simile🔽“For the good”: for the benefit. “For one who is not devoted to the development of concentration”: because of the statement “for one who is not devoted,”

original: vuttattā. Itarāti sukkapakkhaupamā. Sādhikā bhāvanāyogassa anuyuttattā. Tañhi tassa
analyzed: vutta ttā itarā ati sukkapakkha aupamā sādhikā bhāvanā yogassa anuyutta ttā tat hi tassa
translated: the other is the white-clothed one. “For one who is devoted”: because of devotion to the development of concentration. For that is the cause🔽for the production of the sign of unity.

original: sādhikā veditabbā. Sambhāvanattheti paramatthasambhāvane. Evañhi kaṇhapakkhepi apisaddaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: sādhikā veditabbā sambhāvanā atthā iti paramattha sambhāvane evam hi kaṇha pakkhe pi api sadda ggahaṇam
translated: should be understood as more than that. In the sense of esteeming: in the sense of esteeming the ultimate. For in this way the word “even” is included in the dark side also.

original: samatthitaṃ hoti. Sambhāvanattheti vā parikappanattheti attho. Saṅkhātabbe atthe
analyzed: samatthitam hoti sambhāvana tthe iti vā parikappana tthe iti attho saṅkhātabbe atthe
translated: should be understood as more than that. In the sense of esteeming: in the sense of esteeming in the ultimate sense. For in this way the word “even” is appropriate also in the dark side. Or alternatively, in the sense of esteeming is the same as in the sense of supposing. In the sense of being reckoned:

original: aniyamato vuccamāne saṅkhāto aniyamattho vāsaddo vattabboti “aṭṭha vā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: aniyamataḥ vuccamāne saṅkhātaḥ aniyama atthaḥ vā saddaḥ vattabbaḥ iti aṭṭha vā atiādi vuttam
translated: when a sense is stated without restriction, the word “even” should be used in the sense of unrestricted reckoning. That is why “eight” is said, and so on.

original: Ūnādhikānīti ūnānipi adhikānipi kiñcāpi honti, ekaṃso pana gahetabboti “aṭṭha vā
analyzed: ūna adhikāni iti ūnāni api adhikāni api kiñcā api honti ekaṃso pana gahetabbo ti aṭṭha vā
translated: Even though there may be fewer or more, the one-sided view should be taken. That is why “eight,

original: dasa vā dvādasa vā”ti vuttaṃ. Evaṃ vacanaṃ sandhāya “vacanasiliṭṭhatāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dasa vā dvādasa vā iti vuttam evam vacanam sandhāya vacana siliṭṭha tāya atiādi vuttam
translated: ten, or twelve” is said. The words “because of the manner of expression” and so on are said with reference to this manner of expression.

original: Pādanakhasikhāhi akopanavasena sammā adhisayitāni. Utunti uṇhautuṃ kāyusmāvasena.
analyzed: pāda nakha sikhāhi a kopana vasena adhisayitāni uṇha otum kāyusmā vasena
translated: They are well-reclined in the sense of not being disturbed by the tips of the nails on the feet. Heat: the heat of the hot season by means of the body’s heat.🔽Hence it is said: “heated up.” They are developed: perfumed by the hen-bird’s perfume. By the performance of the three actions:

original: Tenāha “usmīkatānī”ti. Bhāvitānīti kukkuṭavāsanāya vāsitāni. Sammāadhisayanāditividhakiriyākaraṇena
analyzed: tena āha usmīkatāni iti bhāvitāni iti kukkuṭa vāsanāya vāsitāni
translated: by the performance of the three actions of well-reclining, and so on. Having made this heedfulness:

original: imaṃ appamādaṃ katvā. Sotthinā abhinibbhijjitunti anantarāyena tato nikkhamituṃ.
analyzed: imam appamādam katvā sotthinā abhinibbhijjitum ti anantarāyena tatas nikkhamitum
translated: having made this heedfulness. They break out safely: they emerge from there without hindrance.

original: Idāni tamatthaṃ vivaranto “te hī”tiādimāha. Sayampīti aṇḍāni. Pariṇāmanti paripakkaṃ
analyzed: idāni tam attham vivarantaḥ te hi iti ādim āha sayam pi iti aṇḍāni pariṇāmanti paripakkam
translated: Now, in order to explain that meaning, he said “They, too” , etc. “They, too” : the eggs. “Develop” : they become ripe for hatching.

original: bahinikkhamanayoggataṃ.
analyzed: bahi nikkhamana yoggatam
translated: “They break out” : they become fit to come out.

original: Tanti opammasampaṭipādanaṃ. Evanti idāni vuccamānākārena. Atthenāti upameyyatthena.
analyzed: tat ti opamma sampaṭipādanam evam ti idāni vuccamāna ākārena atthena ati upameyyatthena
translated: “That” : the simile. “Thus” : in the way just stated. “In the meaning” : in the sense of the simile.

original: Saṃsanditvā sammā yojetvā. Sampayuttadhammavasena ñāṇassa tikkhādibhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: saṃsanditvā sammā yojetvā sampayutta dhamma vasena ñāṇassa tikkha ādi bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: “Having combined” : having properly united. The sharpness, etc., of knowledge should be understood in terms of the states associated with it.🔽For knowledge is sharp in the sense of being clear and unclouded in its own individual essence; it is pure in the sense of being unmixed with defilements; it is bright in the sense of being unmixed with the murkiness of torpor and drowsiness; it is radiant in the sense of being unmixed with the murkiness of lust, etc.; it is penetrating in the sense of being unmixed with the murkiness of doubt.

original: Ñāṇassa hi sabhāvato satinepakkato ca tikkhabhāvo, samādhivasena sūrabhāvo, saddhāvasena
analyzed: ñāṇassa hi sabhāvataḥ sati nepakkato ca tikkha bhāvaḥ samādhi vasena sūra bhāvaḥ saddhā vasena
translated: The sharpness of knowledge is due to its individual essence and to its being unclouded; its purity is due to concentration; its brightness is due to faith;

original: vippasannabhāvo, vīriyavasena pariṇāmabhāvo. Pariṇāmakāloti balavavipassanākālo.🔽Vaḍḍhitakāloti vuṭṭhānagāminivipassanākālo. Anulomaṭṭhānassa hi vipassanā gahitagabbhā
analyzed: vippasanna bhāvaḥ vīriya vasena pariṇāma bhāvo pariṇāma kālo ti balava vipassanā kālo  vaḍḍhita kālo ti vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā kālo anuloma ṭṭhānassa hi vipassanā gahita gabbhā
translated: its radiance is due to energy; its penetration is due to wisdom. “The time of development” is the time of strong insight.🔽“The time of growth” is the time of insight leading to emergence. For insight is called “grasping the womb” at that time because it has grasped the womb of the path.

original: nāma tadā maggagabbhassa gahitattā. Tajjātikanti tassa vipassanānuyogassa anurūpaṃ.
analyzed: nāma tadā magga gabbhassa gahita ttā tad jātikanti tassa vipassanā anuyogassa anurūpam
translated: “The kind of life” is the kind of life suitable for that practice of insight.

original: Satthāpi gāthāya avijjaṇḍakosaṃ paharati bhindāpeti.
analyzed: satthā api gāthāya avijjaṇḍa kosam paharati bhindāpeti
translated: The Teacher also strikes the egg-shell of ignorance and causes it to break.

original: Olambakasaṅkhātanti olambakasuttasaṅkhātaṃ. Palanti tassa suttassa nāmaṃ. Dhāretvāti🔽dārūnaṃ heyyādijānanatthaṃ upanetvā. Dārūnaṃ gaṇḍaṃ haratīti palagaṇḍoti etena palena
analyzed: olambaka saṅkhātanti olambaka sutta saṅkhātam palanti tassa suttassa nāmam dhāretvā ati  upanetvā heyya ādi jānana attham upanetvā gaṇḍam harati iti etena palena
translated: Called “the hanging-up” : called “the Thread called the Hanging-up” . “ Hanging-up” is the name of that Thread. Having remembered :

original: gaṇḍahāro “palagaṇḍo”ti pacchimapade uttarapadalopena niddesoti dasseti. Gahaṇaṭṭhāneti
analyzed: gaṇḍahāro palagaṇḍo ti pacchima pade uttara pada lopena niddeso ti dasseti gahaṇa ṭṭhāne iti
translated: having brought it for the purpose of knowing the wood’s worth, etc. He removes the wood’s knot, thus he is a “knot-remover” . By this “knot-remover” he shows that the demonstrative “that” is a contraction of the first and last words, namely “that knot-remover” . At the place of grasping :

original: hatthena gahetabbaṭṭhāne. Sammadeva khepīyanti etena kāyaduccaritādīnīti saṅkhepo,🔽tena. Vipassanaṃ anuyuñjantassa puggalasseva divase divase āsavānaṃ parikkhayo idha
analyzed: hatthena gahetabba ṭṭhāne sammad eva khepīyanti etena kāya duccarita ādīni iti saṅkhepaḥ  tena vipassanam anuyuñjantassa puggalassa iva divase divase āsavānam parikkhayaḥ idha
translated: at the place to be grasped with the hand. He should rightly reflect : by this he shows that the contraction is of “body misconduct, etc.” .

original: “vipassanāyānisaṃso”ti adhippeto. Hemantikena karaṇabhūtena. Bhummatthe vā etaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ,
analyzed: vipassanāya anisaṃsaḥ ti adhippetaḥ hemantikena karaṇa bhūtena bhumma tthe vā etam karaṇa vacanam
translated: The “fruit of insight” intended here is the daily wasting of defilements in the case of a person who devotes himself to insight. By the instrumental case “with the winter” . Or this is a verbal noun in the sense of a locative case,

original: hemantiketi attho. Paṭippassambhantīti paṭippassaddhaphalāni honti. Tenāha “pūtikāni bhavantī”ti.
analyzed: hemantika iti attho paṭippassambhanti iti paṭippassaddha phalāni honti tena āha pūtikāni bhavanti iti
translated: the meaning being “in the winter” . They subside : they have their fruit of subsidence. Hence he said “ they become rotten” .

original: Mahāsamuddo viya sāsanaṃ sabhāvagambhīrabhāvato. Nāvā viya yogāvacaro mahoghuttaraṇato.
analyzed: mahā samuddaḥ viya sāsanam sabhāva gambhīra bhāvataḥ nāvā viya yogāvacaraḥ mahā ugha uttaraṇataḥ
translated: The Dispensation is like the ocean in being deep in its own nature. The meditator is like a ship in crossing the great flood.

original: Pariyādānaṃ viyāti parito aparipūraṇaṃ viya. Khajjamānānanti saṅkhādantena viya udakena
analyzed: pariyādānam viyāti paritas a paripūraṇam viya saṅkhādantena viya udakena
translated: Like a complete exhaustion: like a complete emptying. Of the fetters that are being eaten away: of the fetters that are being eaten away as if by water that is eating into them.

original: khepiyamānānaṃ bandhanānaṃ. Tanubhāvoti pariyuṭṭhānuppattiyā asamatthatāya dubbalabhāvo.🔽Vipassanāñāṇapītipāmojjehīti vipassanāñāṇasamuṭṭhitehi pītipāmojjehi. Okkhāyamāne
analyzed: khepiyamānānam bandhanānam tanu bhāvaḥ ti pariyuṭṭhāna uppattiyāḥ asamattha tāya dubbala bhāvaḥ  vipassanā ñāṇa pīti pāmojjehi iti vipassanā ñāṇa samuṭṭhitehi pīti pāmojjehi okkhāyamāne
translated: Weakness: the state of weakness due to the inability to give rise to the hindrances.🔽By the happiness and gladness born of insight knowledge: by the happiness and gladness originated by insight knowledge.

original: pakkhāyamāneti vividhapaṭipattiyā ukkhāyamāne paṭisaṅkhānupassanāya pakkhāyamāne.
analyzed: pakkhāyamāne ti vividha paṭipattiyā ukkhāyamāne paṭisaṅkhā anupassanāya pakkhāyamāne
translated: As it is being lifted up: as it is being lifted up by the various kinds of practice. As it is being lowered down: as it is being lowered down by reflective contemplation.

original: Dubbalatā dīpitā “appakasireneva saṃyojanāni paṭippassambhanti, pūtikāni bhavantī”ti vuttattā.
analyzed: dubbala tā dīpitā appa kasirena iva saṃyojanāni paṭippassambhanti pūtikāni bhavanti iti vutta ttā
translated: Weakness is indicated by the words “the fetters are weakened and fall away with little effort, they become rotten” .

original: Vāsijaṭasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vāsijaṭa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Vāsījaṭa Sutta is finished.

original: 10. Aniccasaññāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anicca saññā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the “Perception of impermanence” sutta

original: 102. Bhāventassāti vipassanāya maggaṃ bhāventassa uppannasaññā. Tenāha – “sabbaṃ
analyzed: bhāventassa ati vipassanāya maggam bhāventassa uppanna saññā tena āha sabbaṃ
translated: “Developing” : the perception that arises in one who is developing the path by insight. Hence it is said: “All formations are impermanent” .

original: kāmarāgaṃ pariyādiyatī”tiādi. Santānetvāti kasanaṭṭhānaṃ sabbaso vitanetvā pattharitvā.🔽Kilesāti upakkilesappabhedā kilesā. Aniccasaññāñāṇenāti aniccasaññāsahagatena ñāṇena.
analyzed: kāma rāgam santānetvā ati kasana ṭṭhānam sabbasas vitanetvā pattharitvā  kilesā ati upakkilesa ppabhedā kilesā anicca saññā ñāṇena ati anicca saññā sahagatena ñāṇena
translated: Having cleared the field: having cleared the field completely, having levelled it.🔽Defilements: defilements classed as stains.🔽With the knowledge of the perception of impermanence: with the knowledge accompanied by the perception of impermanence.🔽The perception of impermanence is like a creeper, like a guide, like a cleanser.

original: Lāyananti lāyanaṃ viya nayanaṃ viya nicchoṭanaṃ viya ca aniccasaññāñāṇaṃ. Iminā atthenāti
analyzed: lāyanam ti lāyanam viya nayanam viya nicchoṭanam viya ca anicca saññā ñāṇam iminā atthena ati
translated: With this meaning:🔽with this meaning of the text quoted above. The simile should be construed thus:

original: iminā yathāvuttena pāḷiyā atthena, upamā saṃsandetabbāti ettha pabbajalāyako viya
analyzed: iminā yathā vuttena pāḷiyā atthena upamā saṃsandetabbā ti ettha pabbaja lāyakaḥ viya
translated: the meditator is like the man who clears the creeper,

original: yogāvacaro. Lāyanādinā tassa tattha katakiccatāya parituṭṭhi viya imassa kilese sabbaso
analyzed: yogāvacaraḥ lāyana ādinā tassa tattha kata kicca tāya parituṭṭhi viya imassa kilese sabbaso
translated: and his satisfaction in the destruction of the defilements by the perception of impermanence is like the man’s satisfaction in the clearing of the field by the clearing of the creeper, etc.

original: chinditvā phalasamāpattisukhena kālassa vītināmanā.🔽Kūṭaṃ gacchantīti pārimantena kūṭaṃ gacchanti. Kūṭaṃ pavisanabhāvenāti kūṭacchiddaṃ
analyzed: chinditvā phala samāpatti sukhena kālassa vīti nāmanā  kūṭam gacchanti iti pārimantena kūṭam gacchanti kūṭam pavisana bhāvena ati kūṭa chiddam
translated: The time is like the time when the man spends his time in the happiness of fruition attainment.🔽They go to the end: they go to the end of the field by the far side.🔽By the manner of entering the end: by the manner of entering the hole in the end.

original: aggena pavisanavasena. Samosaritvāti chidde anupavisanavasena ca āhacca avaṭṭhānena
analyzed: aggena pavisana vasena samosaritvā ati chidde anupavisana vasena ca āhacca avaṭṭhānena
translated: Having come together: having come together by not entering the hole and by standing close.

original: ca samosaritvā ṭhitā. Kūṭaṃ viya aniccasaññā aniccānupassanāvasena avaṭṭhānassa mūlabhāvato.
analyzed: ca samosaritvā ṭhitā kūṭam viya anicca saññā anicca anupassanā vasena avaṭṭhānassa mūla bhāvato
translated: and the rest are built up on it.🔽The four-terraced virtue is like the four gables, because it is the root of the non-overturning of the sign of the beautiful, etc., by the four kinds of overturning, that is, impermanence by the overturning of permanence, suffering by the overturning of pleasure, foulness by the overturning of beauty, and not-self by the overturning of self.

original: Gopānasiyo viya catubhūmakakusalā dhammā aniccasaññāmūlakattā. Kūṭaṃ aggaṃ sabbagopānasīnaṃ
analyzed: gopānasiyaḥ viya catu bhūmaka kusalāḥ dhammāḥ anicca saññā mūlaka ttā kūṭam aggam sabba gopānasīnam
translated: The four-terraced virtue is like the four gables, because it is the root of the four-terraced skill in giving attention to the sign of the beautiful, and so on.🔽The sign of the beautiful is like the peak, because it is the cause of the pre-eminence of the overturning.🔽The sign of the beautiful is the best, the peak, the best of all the gables,🔽because it is the cause of the pre-eminence of the overturning. The same method applies to the sign of the foul, etc.🔽The sign of the beautiful is the best, the peak, the best of all the gables,

original: tathāadhiṭṭhānassa padhānakāraṇattā. Aniccasaññā aggāti etthāpi eseva nayo. Aniccasaññā
analyzed: tathā adhiṭṭhānassa padhāna kāraṇa ttā anicca saññā aggā ti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ anicca saññā
translated: because it is the cause of the pre-eminence of the overturning. The same method applies to the sign of the foul, etc.🔽The sign of the beautiful is the best, the peak, the best of all the gables,

original: lokiyāti idaṃ aniccasaññānupassanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Aniccānupassanāmukhena adhigataariyamagge🔽uppannasaññā aniccasaññāti vattabbataṃ labhatīti “aniccasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā🔽bahulīkatā sabbaṃ kāmarāgaṃ pariyādiyatī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tathā hi dhammasaṅgahe “yasmiṃ
analyzed: lokiyā ti idam anicca saññā anupassanam sandhāya vuttam anicca anupassanā mukhena adhigata ariya magge  uppanna saññā anicca saññā iti vattabbatam labhati iti anicca saññā bhikkhave bhāvitā  bahulīkatā sabbam kāma rāgam pariyādiyati itiādi vuttam tathā hi dhamma saṅgahe yasmin
translated: because it is the cause of the pre-eminence of the overturning. The same method applies to the sign of the foul, etc.🔽The sign of the beautiful is the best, the peak, the best of all the gables,🔽because it is the cause of the pre-eminence of the overturning. The same method applies to the sign of the foul, etc.🔽The sign of the beautiful is the best, the peak, the best of all the gables,🔽because it is the cause of the pre-eminence of the overturning. The same method applies to the sign of the foul, etc.🔽The sign of the beautiful is the best, the peak, the best of all the gables,🔽because it is the cause of the pre-eminence of the overturning. The same method applies to the sign of the foul, etc.

original: samaye lokuttaraṃ saññaṃ bhāvetī”tiādinā saññāpi uddhaṭā. Sabbāsu upamāsūti mūlasantānaupamādīsu
analyzed: samaye lokuttaram saññam bhāveti iti ādinā saññā api uddhaṭā sabbāsu upamāsu iti mūla santāna aupama ādīsu
translated: The sign of the beautiful is the best, the peak, the best of all the gables,🔽because it is the cause of the pre-eminence of the overturning. The same method applies to the sign of the

original: pañcasu upamāsu. Purimāhīti kassakapabbajalāyanaambapiṇḍiupamāhi aniccasaññāya kiccaṃ🔽vuttaṃ mūlasantānakapadālanapabbajalāyanavaṇṭacchedanapadesena aniccasaññāya paṭipakkhapacchedanassa
analyzed: pañcasu upamāsu purima ahi iti anicca saññāya kiccam  vuttam mūla santānaka padālana pabba jalāyana vaṇṭa chedana padesena anicca saññāya paṭipakkha pacchedanassa
translated: In the five similes. The former ones show the function of the perception of impermanence,🔽which is stated in the terms “root,” “trunk,” “foliage,” “branch,” and “shoot,”

original: dassitattā. Pacchimāhi balaṃ dassitaṃ paṭipakkhātibhāvassa jotitattā.
analyzed: dassita ttā pacchimāhi balam dassitam paṭipakkha atibhāvassa jotita ttā
translated: because it is shown that the perception of impermanence cuts off its opposite. The latter ones show the strength of the perception of impermanence, because it is shown that it overcomes its opposite.

original: Aniccasaññāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: anicca saññā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Sutta on the Perception of Impermanence is ended.

original: Pupphavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: puppha vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Exposition of the Flower-Collection is ended.

original: Majjhimapaṇṇāsako samatto.🔽11. Antavaggo
analyzed: majjhima paṇṇāsakaḥ samatto  anta vaggaḥ
translated: The Middle Fifty is finished.🔽The Chapter on the End

original: 1. Antasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on the End

original: 103. Aññamaññaṃ asaṃsaṭṭhabhāvena eti gacchatīti anto, bhāgoti āha “antāti koṭṭhāsā”ti.
analyzed: aññam aññam a saṃsaṭṭha bhāvena eti gacchati iti antaḥ bhāgaḥ iti āha anta ati koṭṭhāsā iti
translated: The end is that which goes, which moves, by way of non-association with each other. The word bhāga is said to mean “part.”

original: “Sakkāyanirodhanto”ti nirodhapaccayassa gahitattā vuttaṃ “catusaccavasena pañcakkhandhe🔽yojetvā”ti. Antoti…pe… ajjhāsayavasena vuttaṃ yathānulomadesanattā suttantadesanāya.
analyzed: sakkāya nirodha anto ti nirodha paccayassa gahita ttā vuttam catu sacca vasena pañca kkhandhe  yojetvā iti ajjhāsaya vasena vuttam yathā anuloma desana ttā suttanta desanāya
translated: The end of the cessation of personality is stated because the condition for cessation is included. The five aggregates are yoked by way of the four truths.

original: Antasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽2-3. Dukkhasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: anta sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽dukkha sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The end is stated by way of the inside, etc., because the teaching of the sutta is in accordance with the teaching in the forward order.

original: 104-105. Dutiyampīti api-saddo sampiṇḍanattho. Tena na kevalaṃ paṭhamasuttameva, atha kho dutiyampīti.
analyzed: dutiyam pi iti api saddo sampiṇḍana attho tena na kevalam paṭhama suttam eva atha kho dutiyam pi iti
translated: “A second time” : the word “also” has the sense of “including” . Thus it is not only the first sutta but also the second.

original: Tatiyampi tathevāti iminā “pañcakkhandhe catusaccavasena yojetvā”ti idaṃ upasaṃharati.
analyzed: tatiyam pi tathā iva ati iminā pañca kkhandhe catu sacca vasena yojetvā iti idam upasaṃharati
translated: “A third time” : by this he concludes what was said above, namely, “having combined the five aggregates with the four truths.”

original: Dukkhasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dukkha sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Dukkhasutta is ended.

original: 4. Pariññeyyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pariññeyya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Pariññeyyasutta

original: 106. Pariññeyyeti ettha tisso pariññā ñātapariññā, tīraṇapariññā, pahānapariññāti.
analyzed: pariññeyyā iti ettha tissaḥ pariññāḥ ñāta pariññā tīraṇa pariññā pahāna pariññā ati
translated: “Pariññeyya” : here there are three kinds of full understanding: full understanding as the known , full understanding as investigation , and full understanding as abandoning .

original: Tāsu ñātapariññā yāvadeva tīraṇapariññatthā. Tīraṇapariññā ca yāvadeva pahānapariññatthāti.
analyzed: tāsu ñāta pariññā yāvat eva tīraṇa pariññatthā tīraṇa pariññā ca yāvat eva pahāna pariññatthā ati
translated: Of these, full understanding as the known is only for the sake of full understanding as investigation, and full understanding as investigation is only for the sake of full understanding as abandoning.

original: Tattha ukkaṭṭhāya pariññāya kiccadassanavasena atthaṃ dassento “pariññeyyeti parijānitabbe
analyzed: tattha ukkaṭṭhāya pariññāya kicca dassana vasena attham dassento pariññeyyā iti parijānitabbe
translated: Here, showing the meaning of the highest kind of full understanding by way of the demonstration of its function, he said, “What is to be fully understood is to be fully known,

original: samatikkamitabbe”ti, pahātabbeti attho. Tenāha bhagavā – “katamā ca, bhikkhave, pariññā?
analyzed: samatikkamitabbā iti pahātabbā iti attho tena āha bhagavā katamā ca bhikkhave pariññā
translated: to be fully understood is to be completely transcended.” The meaning is: to be abandoned. Therefore the Exalted One said: “And what, bhikkhus, is full understanding?

original: Rāgakkhayo, dosakkhayo, mohakkhayo”ti, tasmā samatikkamanti, samatikkantaṃ pahānassa
analyzed: rāga khayaḥ dosa khayaḥ moha kkhayaḥ iti tasmā samatikkamanti samatikkantam pahānassa
translated: The destruction of passion, the destruction of hatred, the destruction of delusion.” Therefore, “to be completely transcended” means “to be abandoned.”

original: upāyaṃ. Samatikkamitvā ṭhitanti pajahitvā ṭhitanti ayamettha attho.
analyzed: upāyam samatikkamitvā ṭhitanti pajahitvā ṭhitanti ayam ettha atthaḥ
translated: and the means. “Having gone beyond and having stood”: the meaning is, having abandoned and having stood.

original: Pariññeyyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pariññeyya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Pariññeyya Sutta is finished.

original: 5-10. Samaṇasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Samaṇa Sutta, etc.

original: 107-112. Cattāri saccāni kathitāni assādādīnaṃ samudayādīnañca desitattā.
analyzed: cattāri saccāni kathitāni assāda ādīnam samudaya ādīnam ca desita ttā
translated: The four noble truths are stated because the origin, etc., of the gratification, etc., are taught.

original: Kilesappahānaṃ kathitaṃ rāgappahānassa jotitattā.
analyzed: kilesa ppahānam kathitam rāga ppahānassa jotita ttā
translated: The abandoning of defilements is stated because the abandoning of lust is shown.

original: Samaṇasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: samaṇa sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Samaṇa Sutta, etc., is finished.

original: Antavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: anta vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Anta Vagga is finished.

original: 12. Dhammakathikavaggo
analyzed: dhammakathika vaggo
translated: The Dhammakathika Vagga

original: 1-2. Avijjāsuttādivaṇṇanā🔽113-114. Yāvatāti yasmā. Imāya…pe… samannāgatoti “idaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānātī”tiādinā
analyzed: yāvatā iti yasmai samannāgataḥ ti idam dukkham ti yathābhūtam na pajānāti itiādinā
translated: The explanation of the Avijjā Sutta, etc.

original: nayena vuttāya catūsu ariyasaccesu aññāṇasabhāvāya avijjāya sammohena samannāgato.
analyzed: nayena vuttāya catūsu ariya saccesu aññāṇa sabhāvāya avijjāya sammohena samannāgataḥ
translated: “As far as”: because of this. “Endowed with”: he is endowed with the ignorance that is the nature of not knowing the four noble truths in the way beginning “He does not understand as it really is: ‘This is suffering’” .

original: Ettāvatāti ettakena kāraṇena avijjāgato samaṅgībhūtena upagato, avijjāya vā upeto nāma hoti.
analyzed: ettāvatā ati ettakena kāraṇena avijjāgataḥ samaṅgībhūtena upagataḥ avijjāya vā upetaḥ nāma hoti
translated: “As far as”: for this much reason he is gone to, reached, by ignorance, he is endowed with ignorance.

original: Dutiyepīti vijjāsutte. “Vijjāvasena desanā”ti ayameva visesoti āha “eseva nayo”ti.
analyzed: dutiye pi iti vijjā sutte vijjā vasena desanā ati ayam eva visesaḥ ti āha esā iva nayo ti
translated: “In the second”: in the Vijjā Sutta. “The teaching is by way of clear vision” . This is the only difference. Therefore it is said: “The method is the same.”

original: Avijjāsuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: avijjā sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the “Sutta on Ignorance” is finished.

original: 3. Dhammakathikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽115. Paṭhamena dhammakathiko kathito “dhammaṃ desetī”ti vuttattā. Dutiyena sekhabhūmi
analyzed: dhammakathika sutta vaṇṇanā  paṭhamena dhamma kathiko kathitaḥ dhammam deseti iti vutta ttā dutiyena sekha bhūmi
translated: The exposition of the Dhammakathika Sutta

original: kathitā “paṭipanno hotī”ti vuttattā, tatiyena asekhabhūmi kathitā “anupādāvimutto
analyzed: kathitā paṭipannaḥ hoti iti vutta ttā tatiyena asekha bhūmi kathitā an upādā vimuttaḥ
translated: In the first the preacher of the Dhamma is stated, because it is said, “He teaches the Dhamma.” In the second the plane of the disciple in higher training is stated, because it is said, “He practices in accordance with the Dhamma.” In the third the plane of the disciple beyond training is stated, because it is said, “He is liberated by nonclinging.”

original: hotī”ti vuttattā. Dhammakathikaṃ pucchitena bhagavatā. Visesetvāti dhammakathikabhāvato
analyzed: hoti iti vutta ttā dhamma kathikam pucchitena bhagavatā visesetvā iti dhamma kathika bhāvato
translated: When the Blessed One was asked about the preacher of the Dhamma, he distinguished them, that is, he singled them out, exalted them, by means of the preacher of the Dhamma.

original: visesetvā ukkaṃsetvā. Dve bhūmiyoti sekkhāsekkhabhūmiyo.
analyzed: visesetvā ukkaṃsetvā dve bhūmiyaḥ ti sekkha asekkha bhūmiyaḥ
translated: The two planes are the plane of the disciple in higher training and the plane of the disciple beyond training.

original: Dhammakathikasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhammakathika sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Dhammakathika Sutta is finished.

original: 4. Dutiyadhammakathikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya dhammakathika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Second Dhammakathika Sutta

original: 116. Tīṇi vissajjanānīti yathāpucchaṃ tīṇi vissajjanāni.
analyzed: tīṇi vissajjanāni iti yathāpuccham tīṇi vissajjanāni
translated: Three answers: three answers in accordance with the questions.

original: Dutiyadhammakathikasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya dhammakathika sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Second Dhammakathika Sutta is finished.

original: 5-9. Bandhanasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: bandhana sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the Bandhana Sutta, etc.

original: 117-121. Tīraṃ vuccati vaṭṭaṃ orimatīranti katvā. Tenāha “athāyaṃ itarā pajā, tīramevānudhāvatī”ti.
analyzed: tīram vuccati vaṭṭam katvā tena āha atha ayam itarā pajā tīram eva anudhāvati iti
translated: The “near shore” is called the round of rebirths, because it is “that which is gone to on this side.” Hence it is said: “And this other folk, too, runs on to the near shore” .

original: Pāraṃ vuccati nibbānaṃ saṃsārassa pārimanti katvā. Baddhoti anusayappahānassa akatattā🔽kilesabandhanena baddho, sukkapakkhepi diṭṭhisamanupassanāya rūpādibandhanassa paṭikkhepamattameva🔽vuttaṃ, na vimokkhanti adhippāyo. Imasmiṃ sutte vaṭṭadukkhaṃ kathitanti “tīradassī
analyzed: pāram vuccati nibbānam saṃsārassa pārimanti katvā baddhaḥ ti anusaya ppahānassa a kata ttā  kilesa bandhanena baddhaḥ sukka pakkhe pi diṭṭhi samanupassanāya rūpa ādi bandhanassa paṭikkhepa mattam eva  vuttam na vimokkham ti adhippāyaḥ imasmin sutte vaṭṭa dukkham kathitanti tīradassī
translated: “The other shore” is said to be Nibbāna, since it is the end of the round of rebirths. “Bound” means bound by the fetter of defilements because the underlying tendencies have not been eradicated.

original: pāradassī, parimutto so dukkhasmāti vadāmī”ti āgatattā vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathikanti vattuṃ sakkā.
analyzed: pāradassī parimuttaḥ saḥ dukkhasma ati vadāmi iti āgata ttā vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam kathikam ti vattum sakkā
translated: Even in the bright side, the mere rejection of the fetter of form, etc., by the contemplation of views is stated; the intention is that one does not escape. In this sutta the suffering of the round is stated, thus it can be said that the round and the escape from the round are stated, since it is said: “One who sees the near shore and the further shore, I say he is released from suffering.”

original: Chaṭṭhādīni uttānatthāneva heṭṭhā vuttanayattā.
analyzed: chaṭṭha ādīni uttāna tthānā iva heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā
translated: The meaning of the sixth and following sutta is clear, as it is stated in the same way as above.

original: Bandhanasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bandhana sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Bandhana Sutta is ended.

original: 10. Sīlavantasuttavaṇṇanā🔽122. Ābādhaṭṭhenāti ādito uppattito paṭṭhāya bādhanaṭṭhena rujanaṭṭhena. Antodosaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: sīlavanta sutta vaṇṇanā  ābādha aṭṭhena ati āditas uppattitaḥ paṭṭhāya bādhana ṭṭhena rujana ṭṭhena antodosa aṭṭhena ati
translated: The explanation of the Sīlavantasutta

original: abbhantare eva dussanaṭṭhena kuppanaṭṭhena. Khaṇanaṭṭhenāti sasanaṭṭhena. Dukkhaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: abbhantare eva dussana ṭṭhena kuppana ṭṭhena khaṇana ṭṭhena ati sasana ṭṭhena dukkha ṭṭhena ati
translated: is ended. “In the sense of affliction” means in the sense of afflicting from the beginning of the arising of the disease. “In the sense of internal corruption” means in the sense of corrupting and decaying from within. “In the sense of burning” means in the sense of consuming. “In the sense of suffering” means in the sense of oppressing.

original: dukkhamattā dukkhabhāvena. Dukkhañhi loke “agha”nti vuccati ativiya hananato. Visabhāgaṃ
analyzed: dukkhamattā dukkha bhāvena dukkham hi loke aghanti vuccati ativiya hananataḥ visabhāgam
translated: As pain: as pain in the sense of pain. For what is painful in the world is called “evil” because it afflicts .🔽As alien: as alien to the four great entities, etc., that occur in the opposite way.

original: …pe… paccayaṭṭhenāti yathāpavattamānānaṃ dhātādīnaṃ visabhāgabhūtamahābhūtasamuṭṭhānassa
analyzed: pe paccaya ṭṭhena ati yathā pavattamānānam dhātā ādīnam visabhāga bhūta mahābhūta samuṭṭhānassa
translated: As condition: as the condition for the occurrence of the four great entities, etc., in the opposite way, by being the condition for the affliction of the body.

original: ābādhassa paccayabhāvena. Asakaṭṭhenāti anattaniyato. Palujjanaṭṭhenāti pakārato
analyzed: ābādhassa paccaya bhāvena asaka ṭṭhena ati anatta niyataḥ palujjana ṭṭhena ati pakārato
translated: As not a conveyance: as not a vehicle for self. As subject to abrasion: as subject to abrasion by the abrasion of the aggregates.

original: bhijjanaṭṭhena. Sattasuññataṭṭhenāti sattasaṅkhātaattasuññataṭṭhena. Attābhāvenāti🔽diṭṭhigatikaparikappitassa attano abhāvena. Suññato anattatoti ettha “parato”ti padassa
analyzed: bhijjana ṭṭhena satta suññata ṭṭhena ati satta saṅkhāta atta suññata ṭṭhena atta abhāvena ati  diṭṭhigatika parikappitassa attanaḥ abhāvena suññataḥ anattato ti ettha paratas ti padassa
translated: As void of self in the seven ways: as void of self in the seven ways consisting of the seven kinds of self. As non-existent as self: as non-existent as the self imagined by theorists.

original: saṅgaho kātabbo, tasmā “dvīhi anattamanasikāro”ti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ kātabbaḥ tasmā dvīhi anatta manasikāraḥ iti vattabbam
translated: As void and as non-self: the word “beyond” should be construed with this too, so it should be said that “attention is given to non-self in two ways.”

original: Sīlavantasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sīlavanta sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sīlavant Sutta is finished.

original: 11. Sutavantasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sutavanta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sutavantasutta

original: 123. Tathā ekādasameti ettha tathā-saddena “uttānamevā”ti idaṃ ākaḍḍhati. Idhāti
analyzed: tathā ekādasamā iti ettha tathā saddena uttānam eva ati idam ākaḍḍhati idha ati
translated: . In the same way, in the eleventh: the word “in the same way” includes “only the highest” . Here:

original: ekādasame. Kammaṭṭhānassa uggahadhāraṇaparicayamanasikāravasena pavattañāṇaṃ kammaṭṭhānasutavasena
analyzed: ekādasame kammaṭṭhānassa uggaha dhāraṇa paricaya manasikāra vasena pavatta ñāṇam kammaṭṭhāna suta vasena
translated: In the eleventh, the knowledge that occurs by way of learning the meditation subject, by way of memorizing it, by way of reviewing it, and by way of giving attention to it.

original: nipphajjanato “suta”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nipphajjanato sutan ti vuttam
translated: In the eleventh, the knowledge that occurs by way of learning, bearing in mind, and giving attention to the meditation subject is called “learning” because it is accomplished by way of learning the meditation subject.

original: Sutavantasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽12-13. Kappasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: sutavanta sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sutta on the Learned is finished.🔽The explanation of the Suttas on the Eon, etc.

original: 124-125. Rāhulovādasadisānīti rāhulovādasutte āgatasuttasadisāni.
analyzed: rāhulovāda sadisāni iti rāhulovāda sutte āgata sutta sadisāni
translated: “Like the Advice to Rāhula”: like the Sutta given in the Advice to Rāhula.

original: Kappasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kappa sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Suttas on the Eon, etc. is finished.

original: Dhammakathikavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dhammakathika vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Chapter on Dhamma Speakers is finished.

original: 13. Avijjāvaggo
analyzed: avijjā vaggaḥ
translated: The Chapter on Ignorance

original: 1-10. Samudayadhammasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Suttas on the State of Arising, etc.

original: 126-135. Imasminti avijjāvagge. Catusaccameva kathitaṃ, tasmā heṭṭhā vuttanayattā uttānamevāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: imasmin ti avijjā vagge catu saccam eva kathitam tasmā heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā uttānam eva iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: “In this” chapter on ignorance. The four truths are taught, and so the intention is that since the method of explanation has already been given below, the meaning is evident.

original: Samudayadhammasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: samudaya dhamma sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Suttas on the State of Arising, etc. is finished.

original: Avijjāvaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: avijjā vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Chapter on Ignorance is finished.

original: 14. Kukkuḷavaggo
analyzed: kukkuḷa vaggaḥ
translated: The Chapter on the Burning

original: 1-14. Kukkuḷasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽136-149. Anto aggi mahanto chārikarāsi, tattha ukkuḷavikulato akkamantaṃ yāva kesaggaṃ
analyzed: 🔽antar aggi mahantaḥ tattha ukkuḷa vikulataḥ akkamantam yāva kesaggam
translated: The explanation of the Sutta on the Burning, etc.

original: anudahatāya kucchitaṃ kuḷanti kukkuḷaṃ, rūpavedanādi pana tatopi kañci kālaṃ anudahanato
analyzed: anudahatāya kucchitam kuḷanti kukkuḷam rūpa vedanā ādi pana kañci kālam
translated: The word kukkula is derived from the verb anudahati, to burn. The word kukkula is also used to describe a place where there is a great deal of burning.

original: mahāpariḷāhanaṭṭhena ca kukkuḷaṃ viyāti kukkuḷaṃ. Aniccalakkhaṇādīnīti aniccadukkhānattalakkhaṇāni.🔽Kukkuḷasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mahā pariḷāhana aṭṭhena ca kukkuḷam viyāti kukkuḷam anicca lakkhaṇa ādīni iti anicca dukkha anatta lakkhaṇāni  kukkuḷa sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The characteristics of impermanence, etc., are the characteristics of impermanence, suffering, and non-self.🔽The commentary on the Kukkula Sutta is finished.

original: Kukkuḷavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kukkuḷa vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Kukkula Vagga is finished.

original: 15. Diṭṭhivaggo
analyzed: diṭṭhi vaggo
translated: The Chapter on Views

original: 1-9. Ajjhattasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Ajjhattasutta, etc.

original: 150-158. Paccayaṃ katvāti abhinivesapaccayaṃ katvā. Ādisaddena micchādiṭṭhisakkāyadiṭṭhiattānudiṭṭhi
analyzed: paccayam katvā iti abhinivesa paccayam katvā ādi saddena micchādiṭṭhi sakkāyadiṭṭhi attānudiṭṭhi
translated: “Having made it a premise”: having made it a premise for obsession. The word “etc.” includes wrong view, personality view, and the view of self.

original: saññojanābhinivesa-vinibandhaajjhosānāni saṅgaṇhāti. Tattha abhinivesā taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiyo.
analyzed: saññojana abhinivesa vinibandha ajjhosānāni saṅgaṇhāti tattha abhinivesā taṇhā māna diṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: The fetters, obsessions, bonds, and attachments are included. Herein, obsession is craving, conceit, and views.

original: Vinibandhā “kāye avītarāgo hotī”tiādinā āgatacetasovinibandhā. Ajjhosānāti taṇhādiṭṭhijjhosānāni.
analyzed: vinibandhā kāye avīta rāgaḥ hoti itiādinā āgata cetasovinibandhā ajjhosānā ti taṇhā diṭṭhi ajjhosānāni
translated: Bond is the bond of the mind stated thus: “One is not free from passion for the body” . Attachment is the attachment of craving and views.

original: Sesāni suviññeyyāneva.
analyzed: sesāni su viññeyyāna eva
translated: The rest is easy to understand.

original: Ajjhattasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ajjhatta sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Ajjhattasutta, etc. is finished.

original: 10.Ānandasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: Ro
translated: The Ānandasutta

original: 159. Dharamānakāleti jīvamānakāle. Pahānaṃ apassantoti therassa kira bhagavati pemaṃ
analyzed: dharamāna kāleti jīvamāna kāle pahānam a passantaḥ ti therassa kira bhagavati
translated: “While he is still alive” means while he is still living. “Not seeing his relinquishment” : it seems that the elder had excessive love for the Exalted One.

original: adhimattaṃ. Cittaṃ gaṇhissāmīti cittaṃ ārādhessāmi. Gantabbaṃ hoti, tasmā sapalibodho.
analyzed: adhimattam cittam gaṇhissāmi iti cittam ārādhessāmi gantabbam hoti tasmā sa palibodhaḥ
translated: “I will take hold of his mind” means I will please his mind. “He would have to go” means he would have to go because he would be hindered.

original: Cittaṃ sampahaṃsamānoti cittassa vibodhano. Vimutti…pe… jāto āyatiṃ paṭivedhapaccayattā,
analyzed: cittam sampahaṃsamāno ti cittassa vibodhanaḥ vimutti pe jātaḥ āyatim paṭivedha paccaya ttā
translated: “I will comfort his mind” means I will comfort his mind. “Liberation” is the penetration of the four noble truths. It is called “liberation” because it is the condition for the penetration of the truths in the future.

original: na pana tadā visesāvahabhāvā nibbedhabhāgiyo.🔽Ānandasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: na pana tadā visesa āvaha bhāvā nibbedha bhāgiyo  ānanda sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: But it is not a penetration of the truths in the sense of the realization of the distinction of the truths.🔽The Commentary on the Ānanda Sutta is finished.

original: Diṭṭhivaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: diṭṭhi vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the View-Point Division is finished.

original: Uparipaṇṇāsako samatto.🔽Sāratthappakāsiniyā saṃyuttanikāya-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: upari paṇṇāsakaḥ samatto  sārattha ppakāsiniyā saṃyutta nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The Second Fifty is finished.🔽The Commentary on the Collection of Discourses is finished.🔽The Clarification of the Meaning of the Collection of Discourses is finished.

original: Khandhasaṃyuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.🔽2. Rādhasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: rādha saṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with Māra

original: 1. Paṭhamavaggo🔽1. Mārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama vaggo
translated: The First Chapter🔽The Explanation of the Discourse with Māra

original: 160. Mārasaddoyaṃ bhāvasādhanoti dassento “māro vā assāti maraṇaṃ vā bhaveyyā”ti
analyzed: māra saddaḥ iyam bhāva sādhanaḥ ti dassento māraḥ vā assa ati maraṇam vā bhaveyya iti
translated: The word “Māra” is a verbal noun. Showing that, the text says: “Māra or death would come to be.”

original: āha. Māretāti maritabbo māraṃ maraṇaṃ etabboti āha “māretabbo”ti. Anupādānibbānatthāti
analyzed: āha māretā ati maritabbaḥ māram maraṇam etabbaḥ iti āha māretabbaḥ iti an upādā nibbāna atthā ati
translated: He said: “To be killed” : he is to be killed, he is to be brought to death, thus he said “to be killed”. For the purpose of the extinction without clinging :

original: phalavimuttisaṅkhātā arahato arahantatā nāma yāvadeva anupādānibbānatthā. Nibbānabbhantareti🔽anupādānibbānādhigamassa abbhantare tato orameva idaṃ maggaṃ brahmacariyaṃ vussati,
analyzed: phala vimutti saṅkhātā arahataḥ arahanta tā nāma yāvat eva an upādā nibbāna tthā nibbāna abbhantarā iti  anupādā nibbāna adhigamassa abbhantare tatas oram eva idam maggam brahmacariyam vussati
translated: the state of arahatship, called the liberation of fruition, is for the purpose of the extinction without clinging. In the middle of extinction :

original: na tato paraṃ. Assāti brahmacariyassa.
analyzed: na tatas param brahmacariyassa
translated: in the middle of the attainment of the extinction without clinging. He lives the holy life only up to that, not beyond that. “He” refers to the holy life.

original: Mārasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: māra sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Mārasutta is finished.

original: 2-10. Sattasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sattasutta, etc.

original: 161-169. Laggapucchāti lagganassa bajjhanassa pucchā. Yadi rūpādīsu sattattā satto,🔽khīṇāsavā kathaṃ sattāti? Sattabhūtapubbāti katvā. Kīḷāvigamanti kīḷāya apanayanaṃ
analyzed: lagga pucchā ati lagganassa bajjhanassa pucchā yadi rūpa ādīsu  khīṇa āsavā katham sattā ati satta bhūta pubbā ati katvā kīḷā vigamanti kīḷāya apanayanam
translated: The question of the one who is stuck : the question of the one who is stuck, who is caught. If one is a being because of the sevenfold nature in visible forms, etc.,🔽how is it that those who are without cankers are beings? Because they were beings in the past. The removal of play :

original: oramaṇaṃ. Yantarajju viya bhavapabandhassa nayanato bhavarajjūti taṇhā vuttā.
analyzed: oramaṇam yanta rajju viya bhava pabandhassa nayanataḥ bhava rajju iti taṇhā vuttā
translated: the removal of play, the removal of dalliance. Craving is called “the bond of existence” because it leads to the bondage of existence, like the rope of a puppet.

original: Sattasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: satta sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sattasutta, etc. is finished.

original: Paṭhamavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first chapter is finished.

original: 2. Dutiyavaggo
analyzed: dutiya vaggo
translated: The second chapter

original: 1-12. Mārasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Mārasutta, etc.

original: 170-181. Rūpādivinimuttaṃ maraṇaṃ nāma natthi rūpādīnaṃyeva vibhave maraṇasamaññāti. Maraṇadhammo vināsabhāvo.
analyzed: rūpa ādi vinimuttam maraṇam nāma natthi rūpa ādīnam yeva vibhave maraṇa samaññā ati maraṇa dhammaḥ vināsa bhāvaḥ
translated: There is no such thing as death apart from visible data, etc.; it is only the dissolution of visible data, etc., that is called death. The state of being subject to death is the state of being subject to dissolution.

original: Mārasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: māra sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Māra Suttas is ended.

original: Dutiyavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second sub-chapter is ended.

original: 3-4. Āyācanavaggādi
analyzed: āyācana vagga ādi
translated: The Chapter of the Import of Brief Statements, etc.

original: 1-11. Mārādisuttaekādasakavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Eleven Suttas beginning with the Māra Sutta

original: 182-205. Sukhumaṃ kāraṇaṃ upaṭṭhāti, tenesa thero paṭibhāneyyakānaṃ etadagge ṭhapito. Vimuttiparipācanīyadhammavaseneva, na paṭivedhāvahabhāvena.
analyzed: sukhumam kāraṇam upaṭṭhāti tena īsa thero paṭibhāneyyakānam etad agge ṭhapitaḥ vimutti paripācanīya dhamma vasena iva na paṭivedha āvaha bhāvena
translated: The reason why he is so described is that he is subtle in his application. The Elder was placed at the head of those of ready wit because of his ripening of the deliverance-producing ideas, not because of his penetration.

original: Mārādisuttaekādasakavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Āyācanavaggādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: māra ādi sutta ekādasaka vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  āyācana vagga ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the eleven suttas beginning with the Māra Sutta is ended.🔽The commentary on the Chapter of the Import of Brief Statements, etc., is ended.

original: Sāratthappakāsiniyā saṃyuttanikāya-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sārattha ppakāsiniyā saṃyutta nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The Commentary on the Saṃyutta Nikāya

original: Rādhasaṃyuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: rādha saṃyutta vaṇṇanāya līnattha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The exposition of the meaning of the brief statement in the Rādha Saṃyutta is ended.

original: 3. Diṭṭhisaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Sotāpattivaggo
analyzed: diṭṭhi saṃyuttam  sotāpatti vaggaḥ
translated: The Connected Discourses with Views🔽The Chapter on Stream-Entry

original: 1. Vātasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vāta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Wind Sutta

original: 206. Na ete vātāti ye ime rukkhasākhādibhañjanakarā, ete sattakāyattā vātā nāma na
analyzed: na ete vātā ati ye ime rukkha sākhā ādi bhañjana karāḥ ete sattaka āyattāḥ vātāḥ nāma na
translated: These are not winds: the winds that break up tree branches, etc., are not called “animal-body winds”

original: honti. Te hi niccā dhuvā sassatā. Tenāha “vāto panā”tiādi. Tena sattasu kāyesu catutthaṃ🔽kāyamāha. Rukkhasākhādibhañjanako eso vātaleso nāma, vātasadisoti attho. Esikatthambho
analyzed: honti te hi niccā dhuvā sassatā tena āha vāto pana atiādi tena sattasu kāyesu catuttham  kāyam āha rukkha sākhā ādi bhañjanakaḥ esaḥ vātalesaḥ nāma vāta sadisaḥ ti attho esikatthambho
translated: They are permanent, stable, eternal. Therefore he said: “But the wind is . . . ” Thus he has spoken of the fourth kind of body among the seven kinds of bodies. This is called the “wind element” because it breaks up tree branches, etc., and its meaning is similar to that of the word “wind.” The meaning of “pillar” is that it is like a pillar.

original: viyāti iminā niccalabhāvameva dasseti, pabbatakūṭaṃ viyāti iminā pana sassatisamaṃvāpi.🔽Ayañhi vāyu kāyassa niccataṃ abhinivissa ṭhito “mā ca aniccatā paro hotū”ti na vātā
analyzed: viyā ti iminā niccala bhāvam eva dasseti pabbata kūṭam viyā ti iminā pana  ayam hi vāyu kāyassa nicca tam abhinivissa ṭhitaḥ mā ca anicca tā paras hotu uti na
translated: They are permanent, stable, eternal. Hence he said, “The wind is permanent” and so on. So he has stated the fourth kind of body among the seven kinds of bodies. This is called the “wind element” in the sense that it is like the wind in the sense of the breaking of tree branches, etc. “Like a pillar of the world” : he shows by this that it is motionless. “Like the peak of the Supaṇṇavithi mountain” : by this he shows that it is eternal.

original: vāyantīti bādhati. Esa nayo nadiyo sandantītiādīsu. Udakaṃ panāti dutiyaṃ kāyaṃ sandhāyāha.🔽Gabbho pana na nikkhamati kūṭaṭṭhādibhāveneva tassa labbhanato. Neva te udenti yathā
analyzed: vāyanti iti bādhati udakam panāti dutiyam kāyam sandhāya āha  gabbhaḥ pana na nikkhamati kūṭaṭṭha ādi bhāvena iva tassa labbhanataḥ na iva te udenti yathā
translated: For this wind element is established in the permanence of the body, thinking, “May no impermanence come to me.” It does not blow, does not move, does not stir. “The rivers flow” and so on. “The water does not” : he refers to the second kind of body.

original: vātā, evaṃ tiṭṭhanato lokassa pana tathā matimattanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: vātāḥ evam tiṭṭhanataḥ lokassa pana tathā matimattanti adhippāyo
translated: But the embryo does not come out, for it is possible for it to be like a peak of a mountain. “The wind does not blow” : he shows that the wind element does not move, does not stir, does not stir up the world, just as it does not blow. The intention is that the world is established in the same way as the wind element.

original: Vātasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vāta sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the “Wind” sutta is ended.

original: 2-4. Etaṃmamasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the “This is mine” sutta, etc.

original: 207-209. Diṭṭhaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ cakkhunā daṭṭhabbato. Sutaṃ saddāyatanaṃ sotena sotabbato.
analyzed: diṭṭham rūpa āyatanam cakkhunā daṭṭhabbataḥ sutam sadda āyatanam sotena sotabbataḥ
translated: The visible-data base is seen because it is seen with the eye. The sound base is heard because it is heard with the ear.

original: Mutaṃ gandhāyatanādi tividhaṃ sampattagāhīhi ghānādīhi patvā gahetabbato. Avasesāni
analyzed: mutam gandha āyatana ādi tividham sampatta gāhīhi ghāna ādīhi patvā gahetabbataḥ avasesāni
translated: The odour, etc., bases are sensed because they are sensed by the nose, etc., that have reached them. The remaining

original: cakkhādīni sattāyatanāni viññātaṃ nāma kevalaṃ manoviññāṇena vijānitabbato. Pattanti
analyzed: cakkha ādīni satta āyatanāni viññātam nāma kevalam manaḥ viññāṇena vijānitabbataḥ pattanti
translated: seven bases are cognized because they are cognizable only by mind-consciousness.

original: anuppattaṃ, yaṃ kiñci pāpuṇitabbaṃ pariyesitvā gavesitvā sampattanti anuppattaṃ.
analyzed: an uppattam yam kiñci pāpuṇitabbam pariyesitvā gavesitvā sampattanti an uppattam
translated: What is reached is what is attained, what is obtained by seeking and searching.

original: Pariyesitanti pariyiṭṭhaṃ. Cittena anusañcaritanti manasā cintitaṃ. “Pattaṃ pariyesita”nti
analyzed: pariyesitanti pariyiṭṭham cittena anusañcaritanti manasā cintitam pattam pariyesitanti
translated: What is sought is what is sought after. What is thought with the mind is what is considered by the mind.

original: etasmiṃ padadvaye catukkaṃ sambhavatīti taṃ dassetvā tassa vasena pattapariyesitapadāni,
analyzed: etasmim pada dvaye catukkam sambhavati iti tam dassetvā tassa vasena patta pariyesita padāni
translated: In the case of the two terms “reached” and “sought,” a fourfold reckoning can be made. This is shown by the following, which is stated in order to illustrate the terms “reached” and “sought” according to that fourfold reckoning,

original: tato manasā anuvicaritañca nīharitvā dassetuṃ “lokasmiṃ hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha pariyesitvā
analyzed: tatas manasā anuvicaritam ca nīharitvā dassetum lokasmiṃ hi itiādi vuttam tattha pariyesitvā
translated: and then to show what is “thought with the mind” by excluding what is “reached” and “sought.”

original: pattaṃ nāma pariyesanāya pariggāhabhāvato. Pariyesitaṃ nāma kevalaṃ pariyesitamevāti
