analyzed: pattam nāma pariyesanāya pariggāha bhāvato pariyesitam nāma kevalam pariyesitam eva ati
translated: Herein, what is reached is what is reached by seeking and searching. What is sought is what is merely sought after.

original: katvā pariyesitvā pattassa manussānuvicaritassa vuttattā. Paṭhamavikappe saṅkaro🔽atthīti asaṅkarato ca dassetuṃ “atha vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sabbanti viññātādi. Tañhi manoviññāṇena
analyzed: katvā pariyesitvā pattassa manussa anuvicaritassa vuttattā paṭhama vikappe saṅkaraḥ  atthi iti asaṅkarato ca dassetum atha vā tiādi vuttam sabban ti viññāta ādi tat hi manaḥ viññāṇena
translated: and having searched for it, it is said to be “that which is searched by the mind” because it is found by human beings.🔽In the first analysis there is a confusion of the three terms.🔽In order to show them without confusion, the words “or else” are stated.

original: gahitattā manasā anuvicaritaṃ nāma na diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ.
analyzed: manasā anuvicaritam nāma na diṭṭham sutam mutam
translated: “All” means the cognized, etc. That is called “searched by the mind” because it is apprehended by the mind-consciousness. It is not seen, heard, or cognized.

original: Etaṃmamasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽5. Natthidinnasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: etaṃmamasutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  natthidinna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the sutta beginning with “This is mine” is finished.🔽The explanation of the sutta on “not given”

original: 210. Dinnanti deyyadhammasīsena dānaṃ vuttanti āha “dinnassa phalābhāvaṃ sandhāyā”ti,
analyzed: dinnanti deyya dhamma sīsena dānam vuttanti āha dinnassa phala abhāvam sandhāya iti
translated: “Given” means a gift spoken of in terms of the head of what is to be given. Therefore it is said: “with reference to the non-existence of the fruit of what is given.”

original: dinnaṃ pana annādivatthuṃ kathaṃ paṭikkhipanti. Esa nayo “yiṭṭhaṃ huta”nti etthāpi.
analyzed: dinnam pana anna ādi vatthum katham paṭikkhipanti esa nayaḥ ettha api
translated: But how do they reject the given food, etc.? This is the method in the case of “sacrificed” and “offered.”

original: Mahāyāgoti sabbasādhāraṇaṃ mahādānaṃ. Paheṇakasakkāroti pāhunakānaṃ kātabbasakkāro.
analyzed: mahāyāgo ti sabba sādhāraṇam mahādānam paheṇaka sakkāro ti pāhunakānam kātabba sakkāro
translated: “Great sacrifice” means a great gift common to all. “The honouring of guests” means the honouring of guests.

original: Phalanti ānisaṃsaphalaṃ nissandaphalañca. Vipākoti sadisaphalaṃ. Paraloke ṭhitassa
analyzed: phalanti ānisaṃsa phalam nissanda phalam ca vipāko ti sadisa phalam para loke ṭhitassa
translated: “Fruit” means the fruit of advantage and the fruit of outcome. “Ripening” means the similar fruit.

original: ayaṃ loko natthīti paraloke ṭhitassa kammunā laddhabbo ayaṃ loko na hoti. Idhaloke
analyzed: ayam lokaḥ na atthi iti para loke ṭhitassa kammunā laddhabbo ayam lokaḥ na hoti idha loke
translated: “There is no world beyond”: for one who stands in the world beyond, this world which is obtained through kamma does not exist.

original: ṭhitassapi paraloko natthīti idhaloke ṭhitassa kammunā laddhabbo paraloko na hoti.
analyzed: ṭhitassa api para lokaḥ na atthi iti idha loke ṭhitassa kammunā laddhabbaḥ para lokaḥ na hoti
translated: For one who stands in this world, the world beyond does not exist: for one who stands in this world, the world beyond which is obtained through kamma does not exist.

original: Tattha kāraṇamāha – “sabbe tattha tattheva ucchijjantī”ti. Ime sattā yattha yattha
analyzed: tattha kāraṇam āha sabbe tattha tattha iva ucchijjanti iti ime sattāḥ yattha yattha
translated: Herein, the reason is given: “All beings are annihilated right here.” These beings, wherever they stand,

original: bhave yoniādīsu ca ṭhitā, tattha tattheva ucchijjanti nirudayavināsavasena nassanti.
analyzed: bhave yoni ādīsu ca ṭhitā tattha tattha iva ucchijjanti nirudaya vināsa vasena nassanti
translated: in the various kinds of existence, in the various kinds of birth, etc., are annihilated right there, they perish by way of cessation and destruction.

original: Phalābhāvavasenāti mātāpitūsu sammāpaṭipattimicchāpaṭipattīnaṃ phalassa abhāvavasena
analyzed: phala abhāva vasena ati mātā pitūsu sammā paṭipattim icchā paṭipattīnam phalassa abhāva vasena
translated: By way of the non-existence of results: by way of the non-existence of the results of right and wrong conduct towards mother and father,

original: “natthi mātā, natthi pitā”ti vadanti, na mātāpitūnaṃ, nāpi tesu idāni kariyamānasakkārāsakkārānaṃ🔽abhāvavasena tesaṃ lokapaccakkhattā. Pubbuḷakassa viya imesaṃ sattānaṃ uppādo nāma
analyzed: natthi mātā natthi pitā iti vadanti na mātā pitūnam na api tesu idāni  abhāva vasena tesam loka paccakkhattā pubbuḷakassa viya imesam sattānam uppādaḥ nāma
translated: they say: “There is no mother, there is no father.” Not because of the non-existence of mother and father, or because of the non-existence of the present respect and disrespect shown to them,🔽but because of their non-existence in the world beyond, they say this.

original: kevalo, na bhavato cavitvā āgamanapubbakoti dassanatthaṃ “natthi sattā opapātikā”ti
analyzed: kevalaḥ na bhavataḥ cavitvā āgamana pubbako ti dassana attham natthi sattā opapātikā ati
translated: In order to show that the arising of these beings is like the arising of a bubble, not preceded by a descent from an earlier existence, they say: “There are no beings who are spontaneously born.”

original: vuttanti āha – “cavitvā uppajjanakasattā nāma natthī”ti. Samaṇena nāma yāthāvato
analyzed: vuttanti āha cavitvā uppajjanaka sattā nāma natthi iti samaṇena nāma yāthāvato
translated: “There are no beings who die here and arise there”: he said this because he did not want to say that there are beings who die here and arise there.

original: jānantena kassaci akathetvā saññatena bhavitabbaṃ, aññathā āhopurisikā nāma siyā.
analyzed: jānantena kassaci a kathetvā saññatena bhavitabbam aññathā āhopurisikā nāma siyā
translated: A recluse should be restrained, knowing the right measure in🔽walking, standing, sitting, lying down, looking ahead, looking around, bending, stretching, carrying the double-robe and bowl, and in eating, drinking, chewing, tasting, passing excrement and urine, walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

original: Kiñhi paro parassa karissati, tathā ca attano sampādanassa kassaci avassayo eva na
analyzed: kiñhi paraḥ parassa karissati tathā ca attanaḥ sampādanassa kassaci avassayaḥ eva na
translated: For what can one person do for another? And so he would be of no support to anyone in the attainment of his own welfare, since he would be cut off right there.

original: siyā tattha tattheva ucchijjanatoti āha “ye imañca…pe… pavedentī”ti.
analyzed: siyā tattha tattha iva ucchijjanatā iti āha ye imañcape pavedenti iti
translated: “Those who proclaim this doctrine and view”:🔽“Composed of the four great elements”: the four great entities.

original: Catūsu mahābhūtesu niyuttoti cātumahābhūtiko. Yathā pana mattikāya nibbattaṃ bhājanaṃ🔽mattikāmayaṃ, evamayaṃ catūhi mahābhūtehi nibbattoti āha “catumahābhūtamayo”ti. Ajjhattikā
analyzed: catūsu mahābhūtesu niyuttaḥ iti cātumahābhūtikaḥ yathā pana mattikāya nibbattam bhājanam  mattikā mayam evam ayam catūhi mahābhūtehi nibbattaḥ iti āha catu mahābhūta mayaḥ ti ajjhattikā
translated: Just as a pot is made of clay, so this is produced by the four great entities.🔽“The internal earth element”: the earth element in the continuity of a being.

original: pathavīdhātūti sattasantānagatā pathavīdhātu. Bāhiraṃ pathavīdhātunti bahiddhā mahāpathaviṃ.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu uti satta santāna gatā pathavī dhātu bāhiram pathavī dhātum ti bahiddhā mahā pathavim
translated: “The external earth element”: the great earth outside.

original: Anuyātīti tassa anurūpabhāvena yāti upeti. Upagacchatīti pubbe bāhirapathavīkāyato
analyzed: anuyāti iti tassa anurūpa bhāvena yāti upeti upagacchati iti pubbe bāhira pathavīkāyato
translated: “Conforms”: it goes along, it approaches, it comes up to, in the sense of being similar to it.

original: tadekadesabhūtā pathavī āgantvā ajjhattikabhāvappattiyā sattabhāvena saṇṭhitā idāni🔽ghaṭādipathavī viya tameva bāhirapathavīkāyaṃ upeti upagacchati, sabbaso tena nibbisesataṃ🔽ekībhāvameva gacchatīti attho. Āpādīsupi eseva nayoti ettha pajjunnena mahāsamuddato
analyzed: tad eka desa bhūtā pathavī āgantvā ajjhattika bhāva ppattiyā satta bhāvena saṇṭhitā idāni  ghaṭa ādi pathavī viya tam eva bāhira pathavīkāyam upeti upagacchati sabbaso tena nibbisesa tam  ekībhāvam eva gacchati iti atthaḥ āpa ādīsupi esā iva ettha pajjunnena mahā samuddato
translated: The earth that is a part of that, having come and entered into the state of being internal, is now settled down in the sevenfold state.🔽It approaches, it goes to, that same external earth-body, just as the pot-earth does, and it becomes one with it, without distinction.

original: gahitaāpo viya vassodakabhāvena punapi mahāsamuddaṃ, sūriyaraṃsito gahitaindaggisaṅkhātatejo
analyzed: vassa udaka bhāvena puna api mahā samuddam sūriya raṃsitaḥ gahita aindaggi saṅkhāta tejaḥ
translated: The same method applies in the case of water, etc. Herein, the water that is taken from the great ocean by Pajjunna and becomes rain water again goes to the great ocean.🔽The fire called “sun’s radiance,” which is taken by the sun’s rays, again goes to the sun’s rays.

original: viya punapi sūriyaraṃsiṃ, mahāvāyukhandhato niggatamahāvāyo viya tameva vāyukhandhaṃ
analyzed: sūriya raṃsim mahā vāyu khandhataḥ niggata mahā vāyaḥ viya tam eva vāyu khandham
translated: The great wind that has gone out from the great wind-disk goes to that same wind-disk.

original: upeti upagacchatīti diṭṭhigatiko sayameva attano vādaṃ bhindati. Ummattakapacchisadisañhi
analyzed: upeti upagacchati iti diṭṭhigatikaḥ sayam eva attanaḥ vādam bhindati ummattaka pacchi sadisam hi
translated: The theorist himself breaks his own theory. For the view of the theorist is like a broken pot.

original: diṭṭhigatikadassanaṃ. Manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni ākāsaṃ pakkhandanti tesaṃ visayabhāvā
analyzed: diṭṭhi gatika dassanam mana chaṭṭhāni indriyāni ākāsam pakkhandanti tesam visaya bhāvā
translated: The six faculties with the mind as seventh go to space, he says, and space goes to them.🔽For the objects are included by the inclusion of the faculties.

original: visayāpīti vadati. Visayiggahaṇena hi visayā gahitā eva hontīti. Guṇāguṇapadānīti
analyzed: visayā api iti vadati visayi gahaṇena hi visayāḥ gahitāḥ eva honti iti guṇa aguṇa padāni iti
translated: The good and bad qualities

original: guṇadosakoṭṭhāsā. Sarīrameva padānīti adhippetaṃ sarīrena taṃtaṃkiriyāya pajjitabbato.
analyzed: guṇa dosa koṭṭhāsā sarīram eva padāni iti adhippetam sarīrena taṃ taṃ kiriyāya pajjitabbato
translated: The “parts” are the parts consisting of the good and bad qualities. The body itself is intended here as the “parts” because it is the body that is employed in the various activities.

original: Dabbanti muyhantīti dattū, mūḷhapuggalā. Tehi dattūhi bālamanussehi paññattaṃ.
analyzed: dabbanti muyhanti iti dattū mūḷha puggalā tehi dattūhi bāla manussehi paññattam
translated: “Fools” are those who are confused, deluded people. It is “made by fools” because it is made by those foolish people.

original: Natthidinnasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: natthidinna sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the “Discourse on What is Given with Respect” is finished.

original: 6. Karotosuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: karoto sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The “With One’s Own Hands” Discourse

original: 211. Sahatthā karontassāti sahatthena karontassa. Nissaggiyathāvarādayopi idha sahatthakaraṇeneva🔽saṅgahitā. Hatthādīnīti hatthapādakaṇṇanāsādīni. Pacanaṃ dahanaṃ vibādhananti āha
analyzed: sahatthā karontassa ati sahatthena karontassa nissaggi yathāvara ādayaḥ api idha sahattha karaṇena iva  saṅgahitā hattha ādīni iti hattha pāda kaṇṇa nāsā ādīni pacanam dahanam vibādhanam iti āha
translated: “With one’s own hands”: with one’s own hands. Even the offenses entailing relinquishment and the undetermined offenses are included here by “with one’s own hands.”

original: “daṇḍena pīḷentassā”ti. Papañcasūdaniyaṃ “tajjentassa cā”ti attho vutto, idha pana
analyzed: daṇḍena pīḷentassa ati tajjentassa ca ati atthaḥ vuttaḥ idha pana
translated: “Hands, etc.”: hands, feet, ears, nose, etc. “Cooking, burning, and tormenting”: “tormenting with a stick,” says the commentary. In the Papañcasūdani, the meaning of “tormenting” is given as “harassing.” But here,

original: sumaṅgalavilāsiniyaṃ viya tajjanaṃ paribhāsanaṃ daṇḍeneva saṅgahetvā “daṇḍena pīḷentassa”icceva
analyzed: tad janam paribhāsanam daṇḍena iva saṅgahetvā daṇḍena
translated: like the Sumaṅgalavilāsinī, it is included in “with a stick” and is said to be “tormenting with a stick.”

original: vuttaṃ. Sokaṃ sayaṃ karontassāti parassa sokakāraṇaṃ sayaṃ karontassa, sokaṃ vā uppādentassa.
analyzed: vuttam sokam sayam karontassa ati parassa soka kāraṇam sayam karontassa sokam vā uppādentassa
translated: “Sorrow” is the cause of another’s sorrow, or the arousing of sorrow.

original: Parehi attano vacanakarehi. Sayampi phandatoti parassa vibādhanappayogena sayampi🔽phandato. Atipātayatoti padaṃ suddhakattuatthe hetukattuatthe ca vattatīti āha –
analyzed: parehi attanaḥ vacana karehi sayam pi phandato ti parassa vibādhana ppayogena sayam pi  phandataḥ atipātayataḥ iti padam suddha kattu atthe hetu kattu atthe ca vattati iti āha
translated: He is also agitated by agitation. The word “striving” is used in the sense of the active verb “he strives” and in the sense of the instrumental noun “striving.”🔽“He who kills and he who causes to kill” are the two.

original: “hanantassapi hanāpentassapī”ti. Kāraṇavasenāti kārāpanavasena.
analyzed: hanantassa api hanāpentassa api iti kāraṇa vasena ati kārāpana vasena
translated: By means of a cause: by means of the act of causing.🔽The wall of a house is called a “house-wall.” The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.

original: Gharassa bhitti anto ca bahi ca sandhitā hutvā ṭhitāva gharasandhi. Kiñcipi asesetvā🔽niravaseso lopo nillopo. Ekāgāre niyutto vilopo ekāgāriko. Parito sabbaso panthe🔽hananaṃ paripantho. Pāpaṃ na karīyati pubbe asato uppādetuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā, tasmā
analyzed: gharassa bhitti anto ca bahi ca sandhitā hutvā ghara sandhi  niravasesaḥ lopaḥ nillopaḥ ekāgāre niyuttaḥ vilopaḥ ekāgāriko paritas sabbaso  hananam paripanthaḥ pāpam na karīyati pubbe asataḥ uppādetum a sakkuṇeyya ttā tasmā
translated: The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.🔽The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.🔽The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.🔽The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.🔽The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.🔽The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.🔽The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.🔽The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.

original: natthi pāpaṃ. Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ sattā pāpe pavattantīti āha “sattā pana karomāti evaṃsaññino
analyzed: natthi pāpam yadi evam katham sattā pāpe pavattanti iti āha sattā pana karoma ati evaṃsaññinaḥ
translated: The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.🔽The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing.

original: hontī”ti evaṃ kirassa hoti imesañhi sattānaṃ hiṃsādikiriyā na attānaṃ phusati tassa
analyzed: honti iti evam kirassa hoti imesam hi sattānam hiṃsā ādi kiriyā na attānam phusati tassa
translated: The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing. The house-wall is the wall that is built inside and outside and remains standing

original: niccatāya nibbikārattā, sarīraṃ pana acetanaṃ kaṭṭhakaliṅgarūpamaṃ, tasmiṃ vikopitepi🔽na kiñci pāpanti. Khuranemināti nisitakhuramayaneminā, khurasadisanemināti attho.
analyzed: niccatāya sarīram pana acetanam tasmin vikopite pi  na kiñci pāpanti khura neminā ati nisita khura maya neminā khura sadisa neminā ati attho
translated: But the body is insentient, like a log of wood, and it does not suffer when it is cut up.🔽The razor-edged road is so called because it is a road with razors for grass, or because it is a road that cuts up beings like razors.

original: Gaṅgāya dakkhiṇā disā appatirūpadeso, uttaradisā patirūpadesoti adhippāyena “dakkhiṇañcepī”tiādi🔽vuttanti āha “dakkhiṇatīre manussā kakkhaḷā”tiādi. Mahāyāganti mahāvijitayaññasadisaṃ
analyzed: gaṅgāya dakkhiṇā disā appatirūpadesaḥ uttara disā patirūpadesaḥ ti adhippāyena dakkhiṇam ca ipi itiādi  vuttanti āha dakkhiṇa tīre manussā kakkhaḷā tiādi mahā yāgam ti mahā vijita yañña sadisam
translated: The southern direction is an unsuitable place, the northern direction is a suitable place.🔽The people on the southern bank are hard-hearted, the people on the northern bank are tender-hearted.🔽The great festival is a festival like the great sacrifice of King Mahāvijita.

original: mahāyāgaṃ. Uposathakammenāti uposathakammena ca. Ca-saddo hettha luttaniddiṭṭho.
analyzed: mahā yāgam uposatha kammena ati uposatha kammena ca ca saddaḥ ha ittha lutta niddiṭṭhaḥ
translated: The observance-day rite is the observance-day ceremony. The word “and” is used here in the sense of “also.”

original: Damasaddo hi indriyasaṃvarassa uposathasīlassa ca vācako idhādhippeto. Keci pana🔽“uposathakammenā”ti idaṃ indriyadamanassa visesanaṃ, tasmā “uposathakammabhūtena
analyzed: dama saddaḥ hi indriya saṃvarassa uposatha sīlassa ca vācakaḥ idha adhippeto keci pana  uposatha kammena ati idam indriya damanassa visesanam tasmai uposatha kamma bhūtena
translated: For the word “taming” is a term for the restraint of the faculties and for the virtue of the observance day.🔽Some, however, explain the passage thus: “The observance-day rite is a distinguishing mark of the taming of the faculties. Therefore the meaning is: by the taming of the faculties which is the observance-day rite.”

original: indriyadamenā”ti atthaṃ vadanti. Sīlasaṃyamenāti sīlasaṃvarena. Saccavacanenāti saccavācāya.
analyzed: indriya damena ati attham vadanti sīla saṃyamena ati sīla saṃvarena saccavacanena ati saccavācāya
translated: The restraint of virtue is the restraint by virtue. The truthful speech is the truth.

original: Tassā visuṃ vacanaṃ loke garutarapuññasammatabhāvato. Yathā hi pāpadhammesu musāvādo
analyzed: tassāḥ visum vacanam loke garutara puñña sammata bhāvataḥ yathā hi pāpa dhammesu musāvādaḥ
translated: and its utterance is separate in the world because of the respect and merit it is held to have. For just as lying is weighty among states of unprofitable action,

original: garu, evaṃ puññadhammesu saccavācā. Tenāha bhagavā – “ekaṃ dhammaṃ atītassā”tiādi.
analyzed: evam puñña dhammesu sacca vācā tena āha bhagavā ekam dhammaṃ atītassa atiādi
translated: so truth-telling is among states of profitable action. That is why the Blessed One said, “When one thing is abandoned, the other is abandoned too” .

original: Pavattīti yo karotīti vuccati, tassa santāne phalassa nibbattiyā paccayabhāvena pavatti.
analyzed: pavatti iti yaḥ karoti iti vuccati tassa santāne phalassa nibbattiyā paccaya bhāvena pavatti
translated: “Occurrence” is the occurrence as a condition for the arising of the fruit in the continuity of one who does it.

original: Sabbathāti “karoto”tiādinā vuttena sabbappakārena kiriyameva paṭikkhipanti.
analyzed: sabbathā ti karoto ti ādinā vuttena sabba ppakārena kiriyam eva paṭikkhipanti
translated: “All”: they deny all kinds of doing mentioned in the passage beginning, “When one does and undergoes” .

original: Karotosuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: karoto sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the “When one does” sutta is ended.

original: 7. Hetusuttavaṇṇanā🔽212. Ubhayenāti hetupaccayapaṭisedhavacanena. Saṃkilesapaccayanti saṃkilisanassa
analyzed: hetu sutta vaṇṇanā  ubhayena ati hetu paccaya paṭisedha vacanena saṃkilesa paccayanti saṃkilisanassa
translated: The “Cause” sutta🔽“Both”: by the words denying cause and condition.🔽“Cause of defilement”: cause of defilement, of being soiled, of being stained.

original: malīnabhāvassa kāraṇaṃ. Visuddhipaccayanti saṃkilesato visuddhiyā vodānassa kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: malīna bhāvassa kāraṇam saṃkilesataḥ visuddhiyāḥ vodānassa kāraṇam
translated: “Cause of purification”: cause of purification, of being cleansed, of being purified, from defilement.

original: Natthi balanti sattānaṃ diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikanibbānasampattiāvahaṃ balaṃ nāma
analyzed: natthi balanti sattānam diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika nibbāna sampatti āvaham balam nāma
translated: “No strength”: there is no strength that brings beings to the attainment of the kinds of perfection consisting in the visible and the supramundane.

original: kiñci natthi. Tenāha “yamhī”tiādi. Nidassanamattañcetaṃ, saṃkilesikampi cāyaṃ paṭikkhipateva.
analyzed: kiñci natthi tena āha yamhi itiādi saṃkilesikam pi ca ayam paṭikkhipatā iva
translated: There is nothing to be added. Hence he said “Yamhi” , etc. If this is only a mere indication, then he rejects the defilement too.🔽The words are synonyms. The meaning is this: Strength is in the sense of predominance in each kind of function.

original: Aññamaññavevacanānīti tassā tassā kiriyāya ussannaṭṭhena balaṃ, sūravīrabhāvāvahaṭṭhena
analyzed: aññamaññavevacanāni iti tassā tassā kiriyāya ussanna ṭṭhena balam sūra vīra bhāva āvaha ṭṭhena
translated: Energy is in the sense of bringing about the state of a hero.

original: vīriyaṃ, tameva daḷhaggāhabhāvato porisaṃ dhuraṃ vahantena pavattetabbato purisathāmo,
analyzed: vīriyam tam eva daḷha ggāha bhāvataḥ porisam dhuram vahantena pavattetabbataḥ purisathāmaḥ
translated: The human effort is in the sense of the human burden being borne by one who has taken it up firmly.

original: paraṃ paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanappavattiyā purisaparakkamoti vuttoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: param param ṭhānam akkamana ppavattiyā purisa parakkamaḥ iti vuttaḥ ti veditabbam
translated: The human endeavour is in the sense of the occurrence of the going to a higher and higher place.

original: Satvayogato, rūpādīsu vā sattatāya sattā, pāṇanato assāsanapassāsanavasena pavattiyā🔽pāṇā, te pana so ekindriyādivasena vibhajitvā vadatīti āha “ekindriyo”tiādi. Aṇḍakosādīsu
analyzed: sattva yogataḥ rūpa ādīsu vā satta tāya sattā pāṇanataḥ assāsana passāsana vasena pavattiyā  te pana saḥ ekindriya ādi vasena vibhajitvā vadati iti āha aṇḍa kosa ādīsu
translated: The beings are so called because they are born in the various kinds of generation, or because they are sevenfold in the sense of the seven stations of consciousness .🔽The living beings are so called because they live by means of the in-breaths and out-breaths, and because they occur by means of the in-breaths and out-breaths.🔽The beings are so called because they are born in the various kinds of generation, or because they are sevenfold in the sense of the seven stations of consciousness .

original: bhavanato bhūtāti vuccantīti āha “aṇḍa…pe… vadantī”ti. Jīvanato pāṇaṃ dhārentā viya
analyzed: bhavanataḥ bhūtā ati vuccanti iti āha aṇḍape vadanti iti jīvanataḥ pāṇam dhārentāḥ viya
translated: The living beings are so called because they live by means of the in-breaths and out-breaths, and because they occur by means of the in-breaths and out-breaths.🔽The beings are so called because they are born in the various kinds of generation, or because they are sevenfold in the sense of the seven stations of consciousness .

original: vaḍḍhanato jīvāti sāliyavādike vadanti. Natthi etesaṃ saṃkilesavisuddhīsu vasoti
analyzed: vaḍḍhanataḥ jīvāti sāli yava ādike vadanti natthi etesam saṃkilesa visuddhīsu vaso ti
translated: The living beings are so called because they live by means of the in-breaths and out-breaths, and because they occur by means of the in-breaths and out-breaths.

original: avasā. Natthi tesaṃ balaṃ vīriyanti abalā avīriyā. Niyatatāti acchejjasuttāvutābhejjamaṇino
analyzed: avasā natthi tesam balam vīriyanti abalāḥ avīriyāḥ acchejja suttāvutā bhejja maṇino
translated: “No power, no strength”: they have no power, no strength. “No fixed course”: the unbreakable gem mentioned in the Acchejja-sutta.

original: viya niyatappavattitāya gatijātibandhāpavaggavasena niyamo. Tattha tattha gamananti
analyzed: viya niyata ppavatti tāya gati jāti bandha apavagga vasena niyamaḥ tattha tattha gamanan ti
translated: Avasā: They have no strength or energy, thus they are weak and without energy. Niyata: They are determined in the sense of being bound to a destiny and a rebirth by the occurrence of their continuity, like the unbreakable gem mentioned in the Acchejja Sutta.🔽Tattha tattha gamananti: By way of the six kinds of rebirth.

original: channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ vasena tāsu tāsu gatīsu upagamanaṃ. Samavāyena samāgamo saṅgati.
analyzed: channam abhijātīnam vasena tāsu tāsu gatīsu upagamanam samavāyena samāgamaḥ saṅgati
translated: Samavāyena samāgamo saṅgati: The meeting together of the various conditions.

original: Sabhāvoyevāti yathā kaṇṭakassa tikkhatā, kapitthaphalānaṃ parimaṇḍalatā, migapakkhīnaṃ
analyzed: sabhāvoyā iva ati yathā kaṇṭakassa tikkha tā kapittha phalānam parimaṇḍala tā miga pakkhīnam
translated: Sabhāvo eva: Just as the sharpness of a thorn, the roundness of wood-apple fruits, the variegated colours of deer and birds,

original: vicittākāratā, evaṃ sabbassapi lokassa hetupaccayehi vinā tathā tathā pariṇāmo, ayaṃ
analyzed: vicitta ākāra tā evam sabbassa api lokassa hetu paccayehi vinā tathā tathā pariṇāmaḥ ayaṃ
translated: so too, the transformation of all the world in such and such a way without cause and condition, this is the nature,

original: sabhāvo eva akittimo eva. Tenāha “yena hī”tiādi. Chaḷabhijātiyo parato vitthārīyanti.
analyzed: sabhāvaḥ eva akittimaḥ eva tena āha yena hi itiādi paratas
translated: the non-concealment of all. Therefore it is said: “For by what means” and so forth. The six kinds of rebirth are explained in detail below.

original: Sukhañca dukkhañca paṭisaṃvedentīti vadantā adukkhamasukhabhūbhiṃ sabbena sabbaṃ
analyzed: sukham ca dukkham ca paṭisaṃvedenti iti vadantāḥ adukkham asukha bhūbhiṃ sabbena sabbam
translated: Sukhañca dukkhañca paṭisaṃvedentīti vadantā adukkhamasukhabhūbhiṃ sabbena sabbaṃ

original: na jānantīti ulliṅgento “aññā sukhadukkhabhūmi natthīti dassentī”ti āha.
analyzed: na jānanti iti ulliṅgentaḥ aññā sukha dukkha bhūmi natthi iti dassenti iti āha
translated: na jānantīti: Pointing out this, he says: “They show that there is no other plane of neither-pleasure-nor-pain.”

original: Hetusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: hetu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Hetu Sutta is finished.

original: 8-10. Mahādiṭṭhisuttādivaṇṇanā🔽213-215. Akatāti samena vā visamena vā kenaci hetunā na katā eva. Kenaci kataṃ karaṇaṃ🔽vidhānaṃ natthi etesanti akatavidhānā. Padadvayenapi loke kenaci hetupaccayena nesaṃ🔽abhinibbattitābhāvaṃ dasseti. Iddhiyāpi na nimmitāti kassaci iddhimato devassa brahmuno🔽vā iddhiyāpi na nimmitā. Animmitāti vā kassaci animmāpakā. Ajanakāti etena pathavīkāyādīnaṃ
analyzed: samena vā visamena vā kenacid hetunā na katā eva kenacid katam karaṇam  vidhānam na atthi etesan ti akata vidhānā pada dvayena api loke kenaci hetu paccayena nesam  abhinibbatti tā bhāvam dasseti iddhiyā api na nimmitā ati kassaci iddhimataḥ devassa brahmunaḥ  vā iddhiyā api na nimmitā a nimmitā ati vā kassaci a nimmāpakā a janakā ati etena pathavī kāya ādīnam
translated: 8-10. Explanation of the Great Discourse on the Kinds of Questions, etc.

original: rūpādijanakabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati. Rūpasaddādayo hi pathavīkāyādīhi appaṭibaddhavuttikāti🔽tassa laddhi. Yathā pabbatakūṭaṃ kenaci anibbattitaṃ kassaci ca anibbattakaṃ, evametepīti🔽āha “kūṭaṭṭhā”ti. Yamidaṃ “bījādito aṅkurādi jāyatī”ti vuccati, tañca vijjamānameva
analyzed: rūpa ādi janaka bhāvam paṭikkhipati rūpa sadda ādayaḥ hi pathavīkāya ādīhi appaṭibaddha vuttikā ti 🔽tassa laddhi yathā pabbata kūṭam kenaci a nibbattitam kassaci ca a nibbattakam evam ete api iti 🔽āha yam idam bīja āditaḥ aṅkura ādi jāyati iti vuccati tat ca vijjamānam eva
translated: Not made by anyone, either rightly or wrongly, is unmade. There is no making, no contrivance, of them by anyone in the world is uncontrived. By these two terms he shows that they are not brought into being by any cause or condition in the world. Not made by anyone’s supernormal power is not made by the supernormal power of any deity or Brahmā. Not made by anyone’s mind-made body is not made by anyone’s creation. Not born is not produced. By this he rejects the view that the earth body, etc., are producers of materiality, and so on. For materiality, sound, and so on, are not bound up with the earth body, etc., in the way of being produced from them, according to his doctrine. Just as a mountain peak is not made by anyone and is not the making of anyone, so too are these, is what is meant. He says “standing like a mountain peak” . What is called “the sprout is produced from the seed, etc.” is only what is found in the world.

original: tato nikkhamati, nāvijjamānaṃ, aññathā yato kutoci yassa kassaci uppatti siyāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tatas nikkhamati na avijjamānam aññathā yatas kutoci yassa kassaci uppatti siyā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: He does not come from anywhere else, nor does he arise by chance.

original: Ṭhitāti nibbikārabhāvena ṭhitā. Na calantīti na vikāraṃ āpajjanti. Vikārābhāvena
analyzed: ṭhitā ati nibbikāra bhāvena ṭhitāḥ na calanti iti na vikāram āpajjanti vikāra abhāvena
translated: “Abide” : they abide without any action. “Do not move” : they do not undergo any change.

original: hi tesaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitatā. Aniñjanañca attano pakatiyā avaṭṭhānameva.
analyzed: hi tesam sattannam kāyānam esika ṭṭhāyi ṭṭhita tā aniñjanam ca attanaḥ pakatiyāḥ avaṭṭhānam eva
translated: For it is by not undergoing any change that the seven bodies are “firmly established” and “immovable.”🔽“Do not waver” means that they do not swerve from their own nature.

original: Tenāha “na vipariṇamantī”ti. Avipariṇāmadhammattā eva ca ne aññamaññaṃ na byābādhenti.
analyzed: tena āha na vipariṇamanti iti a vipariṇāma dhamma ttāḥ eva ca ne aññam aññam na byābādhenti
translated: Therefore it is said: “They do not change.” And because they do not change, they do not obstruct one another.

original: Sati hi vikāraṃ āpādetabbatāya byābādhakatāpi siyā, tathā anuggahetabbatāya anuggāhakatāti
analyzed: sati hi vikāram āpādetabba tāya byābādhaka tā api siyā tathā anuggahetabba tāya anuggāhaka tā ati
translated: For if they were to undergo change, they might obstruct one another, just as they might be helped by one another.

original: tadabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ pāḷiyaṃ “nāla”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Pathavī eva kāyekadesattā pathavikāyo.
analyzed: tad abhāvam dassetum pāḷiyam nāla nti ādi vuttam pathavī eva kāya eka desa ttā pathavi kāyaḥ
translated: In order to show this, the text says: “They do not touch.” The earth body is so called because the earth is one part of the body.

original: Jīvasattamānaṃ kāyānaṃ niccatāya nibbikārābhāvato na hantabbatā, na ghāṭetabbatā
analyzed: jīva sattamānam kāyānam nicca tāya nibbikāra abhāvataḥ na hantabba tā na ghāṭetabba tā
translated: Because the seven bodies of living beings are permanent and without any action, they cannot be killed or destroyed.🔽Therefore there is no killer or destroyer.

original: cāti neva koci hantā ghātetā vā. Tenāha “sattannantvevā”tiādi. Yadi koci hantā natthi,
analyzed: ca ati na iva koci hantā ghātetā vā tena āha yadi koci hantā natthi
translated: If there is no killer,

original: kathaṃ satthappahāroti āha “yathā muggarāsiādīsū”tiādi. Kevalaṃ saññāmattameva hoti,
analyzed: katham sattha ppahāraḥ iti āha yathā muggara asi ādīsu utiādi kevalam saññā mattam eva hoti
translated: How is it that they are abandoned by the Master? “As in the case of the mass of cudgels, etc.”, etc.🔽The intention is that there is only mere perception,

original: na ghātanādi, paramatthato sattannantveva kāyānaṃ avikopanīyabhāvatoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: na ghātana ādi paramatthato kāyānaṃ a vikopanīya bhāvato ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: not killing, etc., because in the ultimate sense the bodies are not to be destroyed.

original: Pamukhayonīnanti manussatiracchānādīsu khattiyabrāhmaṇādisīhabyagghādivasena padhānayonīnaṃ.
analyzed: manussa tiracchāna ādīsu khattiya brāhmaṇa ādi sīha byaggha ādi vasena padhāna yonīnam
translated: “The chief kinds of rebirth” are the chief kinds of rebirth among human beings, animals, etc., as khattiyas, brahmans, etc., and as lions, tigers, etc.🔽“Six thousand and sixty times a hundred” is the meaning of the words “five hundred times five

original: Saṭṭhisatāni chasahassāni. “Pañca ca kammuno satānī”ti padassa atthadassanaṃ “pañca🔽kammasatāni cā”ti. Eseva nayoti iminā “kevalaṃ takkamattena niratthakadiṭṭhiṃ dīpetī”ti
analyzed: saṭṭhi satāni cha sahassāni pañca ca kammuno satāni iti padassa attha dassanam pañca  kamma satāni ca ati esā iva nayo ti iminā kevalam takka mattena niratthaka diṭṭhim dīpeti iti
translated: actions” .

original: imameva atthaṃ atidisati. Ettha ca takkamattakenāti iminā yasmā takkikā niraṅkusatāya
analyzed: imam eva attham atidisati ettha ca takkamattakena ati iminā yasmā takkikā niraṅkusa tāya
translated: “In the same way” : by this he shows that the view is pointless, being mere speculation.🔽By “mere speculation” he shows that because the speculators are unrestrained in their speculation,

original: parikappanassa yaṃ kiñci attano parikappitaṃ sārato maññamānā tatheva abhinivissa
analyzed: parikappanassa yat kiñci attanaḥ parikappitam sārataḥ maññamānā tathā iva abhinivissa
translated: they regard whatever they have speculated as true, and they cling to it as such,

original: takkadiṭṭhigāhaṃ gaṇhanti, tasmā na tesaṃ diṭṭhivatthūsu viññūhi vicāraṇā kātabbāti
analyzed: takka diṭṭhi gāham gaṇhanti tasmā na tesam diṭṭhi vatthūsu viññūhi vicāraṇā kātabbā ati
translated: taking up the view of the speculators. Therefore the wise should not investigate the bases of their views.

original: dasseti. Kecīti uttaravihāravāsino. Te hi “pañca kammānīti cakkhusotaghānajivhākāyā,🔽imāni pañcindriyāni ‘pañca kammānīti paññāpentī”ti vadanti. Kammanti laddhīti oḷārikabhāvato
analyzed: dasseti keci iti uttaravihāra vāsino te hi pañca kammāni iti cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā kāyā  imāni pañca indriyāni pañca kammāni iti paññāpenti iti vadanti laddhi iti oḷārika bhāvato
translated: He shows. Some: the residents of the northern monastery. For they say: “The five actions are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.🔽These five faculties are called the five actions.” The five actions are called “complete actions” because of their grossness.

original: paripuṇṇakammanti laddhi. Manokammaṃ anoḷārikattā upaḍḍhakammanti laddhīti yojanā.
analyzed: paripuṇṇa kammanti laddhi manaḥ kammam anoḷārika ttā upaḍḍha kammanti laddhi iti yojanā
translated: The mental action is called “half an action” because of its subtlety.

original: “Dvāsaṭṭhipaṭipadā”ti vattabbe sabhāvaniruttiṃ ajānantā “dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadā ti vattabbe sabhāva niruttim a jānantāḥ dvaṭṭhi paṭipadā iti vadanti
translated: When they should say “the sixty-two paths,” those who do not know the natural pronunciation say “the two-eight paths.”

original: Ekasmiṃ kappeti ekasmiṃ mahākappe. Tatthāpi ca vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyisaññite ekasmiṃ asaṅkhyeyyakappe.🔽Urabbhe hanantīti orabbhikā. Evaṃ sūkarikādayo veditabbā. Luddāti aññepi ye keci🔽māgavikanesādādayo, te pāpakammapasutatāya kaṇhābhijātīti vadanti. Bhikkhūti buddhasāsane
analyzed: ekasmim kappe ti ekasmim mahākappe tattha api ca vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyi saññite ekasmim asaṅkhyeyya kappe  urabbhe hananti iti orabbhikāḥ evam sūkarika ādayaḥ veditabbāḥ luddā ti aññe pi ye keci  māgavika nesāda ādayo te pāpa kamma pasuta tāya kaṇha abhijātī iti vadanti bhikkhū iti buddha sāsane
translated: In one: in one great aeon. And there too, in one incalculable aeon, which is known as the place of the turning back.🔽Butchers: those who kill goats. So too, pig-butchers, etc., should be understood. Hunters: and also others who are addicted to evil actions.🔽They are called “black-born” because of their addiction to evil actions. Monks: monks in the Dispensation of the Buddha.

original: bhikkhū. Te kira “sacchandarāgā paribhuñjantī”ti adhippāyena catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake
analyzed: bhikkhū te kira sa chanda rāgā paribhuñjanti iti adhippāyena catūsu paccayesu kaṇṭake
translated: They say that the four requisites are “thorns” with the intention that they are enjoyed with lust and desire.

original: pakkhipitvā khādantīti vadanti. Kasmāti ce? Yasmā te paṇītapaṇīte paccaye paṭisevantīti🔽tassa micchāgāho. Ñāyaladdhepi paccaye paribhuñjamānā ājīvakasamayassa vilomagāhitāya
analyzed: pakkhipitvā khādanti iti vadanti kasmā ati ce yasmā te paṇīta paṇīte paccaye paṭisevanti iti  tassa micchāgāhaḥ ñāya laddhe pi paccaye paribhuñjamānāḥ ājīvaka samayassa viloma gāhitāya
translated: They eat them, it is said, after inserting them into their throats. Why? Because they enjoy the best of requisites.🔽This is their wrong view. Others say that they eat them after inserting them into their throats because they eat the requisites they get in the right way, but they go against the Acelaka doctrine.

original: paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti nāmāti vadantīti apare. Eke pabbajitā, ye
analyzed: paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti nāma ati vadanti iti apare eke pabbajitāḥ ye
translated: Some who have gone forth,

original: visesato attakilamathānuyogamanuyuttā. Tathā hi te kaṇṭake vattantā viya hontīti🔽kaṇṭakavuttikāti vuttā. Ṭhatvā bhuñjananahānapaṭikkhepādivatasamāyogena paṇḍaratarā.🔽Acelakasāvakāti ājīvakasāvake vadati. Te kira ājīvakasamaye ājīvakaladdhiyā daḷhagāhitāya
analyzed: visesataḥ atta kilamatha anuyogam anuyuttā tathā hi te kaṇṭake vattantā viya honti iti  kaṇṭakavuttikā ati vuttā bhuñjanana hāna paṭikkhepa ādi vata samāyogena paṇḍaratarā  ājīvaka sāvake vadati te kira ājīvaka samaye ājīvaka laddhiyā daḷha gāhitāya
translated: who are devoted to the practice of mortifying and tormenting themselves. For they are like those who go about with thorns in their throats.🔽They are called “thorn-eaters” because of their practice of eating after inserting the thorns into their throats. They are whiter than the Niganthas because of their practice of standing when they eat and drink, of not rejecting food, and so on.

original: nigaṇṭhehipi paṇḍaratarā. Nandādayo kira tathārūpaṃ ājīvakapaṭipattiṃ ukkaṃsaṃ pāpetvā
analyzed: paṇḍaratarāḥ nanda ādayaḥ kira tathārūpam ājīvaka paṭipattim ukkaṃsam pāpetvā
translated: “Acelaka disciples” : he refers to the Acelaka disciples of the Acelakas. They are whiter than the Niganthas, it seems, because they hold the Acelaka doctrine and practice more strictly. Nandaka, it seems, and others, having gone to the extreme in the practice of the Acelakas,

original: ṭhitā, tasmā nigaṇṭhehi ājīvakasāvakehi ca paṇḍaratarā vuttā. Paramasukkābhijātīti ayaṃ tesaṃ laddhi.
analyzed: ṭhitā tasmai nigaṇṭhehi ājīvaka sāvakehi ca paṇḍaratarā vuttā parama sukka abhijātī iti ayam tesam laddhi
translated: are called whiter than the Niganthas and the Acelaka disciples. Their doctrine is that they are supremely happy.

original: Purisabhūmiyoti padhānapuggalena niddeso. Itthīnampetā bhūmiyo icchanteva. Bhikkhu
analyzed: purisa bhūmiyaḥ ti padhāna puggalena niddesaḥ itthī nampetāḥ bhūmiyaḥ icchantā iva bhikkhu
translated: The “man’s stage” is the description of the man of energy. They want these stages to be women.

original: ca pannakotiādi tesaṃ pāḷi eva. Tattha pannakoti bhikkhāya vicaraṇako, tesaṃ vā paṭipattiyā🔽paṭipannako. Jinoti jiṇṇo jarāvasena hīnadhātuko, attano vā paṭipattiyā paṭipakkhe🔽jinitvā ṭhito. So kira tathābhūto dhammampi kassaci na katheti. Tenāha “na kiñci
analyzed: ca pannaka iti ādi tesam eva tattha pannakaḥ ti bhikkhāya vicaraṇako tesam vā paṭipattiyā  paṭipannakaḥ jinoti jiṇṇaḥ jarā vasena hīna dhātukaḥ attanaḥ vā paṭipattiyā paṭipakkhe  jinitvā ṭhitaḥ saḥ kira tathābhūtaḥ dhammam pi kassaci na katheti tena āha na kiñci
translated: The monk, the snake, and so on are in the text itself. Herein, the snake is one who goes about for alms, or one who has entered on the practice of their practice.

original: āhā”ti. Niṭṭhuhanādivippakāre kenaci katepi khamanavasena na kiñci vadatīti vadanti.🔽Alābhinti “so na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhātī”tiādinā nayena vuttaalābhahetusamāyogena
analyzed: āha ati niṭṭhuhana ādi vippakāre kenaci kate pi khamana vasena na kiñci vadati iti vadanti  alābhin ti saḥ na kumbhi mukhā paṭiggaṇhāti iti ādinā nayena vutta alābha hetu samāyogena
translated: The victor is one who is worn out by ageing, who has inferior elements owing to age, or who has stood having conquered his opponents by his own practice. It seems that when he is so, he does not teach the Dhamma to anyone. Hence it is said, “He does not say ‘Take anything’” . And they say that when anyone does anything to him such as spitting on him, he does not say anything by way of forgiveness.🔽The non-gainer: he is a non-gainer because he is not associated with the causes of gain stated in the way beginning, “He does not receive from a bowl” .

original: alābhiṃ. Tato eva jighacchādubbalyaparetatāya sayanaparāyaṇaṃ samaṇaṃ pannabhūmīti vadanti.
analyzed: alābhim tatas eva jighacchā dubbalya pareta tāya sayana parāyaṇam samaṇam pannabhūmī iti vadanti
translated: And because of that very fact they say that the ascetic who is prone to lie down is a non-gainer.

original: Ājīvavuttisatānīti sattānaṃ ājīvabhūtāni jīvikāvuttisatāni. Pasuggahaṇena eḷakajāti
analyzed: ājīva vutti satāni iti sattānam ājīva bhūtāni jīvikā vutti satāni pasu ggahaṇena eḷaka jāti
translated: The hundred ways of livelihood for beings: the hundred ways of livelihood for beings.

original: gahitā, migaggahaṇena rurugavayādisabbamigajāti. Bahū devāti cātumahārājikādibrahmakāyikādivasena
analyzed: gahitāḥ miga ggahaṇena ruru gavaya ādi sabba miga jāti bahū cātumahārājika ādi brahmakāyika ādi vasena
translated: and the rest are included by the word “deer.”🔽There are many kinds of gods, too, according to the distinctions of the gods of the heaven of the Four Great Kings, etc., and the Brahmā-world gods, etc.

original: tesaṃ antarabhedavasena bahū devā. Tattha cātumahārājikānaṃ ekacce antarabhedā mahāsamayasuttavasena
analyzed: tesam antara bheda vasena bahū devā tattha cātumahārājikānam ekacce antara bhedāḥ mahā samaya sutta vasena
translated: Herein, some of the gods of the heaven of the Four Great Kings should be illustrated by the Great Assembly Sutta .

original: dīpetabbā. Manussāpi anantāti dīpadesakulavaṃsājīvādivibhāgena manussāpi anantabhedā.
analyzed: dīpetabbā manussā api anantā ti dīpa desa kula vaṃsa ājīva ādi vibhāgena manussā api ananta bhedā
translated: Humans are of infinite kinds too, according to the distinctions of continent, country, family, clan, occupation, and so on.

original: Pisācā eva pesācā, te mahantamahantā ajagarapetādayo. Chaddantadahamandākiniyo kuḷīramucalindanāmena vadanti.
analyzed: pisācāḥ eva pesācā te mahanta mahantāḥ ajagara peta ādayo chaddanta daha mandākiniyaḥ kuḷīra mucalinda nāmena vadanti
translated: The “demons” are the “demons proper,” and the “great demons” are the great demons, the python demons, and so on. The Chaddanta Lake and the Mandākinī Lake are called the Kuṇāla Lake and the Mucalinda Lake.🔽“The closed-fist” is the one with all the knots .

original: Pavuṭāti sabbagaṇṭhikā. Paṇḍitopi…pe… uddhaṃ na gacchati. Kasmā? Sattānaṃ saṃsaraṇakālassa niyatabhāvato.
analyzed: sabbagaṇṭhikā uddham na gacchati kasmā sattānam saṃsaraṇa kālassa niyata bhāvataḥ
translated: The wise man … does not go upwards. Why? Because the time of beings’ wandering on is fixed.

original: Aparipakkaṃ saṃsaraṇanimittaṃ sīlādinā paripāceti nāma sīghaṃyeva visuddhippattiyā.
analyzed: a paripakkam saṃsaraṇa nimittam sīla ādinā paripāca iti nāma sīgham yā iva visuddhi ppattiyā
translated: When the cause for wandering on is unripened, he ripens it by means of virtue, etc., and so is called “one who hastens the ripening of what is unripened.”

original: Paripakkaṃ kammaṃ phussa phussa patvā patvā kāle paripakkabhāvāpādanena byantī karoti
analyzed: paripakkam kammam phussa phussa patvā patvā kāle paripakka bhāva āpādanena byantī karoti
translated: When the kamma that has ripened is exhausted, he brings it to exhaustion by experiencing it, and so is called “one who brings to exhaustion what is ripened.”

original: nāma. Suttaguḷeti suttavaṭṭiyaṃ. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti upamāya sattānaṃ saṃsāro🔽anukkamena khīyateva, na tassa vaḍḍhīti dasseti paricchinnarūpattā. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva
analyzed: nāma sutta guḷā iti sutta vaṭṭiyam nibbeṭhiyamānam eva paleti iti upamāya sattānam saṃsāraḥ  anukkamena khīyatā iva na tassa vaḍḍhi iti dasseti paricchinna rūpa ttā nibbeṭhiyamānam eva
translated: ‘A ball of thread’ is a ball of thread-yarn. ‘It would be unwinding’ shows that beings’ round of rebirths is gradually being used up, not that it is increasing, since it is limited in extent.

original: suttaguḷaṃ gacchatīti vuccati. Tañca kho suttapamāṇena, sutte pana asati kuto gacchati🔽suttaguḷaṃ. Tenāha – “sutte khīṇe na gacchatī”ti. Tattheva tiṭṭhati suttapariyantanti🔽adhippāyo. Kālavasenāti attani veṭhetvā ṭhitaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ yathāvuttassa kālassa
analyzed: sutta guḷam gacchati iti vuccati tat ca kho sutta pamāṇena sutte pana asati kutas gacchati  sutta guḷam tena āha sutte khīṇe na gacchati iti tattha eva tiṭṭhati sutta pariyantam ti  adhippāyaḥ kāla vasena āti attani veṭhetvā ṭhitam sukha dukkham yathāvuttassa kālassa
translated: “A thread-ball” is a ball of thread. “It goes on being unwound” means that the unwinding of the thread-ball is called “going.” And that is measured by the thread. But if there were no thread, how could it go?

original: vasena nibbeṭhiyamāno bālo ca paṇḍito ca paleti gacchati, nātikkamati saṃsāraṃ.
analyzed: vasena nibbeṭhiyamānaḥ bālo ca paṇḍito ca paleti gacchati na atikkamati saṃsāraṃ
translated: Therefore it is said: “When the thread is exhausted, it does not go.” The intention is that it remains right there at the end of the thread. “In due course” means that the fool and the wise one go on being unwound in accordance with the time stated above, in regard to the pleasure and pain that have been wound up in themselves. They go on being unwound, they go on, they do not transcend saṃsāra.

original: Mahādiṭṭhisuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mahādiṭṭhi sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Mahādiṭṭhi Sutta is finished.

original: 11-18. Antavāsuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Antavā Sutta is finished.

original: 216-223. Ekato vaḍḍhitanimittanti ekapassena vaḍḍhitaṃ kasiṇanimittaṃ. Gāhenāti lābhī
analyzed: ekatas vaḍḍhita nimittanti eka passena vaḍḍhitam kasiṇa nimittam gāhena ati lābhī
translated: The sign of growth on one side: the kasiṇa sign that has grown on one side. “To gain” means to obtain.

original: jhānacakkhunā passitvā gahaṇena. Takkenāti na lābhī takkamattena. Uppannadiṭṭhīti
analyzed: jhāna cakkhunā passitvā gahaṇena takkena ati na lābhī takka mattena uppanna diṭṭhī iti
translated: and he saw it with the eye of concentration. ‘By inference’: he is not a gainer of the state of inference. ‘The view arose in him’:🔽the view arose in him that ‘the world’

original: “loko”ti uppannadiṭṭhi. Sabbato vaḍḍhitanti samantato appamāṇakasiṇanimittaṃ. Ekamevāti🔽“ekameva vatthū”ti uppannadiṭṭhi. Aṭṭhārasa veyyākaraṇānīti veyyākaraṇalakkhaṇappattāni
analyzed: loko ti uppanna diṭṭhi sabbatas vaḍḍhitam ti samantataḥ appamāṇa kasiṇa nimittam ekam eva ati  ekam eva vatthu uti uppanna diṭṭhi aṭṭhārasa veyyākaraṇāni iti veyyākaraṇa lakkhaṇa ppattāni
translated: ‘is infinite’. ‘It extended everywhere’: the measureless kasiṇa sign extended all round. ‘The view arose in him’:🔽the view arose in him that ‘it is only one thing’. ‘Eighteen modes of reply’: eighteen sutta passages that have the characteristic of being modes of reply.

original: aṭṭhārasa suttāni. Ekaṃ gamananti ekaṃ veyyākaraṇagamanaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa suttāni ekam gamananti ekam veyyākaraṇa gamanaṃ
translated: ‘One mode of reply’: one mode of reply to the eighteen sutta passages.

original: Antavāsuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The explanation of the Antavāsutta is ended.

original: 2. Dutiyagamanādivaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya gamana ādi vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the second mode of reply, etc.,

original: 224-301. Dukkhavasena vuttanti “iti kho, bhikkhave, dukkhe sati dukkhaṃ upādāyā”tiādidukkhavasena🔽vuttaṃ. Tādisameva dutiyaṃ veyyākaraṇagamanaṃ. Tenāha “tatrāpi aṭṭhāraseva veyyākaraṇānī”ti.
analyzed: dukkha vasena vuttan ti iti kho bhikkhave dukkhe sati dukkham upādāya ati ādi dukkha vasena  vuttam tādisam eva dutiyam veyyākaraṇa gamanam tena āha tatra api aṭṭhārasa iva veyyākaraṇāni iti
translated: ‘In terms of suffering’: this is said in terms of suffering, according as it is said: “Bhikkhus, suffering existing, dependent on suffering” , etc.🔽The second mode of reply is of the same kind. Hence he says: “There too there are only eighteen modes of reply.”

original: Tehīti “rūpī attā hotī”tiādinayapavattehi veyyākaraṇehi saddhiṃ. Tanti dutiyaṃ gamanaṃ.
analyzed: tehi iti rūpī attā hoti itiādi naya pavattehi veyyākaraṇehi saddhim dutiyam gamanaṃ
translated: ‘With those’: with the modes of reply that occur in the way beginning, “The self is material and unimpaired after death” . ‘That’: the second mode of reply.

original: Ārammaṇamevāti kasiṇasaṅkhātaṃ ārammaṇameva. Takkisaddena suddhatakkikānaṃ gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇam eva ati kasiṇa saṅkhātam ārammaṇam eva takki saddena suddha takkikānam gahaṇam daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: “The object itself” is the object called a “kasiṇa.” The word “reason” should be understood to include the “pure reasons.”

original: Aniccadukkhavasenāti “yadaniccaṃ, taṃ dukkhaṃ, tasmiṃ sati tadupādāya evaṃ diṭṭhi
analyzed: anicca dukkha vasena ati yat aniccam tam dukkham tasmin sati tat upādāya evam diṭṭhi
translated: “By way of impermanence and pain”: “What is impermanent is painful. When that exists, that arises. Depending on that, such a view arises.”

original: uppajjatī”ti vuttaaniccadukkhavasenāti. Tehiyevāti dutiye peyyāle vuttappakārehiyeva.
analyzed: uppajjati iti vutta anicca dukkha vasena ati tehiyeva ati dutiye peyyāle vutta ppakārehiyeva
translated: “By those same”: by the kinds already mentioned in the second section.

original: Tiparivaṭṭavasenāti tehiyeva chabbīsatiyā suttehi catutthapeyyāle tiparivaṭṭavasena vuttoti yojanā.
analyzed: ti parivaṭṭa vasena āti tehi yeva chabbīsatiyā suttehi catuttha peyyāle ti parivaṭṭa vasena vuttaḥ iti yojanā
translated: “By the three-fold method”: the method of the third section of the four-fold sutta is to be applied to the twenty-six suttas.

original: Dutiyagamanādivaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya gamana ādi vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second section on going, etc., is finished.

original: Sāratthappakāsiniyā saṃyuttanikāya-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sārattha ppakāsiniyā saṃyutta nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Saṃyutta Nikāya,

original: Diṭṭhisaṃyuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: diṭṭhi saṃyutta vaṇṇanāya līna ttha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: the elucidation of the meaning of the brief statements there, is finished.

original: 4. Okkantasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: okkanta saṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses on Views

original: 1-10. Cakkhusuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the eye sutta, etc.

original: 302-311. Saddhādhimokkhanti saddahanavasena pavattaṃ adhimokkhaṃ, na sanniṭṭhānamattavasena
analyzed: saddhā adhimokkham ti saddahana vasena pavattam adhimokkham na sanniṭṭhāna matta vasena
translated: “Resolve through faith”: resolve that occurs through confidence, not merely as a conclusion.

original: pavattaṃ adhimokkhaṃ. Dassanampi sammattaṃ, taṃsijjhānavasena pavattaniyāmo sammattaniyāmo,
analyzed: pavattam adhimokkham dassanam pi sammattam pavatta niyāmo sammatta niyāmo
translated: The regularity of occurrence by way of the jhāna is the regularity of occurrence of the right path.

original: ariyamaggo. Anantarāyataṃ dīpeti kappavināsapaṭibhāgena pavattattā. Tathā cāha “tenevāhā”tiādi.
analyzed: ariya maggaḥ anantarāyatam dīpeti kappa vināsa paṭibhāgena pavatta tā tathā ca āha tena iva āha atiādi
translated: It shows the absence of hindrance, because it occurs with the destruction of the aeon as its counterpart. And so he says, “For this very reason it is said.”

original: Kappasīsena bhājanalokaṃ vadati. So hi uḍḍayhati, na kappo, uḍḍayhanavelāti jhāyanavelā.
analyzed: kappa sīsena bhājana lokam vadati saḥ hi uḍḍayhati na kappo uḍḍayhana velā ati jhāyana velā
translated: The world of the physical basis is called the aeon, because it is destroyed, not the aeon, because the aeon is not destroyed. The time of its destruction is the time of the destruction of the aeon.

original: Ṭhito kappo ṭhitakappo, so assa atthīti ṭhitakappī, kappaṃ ṭhapetuṃ samatthoti attho.
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ kappaḥ ṭhita kappo saḥ assa atthi iti ṭhita kappī kappam ṭhapetum samatthaḥ ti attho
translated: The aeon that is standing is the standing aeon. He who has that is the one who has the standing aeon. The meaning is: he is able to stand for an aeon.

original: Olokananti saccābhisamayasaṅkhātaṃ dassanaṃ. Khamanti sahanti, ñāyantīti attho.🔽Cakkhusuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: olokanam ti sacca abhisamaya saṅkhātam dassanam khamanti sahanti ñāyanti iti attho  cakkhu sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The seeing called the penetration of the truths is the looking. They endure, they bear up, is the meaning.🔽The commentary on the Discourse on the Eye is finished.

original: Okkantasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: okkanta saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Connected Discourses on Entering is finished.

original: 5. Uppādasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Connected Discourses on Arising

original: 312-321. Sabbaṃ pākaṭameva apubbassa abhāvato.
analyzed: sabbam pākaṭam eva apubbassa abhāvato
translated: Everything is clear, because there is nothing new.

original: Uppādasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uppāda saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Connected Discourses on Arising is finished.

original: 6. Kilesasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Connected Discourses on Corruption

original: 322-331. Esoti cakkhusmiṃ chandarāgo. Upecca kilesetīti upakkileso. Cittassāti sāmaññavacanaṃ
analyzed: eso ti cakkhusmim chanda rāgo upecca kileseti iti upakkileso cittassa ti sāmañña vacanam
translated: ‘This’ is will and lust for the eye. ‘Contaminant’ is defilement. ‘Of the mind’ is a general term.

original: anicchanto codako “kataracittassā”ti āha. Itaro kāmaṃ upatāpanamalīnabhāvakaraṇavasena
analyzed: an icchanto katara cittassa ati āha itaro kāmam upatāpana malīna bhāva karaṇa vasena
translated: The accuser, not wanting to admit it, said, ‘Of what kind of mind?’ The other said,

original: upakkileso lokuttarassa natthi, vibādhanaṭṭho pana attheva uppattinivāraṇatoti adhippāyenāha
analyzed: upakkileso lokuttarassa na atthi vibādhana ṭṭhaḥ pana attheva uppatti nivāraṇato ti adhippāyena āha
translated: ‘Although the supramundane mind has no contaminant in the sense of causing torment and depression, still it has a contaminant in the sense of obstruction, since it prevents the arising of the supramundane mind.’

original: “catubhūmakacittassā”ti. Codako “tebhūmakā”tiādinā attano adhippāyaṃ vivarati, itaro🔽“uppattinivāraṇato”tiādinā. Ariyaphalapaṭippassaddhipahānavasena pavattiyā sabbasaṃkilesato
analyzed: catu bhūmaka cittassa ati codakaḥ tebhūmaka ati ādinā attanaḥ adhippāyam vivarati itaro  uppatti nivāraṇataḥ tiādinā ariya phala paṭippassaddhi pahāna vasena pavattiyā sabba saṃkilesato
translated: The accuser said, ‘Of the three kinds of mind,’ etc., revealing his own intention. The other said,🔽‘Since it prevents the arising of the supramundane mind,’ etc.

original: nikkhantattā nekkhammaṃ, magganibbānānaṃ pana nekkhammabhāvo ukkaṃsato gahito evāti
analyzed: nikkhanta ttā nekkhammam magga nibbānānam pana nekkhamma bhāvaḥ ukkaṃsataḥ gahitaḥ eva ati
translated: ‘World-transcending’ is renunciation, since it occurs by the abandoning of the fruit of the noble path through tranquilizing. The world-transcending nature of the path and Nibbāna is taken in the sense of the highest degree,

original: āha “nekkhammaninnanti navalokuttaradhammaninna”nti. Abhijānitvāti abhimukhabhāvena
analyzed: āha nekkhamma ninnanti nava lokuttara dhamma ninnanti abhijānitvā iti abhimukha bhāvena
translated: so he said, ‘World-transcending’ means ‘inclined to the nine supramundane states.’ ‘Having known’ means having known by way of direct knowledge.

original: jānitvā. Sacchikātabbesūti paccakkhakātabbesu. Chaḷabhiññādhammesūti ariyamaggasampayuttadhammesu.
analyzed: jānitvā sacchikātabbesu iti paccakkha kātabbesu chaḍḍabhiññā dhammesu ti ariya magga sampayutta dhammesu
translated: ‘In what should be directly known’: in what should be directly seen. ‘In the six things that are his direct knowledges’: in the things associated with the noble path.

original: Kilesasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kilesa saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the connected fileds of the defilements is ended.

original: 7. Sāriputtasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: sāriputtasaṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with Sāriputta

original: 1-9. Vivekajasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: viveka ja sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the “Born of Seclusion” Discourse, etc.

original: 332-340. Na evaṃ hotīti ettha “ahaṃ samāpajjāmī”ti vā, “ahaṃ samāpanno”ti vā mā hotu
analyzed: na evam hoti iti ettha aham samāpajjāmi iti vā aham samāpannaḥ ti vā mā hotu
translated: “It does not occur thus”: let there be no “I am attaining” or “I have attained”🔽because there is no such activity then. But why does “I am emerging” not occur?

original: tadā tādisābhogābhāvato. “Ahaṃ vuṭṭhito”ti pana kasmā na hotīti? Sabbathāpi na hotveva
analyzed: tadā tādisa ābhoga abhāvato aham vuṭṭhito ti pana kasmā na hoti iti sabbathā api na hotvā eva
translated: It does not occur at all

original: ahaṅkārassa sabbaso pahīnattā.
analyzed: ahaṅkārassa sabbaso pahīna ttā
translated: because self-identification has been completely abandoned.

original: Vivekajasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: viveka ja sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the “Born of Seclusion” Discourse, etc. is ended.

original: 10. Sūcimukhīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sūcimukhī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Needle-Mouth Discourse

original: 341. Tasmiṃ vacane paṭikkhitteti – “adhomukho bhuñjasī”ti paribbājikāya vuttavacane
analyzed: tasmim vacane paṭikkhittā iti adhomukhaḥ bhuñjasi iti paribbājikāya vutta vacane
translated: “When that statement was denied”: when the female wanderer’s statement “You eat with your face down”🔽was denied by “I am not a sister, friend” .

original: – “na khvāhaṃ bhaginī”ti paṭikkhitte. Vādanti dosaṃ. Ubbhamukhoti uparimukho. Puratthimādikā
analyzed: na khvā aham bhaginī iti paṭikkhitte vā adanti dosam ubbhamukho ti upari mukhaḥ puratthima ādikā
translated: “They said”: they spoke. “With his face up”: with his face turned upwards. The four directions are the east, etc.

original: catasso disā. Dakkhiṇapuratthimādikā catasso vidisā.
analyzed: catasso disāḥ dakkhiṇa puratthima ādikā catasso vidisā
translated: The four intermediate directions are the south-east, etc.

original: Ārāmaārāmavatthuādīsu bhūmiparikammabījābhisaṅkharaṇādipaṭisaṃyuttā vijjā vatthuvijjā,
analyzed: ārāma ārāma vatthu ādīsu bhūmi parikamma bīja abhisaṅkharaṇa ādi paṭisaṃyuttāḥ vijjāḥ vatthu vijjā
translated: In the case of the “ground-divining” and the “seed-divining” mentioned in the case of the “garden-site” and so on, the “knowledge” is the knowledge of the ground-divining and the seed-divining, respectively.

original: tassā pana micchājīvabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “tesa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tesaṃ tesaṃ attano paccayadāyakānaṃ.
analyzed: tassā pana micchājīva bhāvam dassetum tesam ti ādi vuttam tesam tesam attanaḥ paccaya dāyakānam
translated: The words “in the case of those” are stated in order to show that these are also wrong means of livelihood.

original: Tattha tattha gamananti tesaṃ sāsanaharaṇavasena taṃ taṃ gāmantaradesantaraṃ. Evamārocesīti🔽attukkaṃsanaparavambhanarahitaṃ kaṇṇasukhaṃ pemanīyaṃ hadayaṅgamaṃ therassa dhammakathaṃ
analyzed: tattha tattha gamanam ti tesam sāsana haraṇa vasena tam tam gām antara desa antaram evam ārocesi iti  attukkaṃsana para vambhana rahitam kaṇṇa sukham pemanīyam hadayaṅgamam therassa dhamma katham
translated: “Going here and there” means going from one village to another or from one country to another in order to bring messages to those who are the givers of requisites.🔽“Thus he spoke” means that he spoke the Elder’s Dhamma talk, which was pleasing to the ear, delightful, and went to the heart, without self-praise or disparagement of others.

original: sutvā pasannamānasā evaṃ “dhammikaṃ samaṇā sakyaputtiyā”tiādinā sāsanassa guṇasaṃkittanavācaṃ kulānaṃ ārocesi.
analyzed: sutvā pasanna mānasā evam dhammikam samaṇā sakyaputtiyā ati ādinā sāsanassa guṇa saṃkittana vācam kulānam ārocesi
translated: Having heard it, they were pleased and spoke these words in praise of the Dispensation: “The Sakyan-son contemplatives are right-living.”

original: Sūcimukhīsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sūcimukhī sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sūcimukha Sutta is finished.

original: Sāriputtasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sāriputtasaṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sāriputta Saṃyutta is finished.

original: 8. Nāgasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: nāga saṃyuttam
translated: The Nāga Saṃyutta

original: 1. Suddhikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: suddhika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Suddhīka Sutta

original: 342. Aṇḍajāti aṇḍe jātā. Vatthikoseti vatthikosasaññite jarāyupuṭe jātā. Saṃsedeti
analyzed: aṇḍa jāti aṇḍe jātā vatthikosā iti vatthi kosa saññite jarāyupuṭe jātā saṃsedā iti
translated: The egg-born are born from eggs. The womb-born are born from a womb, that is, from the enclosed place of decay. The moisture-born are born from moisture. The spontaneously-born are born by mere desire.

original: saṃsinne kilinnaṭṭhāne uppannā. Upapatitvā viyāti kutocipi avapatitvā viya nibbattā.
analyzed: saṃsinne kilinna ṭhāne uppannā upapatitvā viya ati kutocipi avapatitvā viya nibbattā
translated: Having fallen down: as if fallen down from somewhere.

original: Puggalānanti tathā vinetabbapuggalānaṃ.
analyzed: puggalānam ti tathā vinetabba puggalānam
translated: Persons: persons to be trained in such a way.

original: Suddhikasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: suddhika sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Suddhikasutta is finished.

original: 2-50. Paṇītatarasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽343-391. Vissaṭṭhakāyāti “ye cammena vā rudhirena vā aṭṭhinā vā atthikā, te sabbaṃ
analyzed: paṇītatara sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  vissaṭṭhakāya ati ye cammena vā rudhirena vā aṭṭhinā vā atthikā te sabbaṃ
translated: The explanation of the Paṇītatarasutta, etc.

original: gaṇhantū”ti tattha nirapekkhacittatāya adhiṭṭhitasīlatāya pariccattasarīrā. Duvidhakārinoti
analyzed: gaṇhantu uti tattha nirapekkha citta tāya adhiṭṭhita sīla tāya pariccatta sarīrāḥ duvidha kārino ti
translated: Their bodies are cast off: they have given up their bodies by their determination to be indifferent to them, thinking, “Let those who want skin take the skin, let those who want blood take the blood, let those who want bones take the bones, and let those who want the whole body take the whole body.”

original: “kālena kusalaṃ, kālena akusala”nti evaṃ kusalākusalakārino. Saha byayati pavattatīti
analyzed: kālena kusalam kālena akusalanti evam kusala akusala kārino saha byayati pavattati iti
translated: They are doers of two kinds: they are doers of what is wholesome and unwholesome, thinking, “Sometimes we will do what is wholesome, sometimes what is unwholesome.”🔽A companion is a co-farer. The state of that is companionship.

original: sahabyo, sahacāro. Tassa bhāvo sahabyatā, taṃ sahabyataṃ. Adanīyato annaṃ. Khādanīyato🔽khajjaṃ. Pātabbato pānaṃ. Nivasanīyato vatthaṃ. Nivasitabbaṃ nivāsanaṃ. Parivaritabbaṃ
analyzed: sahabyaḥ sahacāro tassa bhāvaḥ sahabya tā tam sahabya tam adanīyataḥ annam khādanīyataḥ  khajjam pātabbataḥ pānam nivasanīyataḥ vattham nivasitabbam nivāsanam parivaritabbam
translated: Food is so called because it is not to be eaten now .🔽A drink is so called because it is to be drunk.🔽Clothing is so called because it is to be worn.

original: pāvuraṇaṃ. Yānti tenāti yānaṃ, upāhanādiyānāni. Ādisaddena vayhasivikādīnaṃ saṅgaho.
analyzed: pāvuraṇam yānti tena ati yānam upāhana ādi yānāni ādi saddena vayha sivika ādīnam saṅgahaḥ
translated: A vehicle is so called because one goes by it. The word “etc.” includes carriages, palanquins, etc.

original: Chattampi parissayātapadukkhaparirakkhaṇena maggagamanasādhananti katvā “chattupāhana”ntiādi
analyzed: chattam pi parissaya ātapa dukkha parirakkhaṇena magga gamana sādhananti katvā chattupāhana ntiādi
translated: The sunshade too is a means of accomplishing the journey by protecting from the suffering and weariness of the journey. So it is said: “Sunshade and sandals” .🔽

original: vuttaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ “yaṃ kiñci gamanapaccaya”nti. Patthanaṃ katvā…pe… tattha nibbattanti
analyzed: vuttam tena vuttam yam kiñci patthanam katvā āpe tattha nibbattanti
translated: The sunshade is also a means of going on the journey since it protects from the suffering and annoyance of heat, and so on, and so it is said, “sunshade and sandals,” and so on. That is why it is said, “Whatever is a condition for going” .🔽. . . and are reborn there.

original: campeyyanāgarājā viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: campeyya nāga rājā viyā ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: . . . like the Nāga king Campaka.

original: Paṇītatarasuttādivaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṇītatara sutta ādi vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Paṇītatarasutta is ended.

original: Nāgasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nāga saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Nāga Saṃyutta is ended.

original: 9. Supaṇṇasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Supaṇṇa Saṃyutta

original: 392-437. Pattānanti ubhosu pakkhesu pattānaṃ. Vaṇṇavantatāyāti atisayena vicittavaṇṇatāya.
analyzed: pattānam ti ubhosu pakkhesu pattānam vaṇṇavanta tāya ati atisayena vicitta vaṇṇa tāya
translated: . . . with wings on both sides. . . . With beautiful colours: with very varied colours.🔽For the word vanta is used in the sense of “very.”

original: Atisayattho hi ayaṃ vanta-saddo. Purimanayenāti nāgasaṃyutte paṭhamasutte vuttanayena.🔽Uddharantīti samuddato uddharanti, pathavantarapabbatantarato pana tesaṃ uddharaṇaṃ
analyzed: ati saya atthaḥ hi ayam vanta saddo purima nayena ati nāga saṃyutte paṭhama sutte vutta nayena  uddharanti iti samuddataḥ uddharanti pathavantara pabbata antarataḥ pana tesam uddharaṇam
translated: . . . in the way stated in the first sutta of the Nāga Saṃyutta.🔽They take them out of the ocean, but it is difficult for them to take them out of the gullies and clefts in the mountains.

original: dukkarameva. Paṇītatareti balena paṇītatare, balavanteti attho. Anuddharaṇīyanāgāti
analyzed: dukkaram eva paṇītatarā iti balena paṇītatare balavantā iti atthaḥ an uddharaṇīya nāgā ati
translated: . . . more powerful: more powerful in strength, is the meaning. A nāga that cannot be taken out by them

original: ānubhāvamahantatāya ca vasanaṭṭhānaviduggatāya ca uddharituṃ asakkuṇeyyā nāgā. Te
analyzed: ānubhāva mahanta tāya ca vasanaṭṭhāna viduggatāya ca uddharitum a sakkuṇeyyāḥ nāgā te
translated: and because of the greatness of their power and because of the difficulty of their abode, they are incapable of being lifted out.

original: “sattavidhā”ti vatvā sarūpato vasanaṭṭhānato ca dassento “kambalassatarā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: sattavidhā iti vatvā sarūpataḥ vasana ṭṭhānataḥ ca dassentaḥ kambalassatarā ti ādim āha
translated: After saying “sevenfold,” he said “Kambalassataras, Dhataraṭṭhas,” etc., in order to show them by their individual characteristics and by their abode.

original: Tattha kambalassatarā dhataraṭṭhāti ime jātivasena vuttā. Sattasīdantaravāsinoti
analyzed: tattha kambalassatarā dhataraṭṭhā ti ime jāti vasena vuttā
translated: Herein, Kambalassataras and Dhataraṭṭhas are mentioned according to species. Sattasīdantaravāsino

original: sattavidhasīdasamuddavāsino. Pathaviṭṭhakāti pathavantaravāsino, tathā pabbataṭṭhakā.
analyzed: sattavidha sīda samudda vāsinaḥ pathaviṭṭhakā ati pathavantara vāsinaḥ tathā pabbataṭṭhakā
translated: are those who live in the seven great lakes. Pathaviṭṭhakas are those who live in the earth, and so are pabbataṭṭhakas.

original: Te ca vimānavāsino. Te nāge koci supaṇṇo uddharituṃ na sakkotīti sambandho. Sesanti
analyzed: te ca vimāna vāsinaḥ te nāge koci su paṇṇaḥ uddharitum na sakkoti iti sambandhaḥ
translated: And they are those who live in mansions. No supaṇṇa can lift out those nāgas. The connection is this. The rest

original: “kāyena dvayakārino”tiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ nāgasaṃyutte vuttanayameva,
analyzed: kāyena dvaya kārinā iti ādīsu yam vattabbam tam sabbam nāgasaṃyutte vutta nayam eva
translated: is all to be construed as in the Nāga-Samyutta.

original: tattha ca vuttanayeneva attho veditabboti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tattha ca vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: And the meaning should be understood in the way already stated there.

original: Supaṇṇasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: supaṇṇa saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Supaṇṇa Samyutta is ended.

original: 10. Gandhabbakāyasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Gandhabba-kāya Samyutta

original: 438-549. Mūlagandhādibhedaṃ gandhaṃ avanti apayuñjantīti gandhabbā, tesaṃ kāyo samūho
analyzed: mūla gandha ādi bhedam gandham avanti apayuñjanti iti gandhabbā tesam kāyaḥ samūhaḥ
translated: The Gandhabbas are those who enjoy scents, i.e., those who use scents of roots, etc., as their enjoyment. Their body is a collection of them.

original: gandhabbakāyo, gandhabbadevanikāyo. Cātumahārājikesu ekiyāva te daṭṭhabbā, tappariyāpannatāya
analyzed: gandhabba kāyaḥ gandhabba devanikāyo cātumahārājikesu ekiyā ava te daṭṭhabbā tad pariyāpanna tāya
translated: The Gandhabbakaya is the class of the Gandhabbas. They should be regarded as being included among the Caturmahārājikas,🔽because they are subject to them. Or they are called Gandhabbakaya because they are stationed there.

original: tattha vā niyuttāti gandhabbakāyikā. Tesaṃ tesaṃ rukkhagacchalatānaṃ mūlaṃ paṭicca🔽pavatto gandho mūlagandho, tasmiṃ mūlagandhe. Adhivatthāti mūlagandhaṃ adhiṭṭhāya,
analyzed: tattha vā niyuttā ati gandhabba kāyikā tesam tesam rukkhagaccha latānam mūlam paṭicca  pavattaḥ gandhaḥ mūla gandhaḥ tasmin mūla gandhe adhivattha ati mūla gandham adhiṭṭhāya
translated: The scent that occurs in dependence on the roots, trunks, branches, and foliage of various trees and creepers is called “root scent,” etc.🔽Stationed in the root scent, etc., means dwelling having resolved upon the root scent, etc., or having overcome them. The same method applies to the rest.

original: abhibhuyya vā vasantā. Esa nayo sesesupi. Taṃ nissāyāti taṃ mūlagandhaṃ rukkhaṃ paccayaṃ
analyzed: abhibhuyya vā vasantā esa nayo sesesu pi tam nissāya ati tam mūla gandham rukkham paccayam
translated: Having that as their support means having that root scent, etc., as their support, i.e., having been produced with a tree as their support.

original: katvā nibbattā. Na kevalaṃ tattha gandho eva, mūlameva vā tesaṃ paccayoti dassento
analyzed: katvā nibbattā na kevalam tattha gandhaḥ eva mūlam eva vā tesam paccayaḥ ti dassento
translated: The intention is that not only scent or roots are their support.🔽To show this, he says, “For that reason … .” It is useful means it is employed as a dwelling place.

original: “so hī”tiādimāha. Upakappatīti nivāsaṭṭhānabhāvena viniyuñjati. Gandhagandheti gandhānaṃ
analyzed: saḥ hi itiādim āha upakappati iti nivāsa ṭṭhāna bhāvena viniyuñjati gandha gandha iti
translated: The scent of scents means the scent of scents.

original: gandhasamudāye. Mūlādigandhānaṃ gandheti mūlādigataavayavagandhānaṃ gandhe, timūlādigatasamudāyabhūteti🔽attho. Pubbe hi “mūlagandhe”tiādinā rukkhānaṃ avayavagandho gahito, idha pana sabbaso🔽gahitattā samudāyagandho veditabbo. Tenāha “yassa hi rukkhassā”tiādi. Soti so sabbo🔽mūlādigato gandho gandhasamudāyo idha gandhagandho nāma. Tassa gandhassa gandheti
analyzed: gandha samudāye mūla ādi gandhānam gandha iti mūla ādi gata avayava gandhānam gandhe ti mūla ādi gata samudāya bhūta iti  atthaḥ pubbe hi mūla gandha iti ādinā rukkhānam avayava gandho gahitaḥ idha pana sabbaso  gahita ttā samudāya gandhaḥ veditabbo tena āha yassa hi rukkhassa atiādi saḥ ti so sabbo  mūla ādi gataḥ gandhaḥ gandha samudāyaḥ gandha gandhaḥ nāma tassa gandhassa gandha iti
translated: In a mass of scents. In the scents of scents of roots, etc., i.e. in the scents of the component parts of roots, etc. The meaning is: in the scents that are the mass of scents in roots, etc. For previously, with the words “scents of roots, etc.,” the scents of the component parts of trees were taken. But here the mass of scents should be understood as being taken entirely. Hence he said: “For whatever tree,” etc. That, i.e. all that scent in roots, etc., the mass of scents, is called here the scent of scents. In the scent of that scent,🔽🔽

original: tassa samudāyagandhassa tathābhūte gandhe. Sarikkhaṃ sadisaṃ paṭidānaṃ etissāti sarikkhadānaṃ,🔽patthanā. Yathādhippetaphalāni sarikkhadānattāva adhippetaphalaṃ dentu, asarikkhadānaṃ
analyzed: tassa samudāya gandhassa tathābhūte gandhe sa rikkham sadisam paṭidānam etissa ati sa rikkha dānam  patthanā yathā adhippeta phalāni adhippeta phalam dentu a sarikkha dānam
translated: In a mass of scents. In the scents of scents of roots, etc., is the meaning. For previously in the phrase “scents of roots, etc.,” the scents of the parts of trees were intended, but here the scent of the whole should be understood as intended because of the inclusion of all. That is why he said “of whatever tree” and so on. That is to say, that whole scent of roots, etc., is a mass of scents. That is called “the scent of scents.” In the scents of that scent is the meaning. The giving of what is similar is the giving of what is like.

original: kathanti? Tampi detiyeva puññassa sabbakāmadadattāti āha “asarikkhadānampī”tiādi.
analyzed: katham ti tam pi detiyā iva puññassa āha a sarikkha dānam pi itiādi
translated: The wish. May they give the fruit intended, since they give what is similar to the fruit intended. How is it that he gives what is dissimilar? He gives that too, since he gives all that is wished for. That is why he said “He gives what is dissimilar too” and so on.

original: Gandhabbakāyasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gandhabbakāyasaṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the Connected Discourses with Gandhabbas is finished.

original: 11. Valāhakasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: valāhakasaṃyutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Connected Discourses with Valāhas

original: 550-606. Lokaṃ vālentā saṃvarantā chādentā ahanti pariyesantīti valāhā, devaputtā.
analyzed: lokam vālentā saṃvarantā chādentā ahanti pariyesanti iti valāhā deva puttā
translated: The gods called Valāha are so called because they cover, conceal, beat, and seek the world.🔽The word valāhaka is a plural form derived from the word valāha.

original: Tesaṃ samūho valāhakadevakāyoti āha “valāhakakāyikā”tiādi. Sītakaraṇavalāhakāti sītaharaṇavalāhakā.
analyzed: tesam samūhaḥ āha valāhaka kāyikā atiādi sīta karaṇa valāhakā ati sīta haraṇa valāhakā
translated: The word sītakaraṇa is a gerundive formed from the verb sītaṃ karotī.

original: Sesapadesūti uṇhavalāhakādipadesu. Eseva nayoti “uṇhakaraṇavalāhakā”tiādinā attho
analyzed: sesa padesu iti uṇha valāhaka ādi padesu esā iva nayo ti uṇha karaṇa valāhaka ati ādinā attho
translated: The word uṇhavalāhaka is a compound word formed by the method of apposition.🔽The word cittaṭṭhapana is a gerundive formed from the verb cittaṃ ṭhapeti.

original: veditabbo. Cittaṭṭhapananti “sītaṃ hotū”ti evaṃ cittassa uppādanaṃ. Vassāneti vassakāle.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ citta ṭṭhapananti sītam hotu uti evam cittassa uppādanam vassāneti vassa kāle
translated: The word vassā is a gerundive formed from the verb vassati.🔽The word utusamuṭṭhāna is a compound word formed by the method of apposition.

original: Utusamuṭṭhānamevāti pākatikasītamevāti attho. Uṇhepīti uṇhakāle. Abbhamaṇḍapoti maṇḍapasadisaabbhapaṭalavitānamāha.
analyzed: utu samuṭṭhānam eva āti pākatika sītam eva āti attho uṇhe pi iti uṇha kāle abbha maṇḍapo ti maṇḍapa sadisa abbha paṭala vitānam āha
translated: The word abbhamaṇḍapa is a compound word formed by the method of apposition.🔽The word abbhupajjati is a gerundive formed from the verb abbhaṃ uppajjati.

original: Abbhaṃ uppajjatīti tahaṃ tahaṃ paṭalaṃ uṭṭhahati. Abbheyevāti abbhakāle eva, vassāneti🔽attho. Atiabbhanti satapaṭalasahassapaṭalaṃ hutvā abbhuṭṭhānaṃ. Cittavesākhamāsesūti
analyzed: abbham uppajjati iti taham taham paṭalam uṭṭhahati abbheya iva ati abbha kāle eva vassāneti 🔽atthaḥ atiabbhanti sata paṭala sahassa paṭalam hutvā abbhuṭṭhānam citta vesākha māsesu iti
translated: The word abbheva is a gerundive formed from the verb abbhaṃ karoti.🔽The word atiabbha is a compound word formed by the method of apposition.

original: vasantakālaṃ sandhāyāha. Tadā hi viddho vigatavalāhako devo bhavituṃ yutto. Uttaradakkhiṇādīti
analyzed: vasanta kālam sandhāya āha tadā hi viddhaḥ vigata valāhakaḥ devaḥ bhavitum yuttaḥ uttara dakkhiṇa ādi iti
translated: He says this referring to the spring season. For then the rain-cloud, having been pierced, is fit to be the rain-god. ‘From the north, the south, etc.’

original: ādi-saddena pacchimavātādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Pakativātoti pakatiyā sabhāvena vāyanakavāto.
analyzed: ādi saddena pacchima vāta ādim saṅgaṇhāti pakati vāto ti pakatiyā sabhāvena vāyanaka vāto
translated: By the word ‘etc.’ he includes the west wind, etc. ‘Natural wind’ is the wind that blows by nature or by itself.

original: Taṃ utusamuṭṭhānamevāti āhārūpajīvīnaṃ sattānaṃ sādhāraṇakammūpanissayautusamuṭṭhānameva.
analyzed: tam utu samuṭṭhānam eva ati āhāra upajīvīnam sattānam sādhāraṇa kamma upanissaya otu samuṭṭhānam eva
